151056984.review:
One of the most unique and immersive games I've played. This game is essentially Dishonored in space, which makes sense, considering Prey is made by the same studio as Dishonored. The combat is clean and incredibly satisfying and at some points can be very challenging. The challenge forces the player to uses the plethora of weapon options and abilities at their disposal. 
The world/environment is where this game shines. It all takes place in and around a single space station and this space station is huge. There are tons of hidden rooms and compartments, locked areas containing gear and bits of lore. It really feels like this was a functioning space station at one point. You spend a lot of time chasing storylines that took place before the disaster and learning about the people who lived on this space station. 
The story is decent and has a somewhat predictable twist but the path to get to that twist is enjoyable. 

The only negative I can think of is that a few sections are a bit tedious to get through. Extended areas where you are forced to use zero gravity can become annoying. Most of these sections come at the end of the game where the player should be powered up enough to blast through them but if not, it can turn into a slog. The first 15 hours of gameplay are phenomenal though. Highly recommend.

150551795.review:
TLDR: How did i sleep on this. Must buy for those who love Alien Isolation or immersive sim in general. Flawed but ultimately enjoyable. Warrants a sequel.

Pros:
1. Hours of exploration
2. Eerie atmosphere, though admittedly not as scary as Alien Isolation
3. Easier to progress compared to Alien Isolation where you have lots of petrifying moments
4. Personally not a fan of art deco, but the art direction here really grows on me
5. Clever crafting mechanic and skill tree
6. Lots of different enemy types with unique features and weaknesses, keeping you busy and challenged

Cons:
1. Audio is too loud even after reducing by 50%
2. Sound design is not as good as the award winning Alien Isolation, gauging enemy's proximity is especially tougher here
3. Secondary attack and Exit UI are merged into one key, resulting in accidental firing at Fabricators (see #4)
4. Inconsistent UX for Fabricators where you don't have to exit the UI after pressing Create, with the rest (Recyclers, Workstations) where you need to right click to exit the UI
5. Map and objective tracker are confusing especially when you have many objectives tracked at once, but you can just explore and eventually you'll get to where you're supposed to
6. Some weapons are powerful enough for you to lose the fear factor
7. Inconsistent mechanics on some weapons and secondary attacks, some require you to aim first, some don't
8. Surprise enemies that spot you right after the loading screen when traveling to particular levels
9. Hacking can be frustrating
10. Operators sometimes disappear or stuck in unreachable places

150525488.review:
This game is equally an amazing, frustrating and depressing experience. When you're finished, you'll think "there was so much potential here for greatness." Wasted in the end by some bad circumstances, I think. 

What is good: 

1) Bioshock was touted as a spiritual successor to System Shock 2, well that notion can GTFOOH- if you've played SS2 you'll understand Prey's mechanics instantly, 

2} there's a rather detailed and interesting backstory going on, with an alternative timeline Earth that split off somewhere in the late 1950's Cold War Era...and took a very different path going forward.

3) you can progress as a Lawful Good, Chaotic Evil, or in-between character. Surviving crew are killable, you can do some really depraved stuff if you're inclined. Sorta refreshing.

4) Practically everything can be achieved with at least 3 options. Creativity can be rewarded. Exploring yeild treasures, clues, and interesting finds. You can literally skip chunks of progression via clever/ unconventional thinking. If you're a "cut to the chase" person, about 40% of the map requires no exploration, and has no impact on progression.

5) All the humans have names or identifiers. About 90% of them have distinct faces. Nice to see a departure from a limited cookie cutter appearance pool.

6) Play your way upgrades-be a thief, a soldier, an assassin, a science nerd, or a wizard. You have options!

7) Recycle Grenades-I cannot stress how FREAKING FUN these things are! You can set them as traps, use them as weapons, breach obstacles, and most importantly, you get resources for you trouble. You can reduce chairs, tools...and dead crew members into useful materials. One of the neatest gadgets ever!

And the not so good:

1) Hacking-one of the highest cost skills to obtain, and the only one  that has one of the worst minigames attached to it. I'd best describe it as "Maze Pong from Hell"- it is difficult to work if you keyboard play, and it repeats on higher difficulties. It's on a timer, there are no "modifiers" to gain time, reduce the challenge, etc. You time out, you get shocked. This would have worked if you were hacking unskilled (or under skilled) but otherwise it's butt stupid and annoying as hell. Thankfully there are at least 3 mods that reduce the difficulty or eliminate the game altogether. I recommend them highly.

2) This game has a wack ass spawning system. It's non-existent at first, then starts, progresses, intensifies, to the point where it's near constant at the end. Not my favorite thing.

3) If you are a explorer with a "see the sights" approach, you will not like the switch near the 3rd quarter mark. let's just say, the pace changes, and while you can still take it slow, there's gonna be pain involved for that choice.

4) The end-I thought it was cool for 60 seconds, then I hated it intensely. A terrible ending in my opinion, it's enough of a finale to deter you from replaying the game. It's that bad...they could have chosen several other outcomes, would have had close to the same results...and would have kept you playing.

Other musings:

Low gravity conditions are fun! There's a lot of pretty scenery. Difficulty in my opinion scales "one level higher" than the listing. I play on normal, it feels like the hard setting on mot other games I've played. For complete masochists, there are optional traumas you can engage, weapon and suit degrading that will make your life miserable. Be warned...there were last minute additions and went through little play-testing prior to the release, and it shows. You can get whacked and have several of your "idiot lights" appear at once, and you will really be in it deep.

Pick it up on sale and give it a whirl. It prompted me to type this ridiculously long review!

One of the best singleplayer games out there tbh, I played through the game way back when it released while I was sailing the seven seas (rough times back then), and the game was a blast to playthrough, so ignore the low playtime during review.

This game is like if Dishonored and Deus Ex had a baby, abilities and skills are useful and fun to play around with but never required, there are always alternative routes to do an objective even when no abilities are unlocked, you just have to explore more and think outside the box sometimes (Gloo Gun is extremely useful).

The atmosphere is amazing, this game is a horror game that doesn't even try, it's scazy, it's frightening, everything can be and IS probably a mimic.

Really sad that the game got a ton of undeserved hate on release, the 2016-2019 singleplayer era of gaming was truly something different.

150339741.review: First of all, I really enjoyed this game! It had a really interesting story and the alien species in it was cool too. I had some idea that something wasn't right during the campaign but I didn't expect the twist at the end of it where [spoiler] Morgan was in a simulation the whole time but it wasn't even Morgan you play as, instead it's one of the Typhon that Alex has captured and is implanting Morgan's memories into trying to see if human feelings like empathy can be implanted into the alien's biology as the Typhon have already taken over Earth and Alex is trying to see if the alien being in a simulation with choices (that the player makes) during the story can show evidence that the Typhon can have human emotions like altruism instead of purely existing to colonize and take over other life forms. [/spoiler] It was a really fun game and being able to scan all the alien forms and learn more about them was super cool (maybe that's just because I'm a biology major though). I will say however that navigating the space station is a little bit confusing and I had to look up a few times how I was supposed to get to certain areas because I had forgotten the layout of Talos I. Another thing I liked about the game was the skill trees and how you can manufacture the skill points (neuromods) instead of gaining them purely through something like exp. points so if you haven't been exploring everything and you feel under leveled you aren't S.O.L. and can fabricate some skill points assuming you have the right materials. It's pretty neat being able to use the same abilities as the alien species too it's kind of like prop hunt lol. All in all it was a VERY good game and had a lot of interesting concepts in it sparking thoughts like [b] "Are we the only planet in space with sentient life?" [/b] or [b] "Does extraterrestrial life have emotion like us?" [/b] also, very important note, upgrade your G.L.O.O. Cannon because it's pivotal for combat. 9.5/10 would recommend this game.

150337337.review: As a fan of the original Thief trilogy and Deus Ex, I love immersive sims, games that provide you with a world where you can achieve your goals through a myriad of inventive ways (incl. ways not considered by the creators of the game), leading to emergent gameplay. Prey doesn't disappoint. Definitely not your typical first person space shootout - this game is something much more interesting. I can definitely see myself playing it more than once.

Mmmm....no. Points for making an interesting game. Truly. But just no. No to game development. No to woke storyline.

You have lots of powers to kill things with. But you can't use them at all, because its a survival thing. Gotta save those upgrade points for plot skills (like upgrading your psychonaut helmet thing).

You have psychic abilities dangling at the forefront, to lift objects, to shoot energy beams, but you won't use them. Too expensive to use. Maybe next playthrough (new game +) And if you do get them, be prepared to use them like one time. This is due to your psychic abilities being limited. It probably will do a decent amount of damage though, should you choose to use them anyway. Probably.

Want to go Rambo style? Maybe skip the whole telepath thing for guns? Well that's gonna cost you lots of upgrade points. And if you want to simply upgrade your guns, well you can do a barebones upgrade, but then after that you have to invest in even more upgrade points to upgrade the guns even further. And simply upgrading the guns costs precious resources, of which you have few.

Alright fine. How about just melee mode. Use the wrench. Sorry can't upgrade that till way later. Want to upgrade your melee skills? Also that will cost a significant amount of neuromods (upgrade points). 
We need health to cover your melee, right? Lots of neuromods as well.

Okay, so let's just stick to the story then and not focus on combat. Well, you will get forcefed woke sjw nonsense the entirety of the time. Not kidding. It's not a sidequest thing. It's not something in the background. It's up in the forefront. In your face. Lots of Chayna is awesome references too (yeesh). 

This game was made in Austin, Texas. One of the cesspools of wokeness in Texas. (Albeit limited). I find it odd that there is so much (Chayna this, Chayna that).

In light of the fact that deathloop, and pretty much every other game from Arkane studios, during and after Prey is woke af (and suffering a severe quality famine), one must has to ask, is Arkane even a studio anymore? Or a recipient of foreign propaganda money?

150301600.review:
[h1]Don't waste your money[/h1]
Honestly, one of the worst games I've played recently, and that's counting indie games made by solo devs.

[h1]Good:[/h1]
+ The game went on 90% sale

[h1]Bad:[/h1]
- Graphics are just awful. For a game released in 2017, it looks like a student project. And I've seen student projects better than this. Textures are lazily done, lighting doesn't look realistic, some plants literally have stems that just float in mid air like the model wasn't finished. Holy hell. I'm sure some people will say that "it's stylized, it's not meant to look realistic!" but no. There's no consistency here. Sometimes they go for realistic, and other times it just looks goofy. Imagine TF2 characters in Modern Warfare. That's how this game looks.

- Movement feels bad. You're slow when walking and only marginally faster when sprinting. If you sprint backwards you can barely even see yourself speeding up. It's that bad

- Audio balancing is the worst I've seen in a AAA title. Sounds play like they're right next to your ear, even if the NPC is at the end of the corridor. This is the only game I've ever played where I had Speech volume set to half of Effects volume.

- Performance spikes wildly. Sometimes I get like 150fps, and other times I'm at 90fps. No idea why, maybe it's the location I was in

- The game feels incredibly unresponsive. Some actions are super fast, like crouching or opening your radial menu. Then there's weapon swapping. If I press 1 and immediately follow it with 2, I expect the first weapon swap to be cancelled prematurely so I can get to slot 2 faster. In this game however, they play the full animation out, and if you swap fast enough, they completely [b]IGNORE[/b] your second weapon swap. Piss poor controls

- Doors don't slide into gaps in the wall. They just clip through solid walls with solid "gaps" drawn onto them. Cheap and amateurish

- Skill tree is bland and uninteresting. It's just stat boosts, even creatively bankrupt games like Fallout 4 have more variety of perks and unlockable abilities. I'm not concerned with whether it gets better later in the game. It sucked, so I'm not interested in the rest.

- Throwing items in the game was both hilarious and terrible at the same time. When you take Leverage (I), you're supposed to throw stuff hard enough to damage enemies. The game [i]attempts[/i] to give you this feeling by animating a freaking shockwave behind the item you just threw. But then it falls like 3 feet away from you and the illusion is shattered to pieces, unlike the enemy I just threw the table at. It is also HILARIOUSLY difficult to hit enemies with thrown items. If I throw a god damn table, which is bigger than the mimic itself, it's laughable that it only does like 9 damage, which is barely a quarter of its health. I had to hit it with a thrown table at supersonic speed 4 times to kill it.

- The framerate of the inventory UI is really low for some reason? The rest of my game is moving at 90fps minimum, whereas the squares of my inventory animate at like 20-30fps max. I have no idea how this is a thing.

- All the budget for this game clearly went to Benedict Wong. Shame, because I didn't think his performance was that great, kinda like Keanu Reeves in Cyberpunk 2077. What a waste of development money.

- The funniest thing I experienced was having the poor quality of the game itself spoil the twist in the introduction. Looking out the window of my apartment, everything looked so crappy I instantly thought "this had better be a simulation". Turns out, yep it was a simulation. And the game looked terrible even after that fact was made known to me.

[h1]Overall: 2/10[/h1]
There is a game here, and that's all I can say about it. It is not a good game, nor one that you should invest time into. There are much better games out there that are actually worthy of your time. I cannot overstate this enough, but no love was put into this game. If you want to play a real single player superpower action game, go play Control instead.

150153976.review:
Prey a game that stands as a testament to the creativity and innovation in the realm of first-person action-adventure games. Released in 2017, Prey swiftly captured the attention of gamers with its engrossing story, unique gameplay mechanics, and the freedom it offers in exploration.

[h3]Storytelling and Exploration[/h3]
Prey shines brilliantly in its narrative and explorative aspects. The game is set aboard the Talos I space station, where you are thrown into a world overrun by an alien species known as the Typhon. The storytelling is masterfully woven into the environment. As you navigate through the labyrinthine corridors of the space station, you uncover the plot not just through traditional cutscenes or dialogues, but also via environmental storytelling. Every nook of the station, from the sprawling exteriors to the cramped offices, is filled with lore. Emails, audio logs, and scattered notes create a rich tapestry of stories that tell the tale of Talos I and its inhabitants. This approach to narrative ensures that the more you explore, the deeper your understanding of the game's lore becomes.

[h3]Jump Scares and Atmosphere[/h3]
The game brilliantly intersperses its exploration and narrative with well-timed jump scares and a consistently eerie atmosphere. These elements keep you on edge, making the exploration of Talos I both thrilling and unnerving. The unpredictable nature of the Typhon, especially the Mimics which can disguise themselves as almost any inanimate object, adds a layer of suspense and paranoia to the gameplay. This tension is further amplified by the game's sound design, where the hums and groans of the space station blend with the eerie sounds of the alien creatures lurking around.

[h3]Combat and Gameplay Mechanics[/h3]
Combat in Prey is where the game truly differentiates itself. The range of weapons and gadgets at your disposal is impressive. From conventional firearms to more exotic gear like the GLOO Cannon, which can immobilize enemies and create pathways, the arsenal is diverse and encourages creative combat strategies. The game also introduces neuromods, which allow you to gain alien abilities, adding another layer of depth to combat and exploration. This aspect of the game not only provides a robust combat experience but also impacts how you interact with the environment, solve puzzles, and navigate obstacles.

[h3]Awards and Recognition[/h3]
The game's excellence did not go unnoticed. It was nominated for several awards and notably won for Best Narrative. This accolade is a testament to the compelling story and the immersive world the developers crafted. The way the game merges its narrative, environment, and gameplay into a cohesive and engaging experience is truly commendable.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
Prey is more than just a game; it's an experience. It challenges conventional game design with its unique approach to storytelling and exploration. The blend of horror elements, innovative combat, and a deep, engaging story results in a game that is not just entertaining but also intellectually stimulating. Whether you're unraveling the mysteries of Talos I, outsmarting the Typhon, or simply soaking in the atmosphere, Prey offers a rich, fulfilling experience. It's a game that appeals to a wide range of players, from those who enjoy a good story to those who crave strategic combat and exploration. The game stands as a shining example of what can be achieved when innovative game design meets compelling storytelling.

[h3]Playtime Explanation[/h3]
I finished and played this game for an unknown amount of weeks back in 2017/2018 on a platform other than Steam.

[h1]🧠Great inmersive sim🖥️[/h1]

I played the original Prey from 2006 version of 2K but it never ended, a good and forgotten FPS. This game was different because the original was about Indian-American fighting aliens in the 2000s but this game is about neuroscience and space.

[h2]🎮Gameplay[/h2]

This is an immersive sim FPS similar to Bioshock, Deus Ex, etc... So the gameplay has all the RPG elements of those similar games but does it uniquely. You have elements like having Mimic powers, and weapons similar to the Half-Life series while having to make decisions historywise. There isn't much to say, those elements function very well.

[h2]📕History[/h2]

Neuroscience, experiments, low morality? Heck yeah! , you are in a scientific facility that is researching Typhon or Mimics. Something happens and everything goes wrong horribly. Your character, Alex needs to survive and fix this mess.

[h2]🎨Art[/h2] 

This game is still very pleasing to see, it aged very well. The ambience will scare the shit out of you or feel uneasy because of the Mimics so they did a great effort with the environment, sound design and SFX. The music is also very good.

[h2]🖥️Tested in this PC[/h2]

·RAM: 16 GB
·GPU: Radeon RX 590 Series
·Tons of storage more than enough to fit Ark Survival or the latest COD
·Resolution: 1920 x 1080
·OS: Windows 11
· It's a game from 2017, this PC ran it on Ultra without sweating.

[h2]❤️Final thoughts[/h2]

If you like immersive sims and games like Bioshock or Dishonored, you will love it. This is a game that didn't get much attention because it was released in a year with releases of BOTW, Horizon Zero Dawn, Resident Evil VII, Mario Oddysey, etc... What a great year of gaming was 2017, this game is the embodiment of "wait and there is more" of that year overall.

150119493.review:
[h1]Game Review: Prey[/h1]
[b]By Kiba Snowpaw, Furry Alpha Ice Wolf from HowlStrom[/b]

[h2]Title: Prey[/h2]
[h2]Platform: Steam[/h2]
[h2]Year: 2017[/h2]
[h2]Developer: Arkane Studios[/h2]
[h2]Publisher: Bethesda Softworks[/h2]

[h3]Introduction[/h3]
[i]As a seasoned gamer with a lifelong passion and a deep connection to my ice-wolf identity, I find "Prey" to be a uniquely immersive experience that transcends typical gaming boundaries.[/i]

[h3]Storyline and Setting[/h3]
You awaken as Morgan Yu, initially unaware of your past or the purpose of your presence on Talos I. The game masterfully weaves a narrative that is as unpredictable as it is engaging.

[h3]Gameplay Mechanics[/h3]
[b]"Prey" offers a unique blend of first-person action, exploration, and puzzle-solving.[/b] The combat is intense and strategic, demanding a careful balance between aggression and caution.

[h3]Alien Adversaries: The Typhon[/h3]
The Typhon, the alien species that has overrun Talos I, are as cunning and unpredictable as they are terrifying.

[h3]Graphics and Audio[/h3]
The visual and auditory design of "Prey" is a masterpiece of atmospheric storytelling.

[h3]Themes and Interpretations[/h3]
[i]At its core, "Prey" is a meditation on identity and the human condition.[/i]

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
In conclusion, "Prey" is more than just a game; it's an exploration of the human psyche set against the backdrop of an interstellar nightmare.

[b][u]Rating: 4.8/5 - A Howling Success[/u][/b]
"Prey" is a game that will haunt you long after you've left Talos I behind – a true gem in the vast universe of gaming.

[hr][/hr]

150096285.review:
[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- While the game did look pretty good, it was hard not to notice that it's aged a little bit. Character animations are noticeably clunky, for example. Not bad by any means, but I've played games from the same period that have held up a little better
- I particularly liked the setting and overall look of Talos 1. Arkane has a knack for theming environments well
- The sound design is god-tier. The great thematic soundtrack and the terrifying enemy screeching/roaring/chittering/etc really draw you in. Definitely a game to play with headphones
- The voice acting is also well done. Good performances all around

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- The story is a high point but contained more twists and turns than it honestly probably needed. I appreciate the writers' efforts to keep things interesting, though. I just wish they'd let the atmosphere do a little more of the talking and focused less on tossing you from plot point to plot point. I did, however, appreciate the post-credit twist despite my complaints
- Prey isn't really a horror game in the traditional sense. It feels more like a 1st person stealth action game, likely a byproduct of the fact that you'll often have tools or abilities that can conquer or capably evade most threats. Though I do like the little scripted sequences (the elevator one in particular--you'll know what I'm talking about when you experience it) that hammer home that you are, indeed, still playing a game with some scares
- The overall vibes are ominous, imposing, and mysterious. Paired with the sci-fi setting, it feels very Ridley Scott

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- If you've played Dishonored (another Arkane property), then you'll have a decent sense of how Prey plays. Given that you're on a space base, though, you won't be zipping between rooftops and scrambling up walls all parkour style
- That doesn't mean that the environment is an unimportant element, however. There's still plenty of branching paths that can take you to your objective. You really can avoid a good deal of combat if you're resourceful or observant enough. As I noted before, the level design is quite good, and that goes beyond appearances and factors meaningfully into gameplay
- Depending on the difficulty you're playing on, the game can feel very different. Easier difficulties play more like an FPS, but stealth and resource management start becoming increasingly important even on normal difficulty
- Gear and abilities also play a big part in how your playthrough will go. I did a full human run (no Typhon skills) for this playthough, which resulted in sneak attack, hit-and-run style gameplay that I found kinda fun. Sure, the psychic alien powers may have been more powerful and made me feel like a superhero, but I enjoyed how I had to plan out encounters, ration ammo, and switch weapons to get by with just the human skill trees

[b]Overall Impressions & Performance[/b]
- There just aren't a lot of games like Prey. Alien: Isolation and Dead Space come close to matching the tone and certainly match the setting (while also being stellar games), but those titles are far more straightforward in their respective approaches to gameplay. The immersive sim elements combined with the first-person perspective are simply better at drawing you into the experience and really make Prey stand out in my opinion
- If you're running modern hardware, you shouldn't experience too many performance issues outside of the rare stutter. I didn't encounter any bugs on my playthrough, either

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
- [b]9/10[/b]. Maybe just a slight step down from Dishonored, but it's still one of Arkane's best games. It often goes on sale for dirt cheap (it's 90% off as I'm writing this review), so I'd highly recommend giving it a shot if the setting or gameplay sound appealing

150092133.review:
I've played many hundreds of games in my life, and at the moment this is my favorite game of all time and has been for many years. 

- The environment is so well developed and multifaceted that it puts other entire gameworlds to shame. 
- The toolkit is efficient, every weapon has a use-case that doesn't overlap with the other weapons, not to mention many have applications outside of combat. 
- There are multiple ways to approach each problem and some will seem unsolvable until your third play through. If you pay close attention to the environment and think creatively about your toolkit, you will be shocked at how the game opens up to you. 
- The inventory management is tight and not overbearing while still being engaging, and the recycle mechanic allows the player to decide how they want to play the game and what tools they want more (or less) of. 
-Notice how I said nothing of the story, and that's because it is best if you go in blind! let this world surprise and engage you!

This game is true masterpiece, and everyday I hope for sequel.

149902337.review:
I think this game is neat due to the navigation changes entirely based on your skill point allocation. You can overcome your obstacles by building platforms, evaporating objects, hacking or repairing machines, looting keycards or codes left behind by the deceased or finding an alternative path from curiosity or keen eyes.

What is also neat about the game is the engagement with the environment, where anything you find lying on the ground or containers can be discarded as crafting materials. While searching around for loot, you also come across audio logs, journals and notes of people's experiences before and after the events of Talos 1 breakout, for example the experimentations and people's relationships with each other. 

The sound design is sort of a mess cause the voice acting plays directly in your ears instead of the world. However i can applaud the sound design of the guns, UI and soundtrack. 

For its biggest flaws, the combat and sidequests are dull along the UI being non responsive. Saving the game, equipping something shouldn't be so difficult with a mouse vs pressing enter.

TLDR: Garry's Mod prophunt with good storytelling and atmosphere, which includes metroidvania elements.

149854389.review:
Fantastic gameplay with an intriguing story and setting. The world-building and mechanics are quite well executed, so it's easy to get immersed in the role of Morgan Yu as they go from being a clueless wrench-wielding amnesiac to an unstoppable force with a purpose. Due to the expansive skill-tree and excellent level design, Prey accommodates pretty much any play style. The story can play out differently depending on the choices you make throughout, which can make it fun to revisit with multiple playthroughs as each time feels fresh.
Don't make the mistake of assuming that it's a Doom-like game where you're meant to mow down every opponent with your shotgun (though this can be achieved if you spec your Morgan out that way), it's much more akin to immersive-sims like BioShock, System Shock, or Arkane's own Dishonored series. Take in your surroundings, think on your feet, and be creative with the tools you acquire throughout as they all have more than one or two uses that aren't made explicit. Take your time, experiment, and have fun.

I still consider this the best modern immersive sim, but it has some annoyances that have kept me from replaying it. There are too many world-building readables. A larger percentage of the e-mails/notes should have some kind of gameplay relevance, and the number of messages in the game and their length should have been reduced.

Second big complaint is, there's junk to pick up everywhere. I know this is just how games are now, but I prefer how the Thief series has clear goals regarding the looting and has a strong narrative justification behind it. There are too many items to pick up, and each individual item doesn't impact gameplay enough.

I also don't think the combat is very fun. A lot of that probably comes down to enemy design. This is something Arkane usually excels at, but Dishonored or Dark Messiah this game is not.

I'm sure that all sounded very negative, but I still think the game is quite good. Certain aspects of it are peerless like the crew list system, other aspects are extremely strong like the level design. And while I don't like all of the skills, some of them are really good and have interesting interactions with other game systems. So I suppose my closing thought, I don't enjoy it enough to complete a second playthrough, but I still think very highly of the game.

"The Bioshock sequel the Bioshock fan doesn't deserve because they didn't play it": 

Prey is a game I put in the "I can't believe this game exists" category. Every department on this game is firing on all cylinders delivering a cohesive, extremely well thought out, beautiful experience. IMO, this is the best sci-fi game ever made, the best game from the xbox one/ps4 gen that nobody played, and top 5 greatest games of all time. 

We will never get another game like this again, unfortunately. This game got swept under the rug by the "open world craze" from the x1/ps4 gen and it didnt perform the way it needed to.. The studio lost 75% of staff with redfall.

148497025.review:
SCORE: 4/5

An all-time great immersive sim. Talos I is one of the best designed video game levels ever, a place that feels extremely satisfying and rewarding to explore. Every crewmember has a name whether they are alive or dead, many of them with interesting stories told through audio logs and terminals. It feels great to look around a new area, noting the stories and secrets and the large amount of options you have for how to navigate it and get into locked rooms.

The GLOO Cannon is an ingenious weapon, serving as both a way to incapacitate enemies in combat and as an aid in exploration, allowing you to create what are effectively bridges and staircases to access areas. The rest of the weapon roster is not as inventive, but is nonetheless still satisfying to use.

The upgrade system comes with the usual options for a game of this type (like hacking and increased inventory space, for example), but also contains some fun powers to unlock, like the ability to transform into a mug to fit through a small gap. These abilities are unlocked with Neuromods which are found through exploration and can be created with resources through the game's crafting system. There are enough interesting options to choose from that finding Neuromods always feels like a worthwhile reward, even towards the end of the game.

While the game has elements of survival horror, resources are fairly easy to come by if you explore thoroughly and the game's difficulty is not too high, at least after the very start of the game. Mimics, enemies that can disguise themselves as objects in the environment, are exciting and tense to deal with at the start, although they become more of a nuisance as the game progresses.

The biggest issue with the game lies towards the end of it. The enemy variety is severely lacking, with all enemy types appearing long before you have explored the whole station. This is not helped by the game's insistence of new enemies spawning in previously cleared areas, making backtracking somewhat arduous. By the time the game resorts to frequently having to go back through repopulated old areas in its final act, my interest was beginning to wane and I found myself simply sprinting past everything rather than engaging with it. It's not a major flaw, but it is a shame that the game fails to keep up the exceptionally high level of quality it begins with for the entire story.

148162024.review:
Prey (2017) is good; very *very* good.

I remember also liking the newest Deus Ex games for their clever level designs, where there is always going to be more than one way to skin a cat (for example: getting into a specific room or ambushing an enemy in your favor).

This game has all of that, except dialed up to eleven! The weapons, the human and alien skills, and more importantly the tools that you get early on, allow you to exploit the vertical heights of interior rooms in the game, and rewards intuitive thinking for how to solve a problem with the tools you have. Keycards, versus hacking, versus brute strength, for example. There is almost always another way.

The way they have utilized level design in this game alone deserves a thumb up, but there are also other things I want to praise.

i like the consequential nature of the game, and how you as the main character can choose whether to be empathetic and kind or an absolute menace to other characters you meet in the game. Named characters aren't just immortal for story consistency sake, so you get to carve your effect on it as you want.

The environments have a very interesting look to them which remind me of Bioshock in a way. The game is pretty, and each area is memorable in a different way, barring maybe a couple of zones that don't get used as much in the main story.

The alien enemy designs are fluidly animated and spectacular, and at the start of the game you are off feeling vulnerable and curious of what enemies do. After "researching" and repeated encounters you also promptly get more confident over time, which admittedly can pivot to the game becoming too easy.

Even so, this is why the early hours of the game are precious because they makes you plan your encounters and think about how to approach them cleanly and efficiently. This is where I have to give stealth some credit, even if it becomes a bit outrageous with skill points.

It's not a horror game per-say, but the immersive experience contributed a lot to me going into a pitch black room and feeling eerie. That's another thing I think should be whole-y embraced early on when you feel weaker in the game.

Regarding performance, I ran into a couple of crashing issues of various kinds when running the game at the highest graphics settings. Setting it from "Very High" to "High" however was a lot more stable, and I did not run into any other crashes after that until my first play-through was finished.

I can't comment on the DLCs as of yet, though I've heard the feedback is mixed given the focus on a time limit. This game I don't think has that problem very much, which is at least nice.

Overall through, the base game of Prey (2017) I can absolutely recommend buying, even in 2023.
I can't wait to retry this game on the Steam Deck as well, which I've heard is also a great experience plugged in.

148132456.review:
Prey is an exceptional game!

It is [b]not a straightforward shooter or pure action game with a story told fully through cutscenes[/b], though! If you want that, look elsewhere, Prey is not it.

Prey is about exploration and creative problem solving with a varied tool set.
There are a lot of well planned out interactions between enemies, weapons (shoot glue at a flying enemy, it falls down, takes damage from the fall), electronics and so on. You might not be used to that from other games, because there are few like it, even within the category of immersive sims, so it could take a while to get used to that. But once you do get into it, it's really great!

Also, I feel like I need to talk about Mooncrash here.
The Mooncrash DLC is awesome and amplifies a lot of the exploration and creative problem solving aspects that are so great about the main game. But Mooncrash does an awful job of explaining how it works and how it is meant to be played. The problem is, that it has a complicated structure with roguelike elements and is fully aware of this complexity. So to not overwhelm players, it barely explains anything in the beginning, which makes the game feel relatively pointless in the first few missions/runs (I was disappointed and uninstalled it on my first try). Do stick around and read the explanations after you escape from the base a couple of times. Don't get annoyed by the time limit stuff, it's actually a sensible game design choice here, even if I usually hate time limits. You can counter act the timer fairly well by killing big enemies and collecting loot but it does give you some urgency to get stuff done and lessens the incentives to play the game in an overly cautious and boring way. If you stick around, you'll be rewarded with really satisfying gameplay where you coordinate and plan out your runs with your characters to take advantage of their strengths and weaknesses.

The other DLCs are not worth buying. You'll probably get them anyway in some bundle. Just don't bother installing them.

148044436.review:
Prey is a... action-adventure-survival RPG like game?  I'm not sure how to classify it, but its reminiscent of bioshock/systemshock and Deus Ex but with a lot of freedom.  You fight abroad the Talos I, a space station with shape shifting and psionic aliens called Typhon on board that are wreaking havoc.  During your stay, you have access to special powers called neuromods that give you an edge and help augment your abilities.  You can choose to help with objectives around the station and use technology, stealth, or anything in between to get it done.  

Overall, I give it a 5/5!  It is Arkane Studios' best.  I would say that I was expecting something a little more survival-horror oriented, but once you get full control of the reins you don't feel so helpless and the game starts ramping up.  I liked the absolute freedom and how you never "leveled up" based on getting points for objectives or if you used stealth or did a pacifist run (I'm looking at you Mankind Divided). This game did not get boggled down by too much crafting or too many side quests, the side quests were not necessary other than to get some extra ammo or neuromod, and the crafting came down to making something out of the existing sandbox rather than customizing a weapon. I liked how every advantage was had by what stash you found while exploring or items you got as a reward and what augments you chose.  It was also great how there were no godlike powers or weapons in this game (again, looking you at Mankind divided), but that being said there were some fun ways to defeat your enemies and weapons that you don't find in other games!  My only complaint is the hacking mini-game, it lost its luster when you were hacking 10 robots around you when it took a chunk of a minute for each robot.

147830299.review:
nos lleva a un futuro distópico donde la humanidad se encuentra en una situación desesperada, enfrentándose a una invasión alienígena en la estación espacial Talos I. Aunque este juego ha sido calificado con un 6/10, ofrece una experiencia única que mezcla elementos de ciencia ficción, horror y exploración. Aquí tienes una revisión detallada del juego:

Ambiente e Inmersión (8/10):
La estación espacial Talos I es un entorno meticulosamente detallado y bien diseñado. Desde las áreas de investigación hasta los rincones más oscuros y secretos, el juego logra sumergir al jugador en un mundo oscuro y misterioso. La atención al detalle y la atmósfera son puntos destacados, lo que contribuye significativamente a la inmersión del jugador.

Jugabilidad y Libertad (7/10):
Prey ofrece una amplia variedad de habilidades y enfoques para resolver problemas, desde el uso de poderes alienígenas hasta la modificación genética. Sin embargo, algunas mecánicas de juego pueden sentirse desequilibradas y frustrantes en ciertos momentos, lo que puede afectar la experiencia general. La libertad para explorar la estación espacial y decidir cómo enfrentar las situaciones es un punto fuerte, aunque las ejecuciones podrían haber sido más pulidas.

Narrativa y Personajes (6/10):
La historia de Prey comienza intrigante, pero se convierte en un enigma complejo y a menudo confuso a medida que avanza. Los personajes tienen profundidad, pero a veces sus interacciones se sienten forzadas o poco naturales. La trama tiene giros impactantes, pero a veces la ejecución puede dejar a los jugadores sintiéndose desconectados.

Rejugabilidad (8/10):
La rejugabilidad es un punto fuerte en Prey. La variedad de enfoques y decisiones que puedes tomar tiene un impacto significativo en la experiencia del juego y en el final. Además, hay numerosos secretos y rutas alternativas que animan a los jugadores a volver y descubrir todo lo que Talos I tiene para ofrecer.

Conclusión:
Prey es un juego ambicioso con una gran cantidad de ideas innovadoras. Aunque no todas estas ideas están completamente pulidas y la narrativa puede volverse confusa, el juego ofrece una experiencia única para aquellos que disfrutan de la exploración y la experimentación. La libertad que brinda para abordar desafíos y el mundo detallado en el que se desarrolla hacen que valga la pena explorar Talos I.

Calificación: 6/10

Amazing, the ending credit roll gives me chills. 
    If you played dead space and hated following the road the game tells you to go, absolutely don't miss out on this one. It's got such a vertical, interconnected map in which you get your bearings over time so that you feel like you are thinking and actually playing the game. this enables you to find things the game didn't tell you where it is, which just feels good. 
    beating an enemy is like solving a puzzle, you gradually understand its mechanics and learns to tackle it effectively. with the genius idea of GLOO gun and wrench, combat feels tense and involved instead of you just shooting from afar. 
    but still, there are a lot of things that is weird or has room for improvement, for example, when military operators broke into my office, mikhaila ran into lobby. the next time I came back to lobby, she was nowhere to be found. I tried to track her with security station, it immediately says I failed to find her so I thought she died, but no corpse, weird. what is weirder is that in the ending she still sent me messages. what? there were also weird bugs where every time I switch back to the game and press shift, steam overlay pops up and the pointer is still on screen after closing the menu. also the ending is a bit abrupt, I spent all my resources on ammo and neuromods, expecting a final boss fight that never came. though this might be a good thing, since I am generally not a fan of final boss fight because it usually gets too nerve-racking or frustrating.
    but despite the problems, I still like this game quite a lot, since for me, whether I can enjoy or finish a game depends not on what it gets wrong, but what it gets right.

147722167.review:
Prey is an Immersive Sim which fell prey to Arkane Studios decade-old formula. Initially there's a lot to unpack, everything is moveable and the Typhon Aliens are intimidating yet this all falls through once you obtain equipment and progress. Despite Prey having an average length of ~16 hours it feels as though it SHOULD have been much shorter to reduce the overall bloat as the enemy-types are lacking alongside an equally small amount of ways to approach them. Free shout-out to the Opening. Most interesting way I've seen credits performed.


Gameplay:
The amount of Typhon enemies are surprisingly few. I won't discuss the alternatives and instead put these in parentheses around the enemy type: Mimic (4), Phantom (3), Nightmare, Poltergeists, Telepath/Technopath, and Cystoids. If that seems like a lot, the Cystoids simply detonate when close to the Player, which is more of a trap. The Nightmare is more of a scripted 'event' type, and the Poltergeists and Weavers are rather rare. I only saw around 4 Poltergeists in my playthrough.

I won't speak much to the Typhon mods but in general those are somewhat lacking (Psychic, Fire, Lightning, Lift, Summons). The main weapons are of two camps, Lethal and Non-Lethal. Non-Lethal are the GLOO Gun and Disruptor. The Lethal are the Pistol, Shotgun, and Beam Emitter. There are Sentries you can use- you can hack to make them friendly if you have Typhon Mods installed or if you have no Typhon Mods they stay friendly. However Sentries are generally useless as it's hard to stage them against enemies (as you need to set them up and in a good location), they always get blasted sideways or backwards preventing them from shooting, and when you return to them from other areas the game will blow up all of your Sentries. Just because. And that's why we recycle Sentries in this household.

A major issue is that once you obtain a decent amount of NeuroMods/Upgrades there's no longer a need to ever engage the Typhon in combat. The Fabricator allows Players to craft more rewards than necessary which speeds this process along, especially with the handy Recycling Grenades that turn objects into Materials. This led to me sprinting past nearly every Typhon except those required, which made combat feel more of a chore than something with potential rewards. 

Combat is lacking as the Devs focused on allowing a no-NeuroMod playthrough as an optional choice. This results in Players dealing less damage, having less options and upgrades, having less loot as you cannot access more areas, and so on and so forth. Instead of balancing the game around the upgrades Arkane yet again said 'No you don't WANT that'. Which results in any upgrades feeling cheap as there was no balance centered around them.

The exploration in the game is fantastic, and I enjoyed how interconnected everything was. I liked being able to eject out of one airlock and zooooooom my way to the other side of the station. It's actually crazy cool. So Combat kinda blows but exploring can be fun- especially because I crawl over every cranny looking for scraps. There are TONS of details to this game and tons of logs to read through, programming such fine detail must've been an ordeal. I can give that level of detail nothing but praise with the Achilles heel being the combat.


Inventory:
The game tries to do the grid-based inventory similar to Resident Evil but utterly fails. There's too much trash to pick up which requires much larger inventories and there's no storage which means Players will be hefting around every single Weapon anyways. Combine that with grenades, ammo, and healing- it's just far too much clutter to even be trying to say there needs to be inventory management. I love games that DO actual inventory management but this was half-heartedly done and just gets to be an annoyance rather than a part of the game system. 


[spoiler] 
Story Progression:
The game is a whole lot of go here BUT WAIT, go here first and then come back! It first happens when you hit Morgan Yu's Office. Play the video, it gets interrupted, go into hardware and recover the video to return to the office to finish viewing. So we head to Deep Inventory BUT WAIT, go to Crew Quarters and then you can return to Deep Inventory. Okay we go through that and then go back to the Arboretum to speak with Alex BUT WAIT, you need to scan the Typhon. Okay we do that and return to the Arboretum BUT WAIT, Dahl is trying to supermurder everyone okay we go deal with that and head back to the Arboretum BUT WAIT, the Typhon Alpha appeared and now we need to scramble to do either the EMP or Self-Destruct sequence... THAT WE WERE ALREADY GOING TO DO WITHOUT IT APPEARING. 

The main issue here is that too much stuff is set up right at the start. You immediately are told about doing the Self-Destruct sequence so when you get to the Arboretum it's like the game is nearly finished because Morgan's Arming Key is half the process. The game keeps dangling keys trying to delay the Player. It could have been written to be more engaging rather than show all of it's cards at the start and TRY to figure out ways for why it doesn't all just come together. Alex could've shown you the Arboretum video the second you hit Morgan's Office. That changes a lot considering you spend the first half of the game getting your Arming Key only for Alex to show this video to convince you otherwise. Alex is acting far more weird than Morgan the entire time. There was a point I thought that Alex was dead because I'd never seen him in person and it was someone else using me through his voice. Guess that would've been too clever.


The Ending:
The entire time the game was a simulation of what Morgan Yu COULD HAVE experienced during the Typhon Outbreak which means any of the choices you make have no impact as it has already happened. Earth was infected by the Typhon no matter what you chose. Now this isn't to say that everything was pointless- as the point is to influence you as the Player to become a Typhon who is capable of emoting with Humans. The Ending choice of Kill or Save can ONLY be chosen if the Player acted with empathy. The Kill choice is giving in to the Typhon Nature which seems to be what the Devs were aiming at but fails because of the way it's presented.

The reasoning is that it removes Player agency which causes MOST players to behave in a positive way. I do not believe Players that go out of their way to be Empathetic would then turn around and act like a Typhon but similarly Players who are 'evil' get turned away entirely with the 'restart' ending. And how do you fix it while keeping the intent intact? You simply repeat the Lab Simulations again. It's here you can break the window and attack your captors or choose to obey. Because of this format I believe players would choose to attack and fulfill the purpose of a Typhon simply mimicking empathy without comprehension. [/spoiler]

147551391.review:
[h3] If the "Immersive Sim" genre means anything to you, this is a must play. [/h3]
Preys gameplay is very open-ended with tons of options for creativity, the storytelling is great and the soundtrack by Mick Gordon will stick with you. But the main thing that elevates Prey is how [b] cohesive [/b] the entire experience feels. Arkane said they wanted to make one giant Dishonored level, another title of theirs with very open-ended gameplay but a linear set of missions to do in order. Prey takes place entirely on the massive Talos I space station and every hallway, crew quarter and maintenance tunnel is available to you. Even spacewalking across the [b] entire station [/b] is a great option for getting from one side to the other quickly. You'll need to open doors, fix elevators and clear debris to access the entire station, but how and when you do those things is given a surprising amount of freedom. You will get familiar with the enemies you face, the weapons and tools at your disposal, what upgrades you choose and how they help you, and the Talos I space station itself, and all of it connects beautifully. 

When I finished Prey I [i] immediately [/i] started a new run because I wanted to try using different upgrades on my character and make different decisions in the story, and I've been returning to it periodically ever since. And every time I do, I learn something new. Like I'll find out an enemy I struggled with has a crippling weakness to something I never tried on them, or a locked closet had a solution to get in that I never found because I just used my hacking skill last time. The best example is a nerf-gun the game gives you, just a straight up nerf gun that deals 0 damage. I didn't use it at all my first playthrough, but every subsequent playthrough I have used that nerf gun to do things I never even thought of the first time around! 

There's too much to say about Prey, so I'll leave it with this. If you like Dishonored, or Deus Ex, or System Shock, or Bioshock, or Vampire the Masquerade: Bloodlines, you've got great taste in games and you'll probably love Prey.

The Mooncrash DLC is very different, but fun. Sort of a Prey-Deathloop mix.

147032464.review:
If you enjoyed bioshock or dishonored you'll like this one. When you start out you'll be slowly hitting every inanimate object you come across to check if its a mimic waiting to kill you. By the end you'll be bunny jumping across rooms destroying anyone and anything that DARES gets in your way. If you spec too many ability points into alien majek the human friendly defense turrets will start targeting you unless you crafted it or hacked it yourself. 

Ending twist blew my mind tbh. Its one thing to read about it online but to actually experience it, its just not the same. You won't be able to grab every ability upgrade in your first play through and exploring everything is rewarding because thats how you get new and upgraded abilities. I kinda like this system it feels both restrictive and liberating at the same time. I think the reason this game didn't do as well as it hoped was because people gave up half way through because it was annoying to be constantly paranoid of every single object potentially being a mimic. And this paranoia doesn't really go away until later in the game when you've explored all the maps. The mimics eventually become a mild inconvenience but then its role is taken up by some new freaky alien ready to kill with harry potter majek. 

And this annoying fear and paranoia only continues when you meet more nasty aliens. Imagine walking past someone's office desk and you have to wonder if any books, staplers, trash cans, coffee mugs, pencils, anything is actually an enemy just waiting for you to let your guard down to jump you. But you get access to ways to detect them midway through the game. One tip mimics can only replicate items in their very immediate vicinity. So if you see a lunch table with an unusual amount of chairs pulled up to it, one of them could be a mimic or maybe a group of friends decided to pull up chairs for a conversation huddle before everything went to shit. Who knows better safe than sorry smack the chairs and hope you don't run into one while u run out of stamina. There are so many locked doors with key cards, sticky notes and audio logs with codes left on dead people, hidden under a book on a near by table, but I spend an abnormal amount of time using the toy cross bow to ricochet the harmless foam projectile trying to perfectly hit the manual open button on the side of the door that I couldn't get access to. Or you could spec into alien skills and turn into a clipboard small enough to fit through the broken window you just smashed with your wrench. Up to you but if you try to spec into everything melee, tech, stealth, aliens, etc. you won't have enough skill points to grab everything especially if you aren't doing every side objective. Because to upgrade skills in this game you find them in secrets, private safes, on the floor, crafted etc. but you will never have enough resources to do everything in a single play through. 

You can fly around in space or zones with broken zero gravity this is when you are the most vulnerable, slowest and the objective way points get fucked up the most. All of us are used to having two Axis of movement (1) front back, (2) up down but in space you have a 3rd Axis of rotation (3) clockwise counter clockwise. Its confusing and the mini map is the least useful because trying to program a way point system for this would have been incredibly difficult and time consuming (time affects cost of production because of employee salaries). As an employer skipping the implementation, costs less money for me and as a programmer it is less complicated work for me. So skipping that is just a win win for everyone except players trying to navigate themselves which isn't impossible but difficult to get used to. Speaking of programming I need to get started on my python assignment. I have no idea what I'm doing and all the syntax resources are from different places because of how broad python is. Welp fuck me.  

This is one of those games where completing it to the end is actually a sort of commendation similar to completing dark souls 3. Proving your resilience and tenacity as a gamer without it feeling like complete horse shit. Dark souls 1 and 2 had a fair amount of horse shit that just felt unfair. Dark souls 3 and this game it feels reasonable and problems can be solved creatively using the tools you spec'd into. But given the nature of this game and the twist at the end I can see why they canceled the sequel it just wouldn't feel right and the game dynamics wouldn't feel the same given the twist at the end. 

tldr; 
Semi spooky scary game with constant tension, resource management and creative freedom to solve problems based on what abilities and available resources you have on you. Going through the game can be rough as this tension and fear is fairly constant throughout the entire play through up until the end when you know the maps like the back of your hand. 


To get the max experience from your first play though I recommend specing into alien majek. The consequences are daunting but this is how the devs envisioned players playing the game even if players can choose not to. Like 2 or 3 rooms out of the hundreds can't be accessed at all without the alien morph ability that mimics have. These are inconsequential but annoying if you don't have the skill. As thorough as I like to be (100% map completion in an Assassins Creed or far cry game) there are still a few nooks and crannies I didn't bother with. And tiny of them I couldn't do at all because of gameplay and playthrough choices.

146905396.review:
I never really much enjoyed Bioshock.  Just thought it was paced a bit slow and while the premise and the intro was extremely cool, the spectacle of that wears off fast and you're just left with not much gameplay.

Prey feels like someone decided they wanted to mod Bioshock to make it fun for me personally.  I found the plot a little more compelling, the gameplay a little more interesting, the resource management a little more interesting, there's good crafting elements, the skill upgrades feel better done, the exploring feels more interesting, and you can actually go outside the space station and do things and find things.

That being said the game does feel just a little bit meh after long enough and the ending is weak, a complaint I've heard from multiple people.  The game very intentionally is set up so that you always feel outmatched, hence the name 'Prey', but I do feel like after awhile having no sense of progress or victory just wears on you.  You're very often gaining some new ability right about one step behind when it would have been useful.  You might have some really intense fight trying to take out a tough boss in a room, setting up all kinds of clever traps and ploys and along with some good luck you kill it, only to go out of the airlock to grab something and you come back in and now there are two.  I understand the feeling they are trying to evoke, but it's just a bit too often that the only viable strategy is pretty boring or even cheesy.  Even if you're trying to create a sense of being overwhelmed, you gotta give me a little space to occasionally feel a victory.  If I wanted to feel like I was in a no win situation where I'm just running in a hamster wheel and getting nowhere I'd just spend more time at work.

146899299.review:
This game never shuts the fuck up. Ever. You can't walk ten feet without a call coming in that you basically have to stop and listen to. And then that is usually followed up by another exposition dump of a call. Every person on this station must be a fucking seasoned author the overly flowery way they talk. It's fine at first, but by the end you just want people to shut the fuck up and stop giving you pointless side missions. It doesn't help that most of the main story missions also feel like nonsense busy work. 

Do you like side quests in games? Hey, me too, dude. But the side quests in this game have you running all over the entire GIANT map to press 'F' and loot a body or chest. None of the things you will find feel like it was worth your time to search an entire warehouse full of shit for one hidden corpse with a crafting recipe for foam darts. Yes. There's no real reward other than making the quest markers go away. 

Near end game and I have no ammo, materials to create ammo, or desire to continue. And it just so happens that they have been absolutely HAMMERING me with enemies that take little to no damage from my almost fully upgraded skills and weapons. This isn't Cyberpunk, or Skyrim or anything like that. You're not a god by end game. Point blank I've pumped an entire ten rounds from a shotgun at end game enemies and they barely flinch. 

TL;DR: Save yourself time and unnecessary frustration and just play Dishonored.

146582328.review:
PREY (2017) – not to be confused with the 2006 game of the same title – is a very original video game that breaks from the usual boundaries of the first-person shooter genre. This gem of a game serendipitously came into my hands quite late, but held me captivated once I got into the flow of the game itself.

While the story is interesting to follow, and its conclusion is nothing exceptional, what truly sets this game apart is its unique gameplay mechanics – especially the superpowers, which are amazingly impressive when used creatively to fight the alien foes. These power mechanics offer diverse and creative ways to achieve certain objectives which really makes for a more immersive gaming experience, and which in my view, is unparalleled within this FPS action genre.

Additionally, the way the Steam achievement system works with this game really added to the game's appeal too, as it motivated me to replay the game three times (consecutively) in order to unlock every achievement. In total, I spent 64 hours on this experience. In summary, my journey through Prey was very enjoyable. Nevertheless, it showcases gaming originality and earns a place among the greats in my view.

146569630.review:
This recommendation comes with caveats.  It's a fascinating game with an intriguing narrative and unique environmental storytelling.  But I never understood the combat and I had to rely on stealth, save scumming, and running for my life during the final act.  It was punishing and frustrating, and I was relieved when the game was finally over.  I've heard that Prey's combat is somewhat atypical for its genre so I strongly recommend learning about its combat mechanics if you want to explore Talos-1 with more confidence than I did.

In spite of all that, Talos-1 is far more interesting than Rapture, but I was never really a Bioshock fan.

146537995.review:
It's so sad that this game suffered from the "Immersive Sim Curse" (publisher interference, lack of support and low sales, despite critical acclaim), because it's an excellent game. There is everything fans of the genre could expect of, all done with high production standards. Talos I isn't as dreadful and desolated as Citadel Station or the Von Braun, but good part of this is because it really looks and feels like a real place, where people live and work, and all the stuff is happening while you play (in short, it's not supposed to be a derelict station).

There is a lot to discover, and my second playthough was way longer than the first one, when I followed the main story more straighforwardly. And all of that without even installing a single typhon neuromod, which I'm saving for a third run. The game's difficulty is on the low side overall, so if you are a System Shock 2 veteran you may go for Nightmare difficulty in your first playthrough without problem (and with all survival settings on, for sure). Enemies will be really tough and dangerous, but you'll end up swimming in resources in short time. There are mods that "survival up" the game, although I still didn't try them.

I just modded one gameplay thing because it was more annoying than challenging, and that was [spoiler] the Nightmare appearances. They boiled down to simply running, hunkering down under a table and staring at the screen for three minutes until the timer went off. The game's AI should be much better than it is to really give you a feeling of being hunted, so I just removed it completely. [/spoiler]


The graphics are good in general, but anti-aliasing is abysmal, to the point of actually harming the experience. I highly recommend to download a graphics improvement mod to get rid of that. "Real Lights plus Ultra Graphics" available in Nexusmods solve the issue and give you many other improvements. I had a few glitches in Talos Exterior and FPS drops in Arboretum that may be related to it, but they were minor things compared to the huge improvement. If you want something lighter, take a look at the "Engineer - Reshade".

146522809.review: Amazing and immersive game. Very well designed levels that offer lots of choice how to approach anything. Worth multiple playthroughs to experience completely different playstyles.

146511085.review:
SPOILERS AHEAD!

This game released at about 2017 and didn't have much publicity when it came out, and I had bought it on my PS4 (never finishing it) about a year or so after, bought the moon DLC for it and everything. However, seeing it on sale, I came back to it again recently on steam. Unlike my much younger self, I would say I have a far greater appreciation for certain atmospheres of games, especially in the Sci-Fi setting, and I am enthralled by this game setting, and I am very close to finishing the game.

I'd like to say that the atmosphere of this game is incredible, the start of the game starts mysterious, and the more you explore this empty station you get more and more questions. The names of crew members can be hard to follow at times and the plot, but if you stay focused it really follows up on itself. You become ingrained in the plot the more you explore, wondering what happened to everyone and what WILL happen the more you explore. If you play on HARD (my personal recommendation) you really have to choose between sneaking at first or killing everything, sometimes not having a choice. Every room feels unique, the atmosphere constantly Regal yet Scientifically focused. This game's design is unlike every other, recently Starfield has been able to come close but the NASA-esqueness it has just doesn't fill the same hole. The sheer amount of science it has dumped into it and the "lore" is incredible (even history with the USSR and US is fun too).

The combat for the game is thrilling because at any random moment I could have just exploded and get jump scared by an enemy (such as the Nightmare, such a unique experience). The aesthetic is everywhere from the music (lovely) to the environmental design (perfection), to even just the weapons (simple but enjoyable).

One of the little things I do in the game is just walk around, exploring the wonderful areas it has, even admiring the way it changes the further you go along with the Coral spreading everywhere and the Typhon themselves are such a unique enemy, especially playing what is essentially Prop Hunt with the mimics. The frustration / fear that I would get at seeing certain enemies and playing peek-a-boo or destroying them. There is no part of this game (other than the faces of crew mates) that wasn't lovingly detailed and has REAL work put into it.

The inclusion of the lesbian relationship was quite nice because there was work put into it that made it part of the story, even going so far as to help murder the man who killed the one girlfriend. I feel a major part of why people dislike modern gaming is the inclusion of LGBT at every given opportunity but it is put into Prey so casually it felt fitting, like sure why wouldn't there be some lesbians there when they are dedicated scientists trying to help better things with lore and backstory and everything.

I love this game, I have very little negative to say in anything about it. It may get annoying at times, but never BAD. I will put more upon this review once I finish, but I doubt my opinion will change much.

146293240.review:
This is really my first Arkane game that I'm playing, but I can already tell what it's about, and where these guys' focus is.

It's all about the pride of being human.

Use your wits; we've all got them.

It's all about letting the player do things exactly the way they want, and telling them that there's no wrong way to play.

That's very realistic, because that's the way that our world is.

There's no wrong, or abnormal, things just are, and they're the way they're supposed to be.

Things happen, because they have to.

It's about fate.

Just be you. 
You don't have to do anything in particular to be you, you just are.

Enjoy yourself, and the way in which you get yourself out of a sticky situation.

What a cool way to craft a game.

These guys are such artists, it's awesome.

Love it <3

And other than all that, here's some other stuff that I immediately fell in love with:

The fact that they used CryEngine.

I love that typical CryEngine look that the cubemaps have, and the SSR and shadows too.
You can tell that the engine gave them loads of controls over the lighting, and it looks so good for it.

And the way in which they showed off that simulation room; how do you even render that? Ha ha.

And the sound.; my god, the sound.

It's so reminiscent of the way old games used to sound, like System Shock! What do you know, ha ha.

But seriously, I love the way in which the sounds have a very loopy signature to them.

Games before used to have short, looping sounds because they just couldn't handle big sounds yet.
That's Midi for ya.

But here, they use it as a throwback to System Shock and the like.


Well, I could obviously keep on listing all the stuff I liked, but point is, these guys obviously loved what they were making; it's really felt.

It really respects the player so much, and I love to see that.

Just beautiful.

Defacto swan song to the immersive sim genre. They don't make 'em like this anymore. Yes, there are some newer titles, both inside and out the indie scene that could fit, but this is pretty much the high water mark. Its my favorite style of game and its pretty much dead in the AAA space. That's why I put off playing it til now. 
Good story, technically sound, fun and intelligent gameplay. Recommended at full price. 146284797.review:
La gente tiende a compararlo con los juegos más antiguos de Bioshock (1 y 2), y no están del todo equivocados, pero eso es lo que parece en la superficie.
¿Llave inglesa? Control
¿Múltiples superpoderes que se encuentran a lo largo del juego? Control
¿Armas que se pueden mejorar para profundizar tu estilo de juego? Controlar
¿Un mundo de juego que alguna vez estuvo lleno de vida y ahora está prácticamente desierto? Control
¿Estética de terror general y miedo a lo desconocido en un espacio claustrofóbico? Control

Si lo miras así, bien podría ser un sucesor espiritual de Bioshock, sin embargo, Arkane fue más allá con este.


Arkane, que ya ha demostrado durante mucho tiempo su destreza en el diseño de niveles no lineales con Dishonored 1&2, se ha superado a sí mismo con Prey.
¿Ves esa estación de seguridad? Hay estos jugosos Neuromods (puntos de habilidad) adentro, pero no tienes el código correcto.
Bueno, aquí es donde realmente brilla Arkane Studios.
Para enumerar algunas de las posibilidades para ingresar a la estación:
- averigue quién trabajó en esta estación, rastreelos usando otra computadora, encuéntrelos (o más probablemente, su cadáver), obtenga el código clave.
- Hackea la consola para forzar la apertura de la puerta.
- Usa la "Pistola Gloo" (esto es una locura, el mejor dispositivo que he visto en mis años jugando videojuegos) para construir una escalera hasta la estación de seguridad y entrar por el respiradero.
- ¿Ves este pequeño hueco en la ventana (a prueba de balas)? Pon una taza, una manzana o algo pequeño al lado, conviértete en esa manzana (porque Mimicry) y rueda como si fueras dueño del lugar, luego vuelve a transformarte.
- La consola de seguridad se puede ver desde el hueco de la ventana, ¿verdad? También puedes disparar a los botones con tu confiable *Huntress Boltcaster*™, que tiene dardos de espuma para desactivar el bloqueo de seguridad.

Consigue esos Neuromods, inviértelos en una habilidad de pirateo superior, así la próxima vez que te encuentres con una puerta como esta, tendrás una habilidad más en tu repertorio.


Verás, en la superficie es Bioshock, pero en el fondo es mucho más profundo en casi todos los aspectos.


La mejor parte es que nunca estás realmente restringido.
El Talos-1, la enorme nave espacial de investigación en la que se desarrolla este juego, está construido como un metroidvania en muchos aspectos, lo cual me encanta.
A veces encuentras un nuevo dispositivo, recibes un nuevo superpoder, desbloqueas una nueva habilidad y dices: ¿Puedo ingresar ahora al lugar X?
Así que regresa y podrás. Y encuentras nuevos ♥♥♥♥, encuentras nuevos registros, que te dirigen hacia una nueva dirección en tu búsqueda autoconcedida para comprender finalmente qué sucedió exactamente en el Talos-1.

El combate en este juego adopta un enfoque similar al de la estación de seguridad descrita anteriormente.
¿Ves estas imitaciones? Bueno, todavía no te conocen, no se han transformado. Si los activas, te atacarán y sufrirás daño, así que juguemos de forma inteligente.
- ¿dispara con tu arma hasta que exploten?
- ¿Tirar un objeto al lado de un gasoducto, disparar el gas y verlos arder?
- ¿Gloo hasta que estén pegados en su lugar y luego tómate tu tiempo para arrojarles objetos aleatorios como microscopios, contenedores de basura y cualquier otra cosa que no esté clavada?
- ¿Escabullirse de ellos por completo? Parece que hay algunos respiraderos cerca, ¿me pregunto adónde conducen?
- ¿Recuerdas esa torreta automatizada que viste hace unos minutos? Me pregunto qué les hará cuando lo despliegues y simplemente abras la puerta.

Las posibilidades son infinitas y realmente espero que este juego algún día reciba los elogios que realmente merece.
Se siente como si Bethesda arrojara dinero y el nombre "Prey" a Arkane y dijera "vuélvete loco", y eso es lo que hicieron.


Realmente no quiero entrar en más detalles, pero debes saber que por el  precio de lo que vayas a pagar por esto, obtendrás el valor de tu dinero.

This sat in my "I'll play it one day" file for a couple of years and finally, with nothing much else to do I decided to give it a go...it popped up on Best Games in a couple of YT vids and that got me curious.
I've played the Dishonored games by Arkane and figured this should be worthy and I was so happy to have my suspicions confirmed, it's amazing.
Unlike many games that hold your hand and basically walk you through repetitive game play, Prey unfolds  slowly, deliberately and beautifully. I love how going in not knowing WTH is going on turned out to be part of the game itself, you really don't know what the hell is going on and you have to figure it out, leave no stone unturned!!!
One thing I would suggest is to look on YT for suggestions on the basic skills you want to take early, it'll make your game so much better, not knowing is cool, but it also leaves you baffled in a not so great way...I think I'll be doing a restart so I can correct a couple of things I got wrong, I've still got lots to play and best to restart sooner rather than later.
I highly recommend this game, I give it a hard 9/10

146076158.review:
Amazing game play, environments, weapons, alien powers, and story twists. After getting to my office, I got stuck progressing because I forgot to pick up a key card on my desk. Don't make my mistake. The game starts out linear, to teach you the basics, then opens up, massively. Give yourself time to explore and experiment. 
When I started, I threw myself at every enemy, but every challenge has creative solutions. Every enemy has weaknesses you can exploit. There is always something more terrifying around every corner. The game keeps your head just barely above water. Your weapons, skills, and powers gradually grow as the alien threat becomes more dangerous.
Pretty soon, everything just clicked. There are so many was to play this game and have fun. On my first play through, I tried to stay human and eliminate the alien scourge. I was a hacker gunslinger who could toss entire lockers at enemies. However, the first thing I did when I finished was start new game+ to try a totally different path.
