146017344.review:
I've played this game several times. The first time I played it, I got to the main lobby, looked at all the different exits and options and thought "this is System Shock. I'm not mentally in the right place. I need to come back to this so if it does turn out good, I can appreciate it better." I did that, putting it off for the rare reason of appreciation, instead of disgust. Normally when I quit a game to come back later, it's because I can tell from the Tutorial, Prologue and Intro of a game that I won't like it. I come back purely to finish it for the mental checklist.

I came back to play it in 2020. I enjoyed it a lot, with the game living up to the expectations I had. It continues the post-Bioshock tradition of simplified stats, but I enjoyed this so much more. It doesn't get trapped in the easy antagonism that Bioshock uses for all it's games. I found myself thinking of Star Trek while playing. Star Trek had villains, but it also had characters that were antagonists. These are characters who are opposed to our protagonists on a cultural or ideological level. They're not killing for fun and they're not attempting to gain domination over all they survey. Despite what the writers of Bioshock might think, people aren't evil based on an On/Off switch inside their brain. It's not a binary. It also uses the unreliable narrator trope, or a variant thereof, a lot better than Bioshock Infinite tried to do with their terrible ending. I would also argue it's a more subtle critique of capitalism, as opposed to Bioshock's pseudo-Libertarian world.

Themes and comparison's aside, the game looks good, runs well, plays well.
My usual pre-flight checks of raw mouse input and higher FOV went off without a hitch, no text editing required. I very rarely had the game drop below 60fps, with it generally running around 100fps. I experienced the most lag during two points. The first being the coral sections in general, but especially the G.U.T.S. and when multiple Military drones were active firing lasers at once. It was still above 60fps, but there would be small freezing sometimes. There was one crash I had for unknown reasons. I had just exited Psyotronics and when I attempted to load back in  the game froze and I had to end the process. Besides this, it ran fine.

Jump scares are normally something I despise in general. It's a surprise and you flinch, but you're not scared. It's a reflex. It's on the same emotional level as a fly in your face or a ball coming towards you. They're a tool to be used, but a bad creator will make it their only tool, for evidence see the Five Nights at Freddy's franchise or the Paranormal Activity horror movies. This game earns the moments where it surprises you, although I wouldn't call it a horror game. The mimic enemies fooled me several times even with the detection addons. There is one very notable jump-scare. [spoiler]There's a screen that requires calibration and when you press the final dot for calibration a phantom enemy appears on the screen and attacks you. Once you calm down and realise it was just a recording, a real phantom spawns somewhere out of your field of vision and attacks you. It didn't really affect me that much, not because I'm not a wimp, but because the moment the false phantom showed up I hit it with a wrench, breaking the screen. I then heard the phantom making noise, so I hid until it was visible. In researching this room and the onscreen video, I found out that most people had been scared by this and I can see why.[/spoiler] It's very effective at lowering your guard in a comfortable environment doing mundane things. It's essentially an in-game version of that Maze Game prank from 2005 or so. Beyond that I think that you have a good chance of working out what objects are mimics even without an add-on, so it's a fair fight for an observant player and the jump scares from a missed mimic are earned.

The sound design is great. A lot of games struggle with what to do with sound in space. They tend to either accept the rule of cool and give it noises or be simplistic and make it completely silent. Both are unrealistic, but the pedants get more angry at the first case because they hate fun and they read a children's fact book once that explained the concept of a vaccuum. Prey uses it as an opportunity. The outside is silent, but inside your suit you hear breathing, your fired weaponry creates vibrations, you hear escaping or jettisoned gases from your suit or thrusters. It changes the way you interpret a fight when you lose the advantage of hearing and it's fun. All the voice actors do great. Alex Yu's voice actor Benedict Wong gets a lot of dialogue and he does great, although sometimes I thought of Zoidberg from Futurama with some of his line deliveries. He's a fun casting choice too because he was in two great Sci-Fi films, 2007's Sunshine and 2009's Moon. He was also in Prometheus, which wasn't a good movie, but the mimics are influenced by the facehuggers a little, so there's a tenuous link. Morgan Yu's voice actors get stuck with the majority of the lines in game, either through recordings of themself or through January. This most recent playthrough I played as a Male Morgan Yu, however on my first two playthroughs I chose the Female Morgan Yu. I can't remember much about it, but I remember liking her work. She's voiced by Sumalee Montano and has apparently done a whole bunch of games. I can't comment on her specifically because of how long ago it was, but I wouldn't want to forget about her work. Tim Kang is the voice actor for the male Morgan and does great. The only thing I've heard him in was Mirror's Edge Catalyst as Dogen, a crime lord. He was fine from memory but I think that's all anyone could be with that game. Anyway, he was very believable as a character, regardless of whether he was portraying the original version of Morgan, [spoiler]Morgan after he gradually changes personality[/spoiler] and January. The rest of the cast were all good in their roles as well, I don't recall a line delivery I would call unrealistic for the situation.

[spoiler]One other voice actor related gag I wanted to note. In Psyotronics, a prisoner with a long rap sheet is asking to be released. You can release him, leave him trapped or kill him via Typhon. While the voice acting itself wasn't anything special, I have to note that the character is portrayed by Walton Goggins, who I think I've only ever see play villains before. If I had recognised him I probably would have thought twice before letting him out, but luckily my shotgun helped comfort me during my time of mistrust. For the record, the character ended up being true to his word.[/spoiler]

I think the story was logical. I never felt blind-sided or that things weren't explained to me. I had questions and I think they were all answered or kept ambiguous.

Prior to this game, there was another game released as Prey. I want to mention it because of the name mostly. This game is very appropriate for the title Prey. The original game seemed unrelated to the title. I was never a big fan of the original title in general, the only part that I found notable was for having the main character and a few others be Native American, specifically Cherokee, for not making said characters into horrible stereotypes or Turok ripoffs and for actually hiring Native Americans to voice those characters. A very respectful thing to do that some major film studios don't even bother with. I think the series should have continued, but the series should have been retitled. The original Prey hasn't been available on Steam for years and never available on other storefronts, so it's a moot point from a buyer's standpoint, but it annoys me when I want to talk about one or the other and have to clarify which one I'm talking about. Prey is a great title for a game, but was a lousy title for the 2006 game.

145869539.review:
I've had a love-hate relationship with this game since I first picked it up a few years ago. I've tried to play it multiple times, each time getting a little bit further but inevitably giving up on it and then restarting from the beginning the next time I picked it up.

Prey is... very unapproachable to most people, at first anyway. It's very, very overwhelming right from the get-go. The space station is massive, like absolutely huge. Even now with 49 hours of playtime, I still haven't seen every area in this game. What makes the game feel even bigger though is that it's PACKED with stuff. I'm talking items, audio logs, secret passageways, locked doors, secret side quests and more. I really can't express how much of a learning curve there is here, and if you decide to give this game a go I highly recommend trying to stick with it and keep in mind it's a very slow-paced game and gets better as it goes on.

When I say this game is slow-paced, I mean that there's an emphasis on avoiding combat if you can, especially in the early game. Bioshock this is not, your weapons do very little damage at first and the enemies you go up against do SO much damage to you so generally you are better off trying to get the drop on enemies or just outright avoiding them until you get your hands on better upgrades. You'll die in 3-4 hits from starter enemies and they move very rambunctiously, it's hard to get a grasp on when they attack because their telegraphs are hard to read. I found the difficulty to be pretty frustrating for the longest time, until I learned how to deal with enemies and build my character around it.

The reason I just wrote three paragraphs talking about how dang hard this game is to get into at first is because I want you to understand what you're getting into, and that it's worth it if you can get past that steep learning curve. After a while of playing I eventually hit a point where everything just... clicked. I understood what I was supposed to do, I managed my resources right and maximized recycling and explored every nook and cranny I could for neuro-mods and ammo. And this is when the game turns incredible. Like, modern masterpiece level of good.

The game suddenly turns from a frustrating chore into one of the best immersive sims I've ever played. With the annoyances out of the way I started to notice and appreciate the amount of detail and effort that's gone into this world and the different ways you can play and build your character.  It feels very 90's in the best way possible, like a modern version of System Shock 2 but with it's own twist. 

I don't think the game is perfect or anything, but the enjoyment I got out of this thing once I learned what it was trying to do was really surprising and tons of fun. It's a very technical and almost hardcore game but extremely rewarding if you can take the time to learn it and I definitely recommend Prey if you have the patience for it.

145807586.review:
The game is beautiful and the story is decent, it makes me want to play it. But from the beginning I got the feeling that i set the wrong difficulty level and after a while I got more and more frustrated and annoyed by the insolubility of so many problems and situations. Many times the only way to progress is by trying multiple times (with getting killed inbetween), which I find stupid and old-fashioned. It brings one to quick save every two minutes for which of course there is no hotkey so you need to interrupt the game flow every time. 

As with many games it is too much about collecting and looting and thinking about what skill to acquire next, only in this case collecting materials has the extra frustration of never being enough to really be able to acquire something useful. I guess it was meant that way, surviving with constant shortage of everything, but somehow in this game this aspect was only frustrating to me. Furthermore the games was advertised as shooter and the one thing you can never do in this game without considering every bullet is shoot.

I played and loved Dishonored 2, thats why I bought this game. I completed Dishonored 2 with 0 kills and never got that frustrated as with Prey.

Last but not least: the game is bugged, I got stuck inbetween objects and glitched several times, also a few crashes while loading a new level. The sound design is not good and also bugged, several times I got multiple speech files played simultaneously, even during cut scenes. Furthermore there are phenomena reminding of bad level design in very old games like getting spawned/positioned directly in front of an enemy. Considering the pressure produced by the imbalance of the games difficulty this produced unnecessary further frustrations.

Finally the two endings offered are both too simple and the extra plot twist was just superflous (maybe it matters somehow for a subsequent title, I don't know).

All in all I finished the game not knowing why and whishing for it to end for at least 80% of playtime.

145678588.review:
If you routinely go back and play games like System Shock 2, Dead Space, or Deus Ex at least every year or so, considering adding Prey to your line up. 

Excellent immersive sim. 
Loved the unique retro-futuristic aesthetic and the character design.
I really appreciated that Prey could be engaging, scary, and create a frightful atmosphere of dread, without leaning so heavily on shock and gore like some of it's contemporaries (not a judgement, just an observation).  
Lots of interesting and inventive game-play designs that showed a lot of creativity, along with being well balanced and fitting in well to the game.

Very streamlined and well paced gaming experience. Trimmed down a lot of the bloat that happens in games like this, inventory and character management was intuitive and rarely, if ever, slowed the game down. 

I will advise playing on a higher difficulty. I played on normal, and while it was definitely full tilt survival horror for the first half, by the end of the game I was starting to feel like a pest exterminator. Loaded to bear with enough resources and ammo to handle almost any issue that came my way with little trouble. Though I have played my share of Survival horror games. So newer players might want to try normal and see how it feels to them.

First play-through clocked in at 42 hours, was well paced, fun, and compelling, and I definitely see myself plaything through it again, trying out some different builds and story paths.

145664469.review:
(warning: gameplay spoilers, but not story spoilers)

Key points no one mentioned to me or else I'd have played it way sooner:
Distract enemies with nerf gun
Turn corpses into friendly AI that will fight with you against enemies
Turn yourself into a cup
If you don't like jump scares you get an option very early in the game to scan the rooms for mimics

Art Deco art style isn't something I enjoy either but in this game it grew on me over time.
Game ends up feeling more like Deus Ex than Alien Isolation. I like both games but just worth mentioning.
Would've liked a cover system instead of leaning left/right but otherwise this game is sick.
Co-op could've been nice too, but I understand that's a lot to ask for these days.

Highly recommend. 9/10.

145652483.review:
Si no quieres leer toda la reseña aquí un resumen rápido: Compralo!!!.

Antes de nada quiero dejar claro también que Prey para mi fue uno de esos juegos que se quedo en mi Biblioteca de juegos durante mucho tiempo sin apenas jugarse, ya que cada vez que lo empezaba me aburría, no fue hasta que un día armándome de paciencia decidí darle mas de 1h de juego.
Para mi sorpresa lo que me encontré fue un juego que si bien no me parece que destaque sobradamente en ninguno de sus aspectos, en su conjunto es un titulo realmente solido y divertido. Sin más me limitare a poner los pros y los contras.

PROS:
    -Un juego estable tanto a nivel argumental como a nivel de rendimiento, no decepciona en ninguno de 
    estos puntos.
    -Tus decisiones importan, hacer algo o no hacerlo tiene un impacto real en tu partida.
    -Un sistema de loteo y supervivencia muy básicos pero agradables no se siente pesado ni aburrido.
    -Un mundo interconectado que se inspira mucho en el estilo metroidvania, es decir, ir desbloqueando 
    nuevas zonas en este caso mediante hackeo, llaves de acceso, etc.

CONTRAS:
    -Muy poca variedad de armas, y algunas de las que hay como la escopeta, parecen sacadas de una feria.
    -Un gunpley al más puro estilo Bethesda, enemigos con barras de vida que se comportan como esponjas, 
    jugar a mas de dificultad media, se vuelve tedioso y aburrido matar a ciertos enemigos.
    -Muy poca variedad de enemigos.

En resumen, el juego en general se siente bien y por lo que vale hoy día merece mucho la pena, pero no puedes evitar pensar que paso sin pena ni gloría en su día y que de no haber sido así, una secuela podría haber dado mucho más de sí y crear lo que habría sido una saga de juegos de ciencia ficción increíbles pero que lastimosamente no pudo ser. No obstante quiero dejar claro el juego tiene un comienzo y varios finales que para nada defraudan ni te dejaran a medias esperando una secuela que nunca llegará.

145030500.review: Prey was the first immersive-sim game that I've ever played, and I think that classification checks out. Only in this game can you kill every single person on this station, using the most obtuse ways ranging from stealthy take-downs and well placed traps, to psychotic run-and-gun methods and propelling furniture at lethal velocities, only to then choose to LEAVE the station and have the person that you just killed break the 4th wall and pull the plug. I should clarify and say that this wasn't how my first play through went (this was my 2nd) and that the story is a genuine mindfuck start to finish. Despite it not having any connection whatsoever to the previous Prey game, it still remains as a captivating story that tests the empathetic nature of the player rather than the character you play as, with subtle hints along the story's path that things may not seem what they really seem to be (i.e. All in Le Head of Le Head???). I find the combat to be really fun and intense, trying to figure out what is a mimic and where other typhons are attacking from, or whether or not I'm going insane and smashing an assortment of fine china when there's no enemy in the room I'm in (shotgun is REALLY op). I think Arkane's take on New Game+ for this is neat, letting you keep neuromods, but I feel it makes things WAY too easy, even on Nightmare difficulties with weapon deterioration and health effects selected. So, I advise staying away from NG+ if you still want a challenging experience, but if you want to have it on for fast runs, go for it! It's a shame that this game didn't get as much traction back in 2017, this truly is an underrated gem, and I have yet to play the Mooncrash dlc. If you want to jump into the immersive-sim genre, I believe Prey (2017) is definitely a solid first pick for newcomers that want to get into immersive-sims.

145022062.review:
I'd give it a maybe if it was possible but I gave it a Yes as a No would have been unfair.
Long story short; game has an interesting story but gives too little of itself while dragging on and on. The story and the curiosity it created was enough for a Yes on my end, but I don't think you'd be missing all that much if you didn't play Prey.

Prey essentially tells a story that grabs your interest quickly, but it does so in quite a tedious way. Halfway through the game, the novelty of the enemies had vanished and I was disillusioned of the complexity of the tasks. It eventually becomes "go from point A to point B" and has close to no challenge. There are a lot of side quests that pile up on that same logic, making things even more tedious if you choose to do them. Halfway through the game pretty much every challenge had become trivial as enemies are overused turning mimics into something gimmicky and the bigger foes into a matter of how much ammo you have. This basically means the horror aspect of the game dies pretty quickly.

This could have been a more immersive and balanced out game if there were more stages to the story. As it is, you're playing the stretched out ending of the game from about the initial hour or 2 of the game.  You're also given a ton of tools and skills. It was fun to experiment with them but a majority of them became redundant very quickly.

I believe this game could have used another 15 hours or so of story. Within the overall journey of the hero, it'd help if we ever felt immersed into the ending conditions. In the end it couldn't cash out the curiosity that it had built and left me wondering if that really was all.

144909002.review:
This review is a little spoiler-ish, be warned. 

Prey is the best immersive sim in the whole world until it isn’t. 

It really plays like a dream: you have giant, interesting and interconnected space station and the hundred and one way to explore it. The story starts very intriguing, to put it mildly. I doubt many people can witness Prey’s mind-bending opening and not want to get to the bottom of the mystery. In terms of interesting situations, level design, player agency and all that jazz this game is so ahead of the competition that it’s not even funny. Enemy variety could use some work, I guess, but action is not the star of the show here so it’s forgivable. 

So, you explore the station top to bottom, finish all the loose ends there and you are ready for it to be over. Game overstays its welcome a little by this point, but nothing too outrageous. It’s all well and good. 

And then game slaps you with overtime. 

And oh boy is this most boring, tedious and unnecessary overtime ever. There is nothing new to explore, there is no one interesting to meet, and you just do a lot of «go there, slap the button» busy work all over the station while fighting generic flying pew-pew robots. It’s absolutely mind-numbing stuff. 

And then Prey ends. 

It has the twist ending and it’s insulting. This kind of ending was old and tired ages ago, it invalidates every player decision up to this point, and it even fails at being unexpected. Seriously, they outright spoiled it to every imsim player worth their salt in the middle of the game. There is DO NOT GO THERE moment around midpoint and of course everyone will save the game and freaking go there. It’s imsim, it’s in DNA of the genre. Everyone will go there and everyone will be slapped with the biggest spoiler in the game way too early. Who does that? Screw it, if you for whatever reasons want to experience the ending as it should be – DO NOT try to escape the station early. 

This game has problems. The core of it is still way too amazing to give it the negative review, but it could’ve been solid 10/10 experience if devs practiced some restraint. Story of my life.

8/10

144641524.review:
Games like Prey make me wish Steam had a "mixed" review option. There's a lot to like, but there's enough bad to make me want to stop playing. And that's a shame, because it's clear the developers sincerely care about this genre.

First, the good. The visual design and atmosphere is unparalleled. It really does feel like you're floating adrift a dying space station. If you're an immersive sim purist who loves scouring every inch of the map for notes, keycards, codes, and random tidbits, then this game will likely satisfy your itch. A lot of effort went into designing the maps to allow players with multiple options to traverse the space station by investigating every nook and cranny. The talent system via neuromods is exciting. I loved being able to build my character in a ton of different ways including some abilities which make you superpowered in some regards. Picking up items and throwing them at enemies with leverage was genuinely fun. Unfortunately, that's where the good ends. 

While there's plenty to explore and investigate, it ultimately feels quite pointless when there's nothing truly compelling to push you forward. Game design which revolves around picking up random objects around the map isn't anything new. Previous games like Thief, Deus Ex, and System Shock locked that up decades ago. Prey doesn't bring much new to the table in that regard. That's a problem because while those previously mentioned games had interesting stories and characters, Prey doesn't. There isn't an established singular antagonist until well into the game. Sure, there's Typhon creatures wandering the station, but they're just mindless blobs without an established motive. That wouldn't be a problem if the mysterious elements of the game were enough to keep you going, but the story pacing makes the mystery fade away. About 8 hours in, I found myself forgetting what I was really trying to accomplish in the main story and then realized that I just didn't care. I was exploring for the sake of exploring and to make sure I had enough "materials" to keep my inventory going.

Which leads to the next problem: inventory management. The recycler and fabricator is an interesting concept, but I found it to be more tedious than fun. You have to spend a lot of time picking up trash around the map to recycle and ultimately fabricate items to use. I think I would have preferred less trash and more items without the need to fabricate anything. It felt like an unfun intermediate step.

The audio also really bothered me. At first, it was fun to be spooked by a mimic and its accompanying audio twang, but eventually it grated on me and became annoying. And what's with the audio cue radius in this game? I swear it would make the screeching spooky noises for creatures multiple rooms away from me. Or when you're wandering around and an operator suddenly screams HELLO MR. YU even though you're no where near it. It breaks the "immersion" part of the genre when the audio is so off.

The combat and enemy system has a lot to be desired. The enemy design started off interesting but never proceeded beyond various forms of black goo. Mimics were fun until they weren't. Phantoms and poltergeists were never fun. The two enemies you're introduced to in the first 15 minutes are the only two you see for most of the game (including their variations). Yes, you'll run into bigger baddies but they're few and far between. You better enjoy dealing with mimics and phantoms.

While this game emphasizes that running, hiding, and sneaking is a valid tactic, I found that they aren't in reality. If you want to explore and investigate every room like this genre encourages you to do, then you're going to run into a lot of combat sequences. That's a problem because the combat is clunky. I'm not expecting this game to be a Doom-like action shooter, but I do expect gunplay to feel satisfying. Enemies are sometimes bullet sponges, which requires you to fabricate more bullets, which requires you to explore for more junk, which causes you to end up in more combat. Your weapon choice consists of far too many non-lethal options, most of which appear to be various forms of grenades.

Overall, it's not a bad game. It's polished and had a lot of potential, but ultimately felt a little flat without a compelling reason to continue immersing myself in the sim.

144510441.review:
[h1]Prey is a top-tier sci-fi immersive action experience with incredible polish and passion behind it; a myriad of weapons, abilities, and enemies make for engaging and interesting gameplay.[/h1]
[h3]I played 14 hours in one day of this game. Seriously fun.[/h3]

[b]Settings:[/b]
-Dot reticle
-Played on Very High graphics preset with 90 FOV
-Played on Normal Difficulty
[hr][/hr]
[h2]Pros:[/h2]
[list]
[*]One of if not the best environments in gaming; Wonderfully interconnected and whole and LIVING. Open world as well. There's a surprising amount of variance in looks and structure within the space station, which is impressive
[*]Really strong introduction sequence; total mindfuck (also neat intro credits); the tutorial is excellent and I didn't even notice it was a tutorial until I watched Joseph Anderson's review and he pointed it out
[*]Interesting and thrilling story
[*]As you get better, you have access to new places inside old areas; Gives you reasons to revisit
[*]Fully rewarded for exploring
[*]Prop hunt: Looting is tied to a source of danger, so searching rooms gets even more interesting
[*]All weapons are useful in certain scenarios. The upgrade system gives weapons that may not be too useful an incredible amount of versatility
[*]Enemies are interesting to fight and the game stays surprisingly difficult but fair for Normal; Combat is alright, but isn't the best
[*]Neuromod system is super interesting
[*]Developers accounted for a ton of paths and choices. Really impressive. So much content you just may never experience
[*]Game knows how to have fun, how to scare you, how to build ambience, and how to be campy. There's a lot of variance
[/list]
[h2]Cons:[/h2]
[list]
[*]Moving and fighting in space is clunky and unfun even after getting used to space movement; fighting enemies in space (vs inside the station) is generally much harder to do
[*]Difficult to understand which difficulty is the right one for you (it's usually normal)
[*]The prop hunt mechanic is pretty much destroyed later on in the game by an upgrade. It ran its course, but I wish there was more to this
[*]The vignette when you crouch is annoying and lame
[*]Some areas have dialog triggers right next to encounters with enemies, and most live conversations aren't saved as audio logs, which is really lame. I missed a few pieces of dialogue due to this
[*]The Nightmare is a fantastic concept but ends up being really poorly done. Nearly every time I interacted with the Nightmare it somehow glitched out in a very noticeable way. It also doesn't hunt well enough. It also just straight up disappears when the timer ends.
[*]There's a bug with a golden gun you can obtain via a sidequest where it shows the wrong damage numbers, which makes it look worse than the default pistol.
[*]Another bug where the fire in the shuttle bay was invisible, with only the light surrounding it informing you where the fire is generally
[*]Some side quests are just lame (DnD one; it ends with you guessing passcode combinations (there are 24))
[*]PONR without directly spelling it out to the player which locks you out of sidequests is lame and no amount of muh immersion cope will ever fix it
[*]Sometimes objective complete notifications or calls will interrupt serious or scary moments, breaking the tension
[*]Hacking is far too simple and overstays its welcome. It's not horrible, it's just not fun the 80th time you do it. Also the time allotted for level 3 and 4 hacking is too much. Level 2 is actually the hardest, so poor balancing as well
[*]Notification system is lame and overbearing at times. Sometimes it needlessly holds your hand as well, but that's an incredibly difficult thing to balance. I personally would wait before entering combat or entering a zone for notifications and story beats to fully play out so I didn't miss anything. Sometimes if you move into an area with a dialogue trigger it would overwrite previous dialogue that was queued up to play.
[*]Suit and scope chipsets are mostly underwhelming due to a few chipsets that are much better than the rest
[*]The actions [spoiler]your parents[/spoiler] take is not nearly explored enough
[*]NPC interactions are poorly done; talking to others face to face is reminiscient of older games where merely walking by an NPC will cause them to regurgitate the same dialog at you; they're also kinda glitchy
[*]End cutscene and credits are weirdly low quality; like 720p
[*]Some audio logs won't play automatically when you pick them up when they should
[/list]
[h2]Neutral:[/h2]
[list]
[*]Crosshair is noticeably low; it ends up working out fine but just kinda odd.
[/list]
[hr][/hr]
[h3]End Stats:[/h3]
[list]
[*]24h30m
[*]Good Ending
[*]Rescued 17 humans
[*]Killed 2 humans
[*]Installed 218 neuromods
[*]Acquired 52 human abilities
[*]Acquired zero typhon abilities
[/list]

Mooncrash doesn't really interest me so I won't be playing it. I played this game by painstakingly searching every single room, so trying to do that with a timelimit would break me.

Overall, Prey is a fantastic sci-fi immersive sim with some minor shortcomings that will leave you feeling totally satisfied. It's a blast from front to back, and one I will remember fondly. [url=https://isthereanydeal.com/game/preyii0ivii/info/]Goes on sale regularly, so wait for sale.[/url]

144463952.review:
A fantastic and immersive FPS. You get to explore a derelict space station, play literal hide and seek with aliens and make decisions that impact the rest of the game and the ending, like choosing who to trust or who to kill. There are a lot of secrets path and many different ways to approach objectives - you can learn skills like hacking or repairing to open up paths, and eventually even learn alien abilities if you so choose.

The story is pretty interesting, the atmosphere is great and the game feels downright scary and claustrophobic at times, with aliens disguising as objects so you always have to be cautious - at least up to a certain point, if you distribute your skill points right; you'll become pretty powerful eventually. My only complaint is that, towards the end of the game, enemy spawns can become very oppressive, forcing you to either run away from everything or use your very limited resources more than you may like. I guess it does force you to pick your battles.

Anyway, Prey is a very immersive, fun FPS with many secrets, different ways to approach objectives and choices you can make to shape your playthrough. I would definitely recommend it!

144023055.review:
I like this game, if you're reading this I think there's a good chance you'll like it too and that's really all that needs to be said: preeeeeeeeeeetty good game, ez recommend. However, I've justabouts one thing to say that holds it back for me:

The difficulty is non-existent, specifically I'm not convinced the current save system was a good decision for the game's balance.

The combat, the resource management, basically anything that would offer some form of challenge to those looking for it is trivialized by the fact you can quick load a quick save basically whenever you want. There's no real consequence to doing it beyond your own pride (and since dying force requires loading a save anyway, who even cares?), results are near instant so the ease practically encourages it, and it's not a system I can really tell players NOT to use because who wants to spend ten minutes looting a bunch of rooms and then run into an electrical grid out the corner of your eye and get all your busy-work progress reset? In acknowledgement of the more tedious alternative it's better that it exists, but only because the game is already designed with it in mind and removing it is like removing objective markers in a generic open world game.

What that means in practice though, is that in my complete Prey run on nightmare + survival mode, I never had to worry about the serious statuses (they go away when I die, I don't want to waste resources cleansing them), I never took combat seriously (even less so when I did get good at it), and I used 4 medkits, crafted 0. and recycled 20 - 40 suit repairs because it never mattered how low my health/integrity got cause the only health point that matters is your last one. I might as well have been playing on easy.

Otherwise, if you can look past that I think there's a pretty solid game here (just not the fucking hacking mini-game, I would've easily spent 20 neoromods to delete them from my run).

144013605.review:
I'm gonna downvote it and complain just because I can. Otherwise, it's a pretty good game.

This is Prey, not to be confused with Prey (2006) which shares absolutely nothing with Prey other than the name, and the vague setting of being in space with aliens. Ironically you will be constantly reading e-mails from desk stations to get passwords for hidden stashes like it's the Doom 3 engine which Prey(2006) is based on.

It's somewhat System shock, but not really. Haven't played System Shock extensively but most of the inspiration is in the inventory system, immersion and dialogue found in deskstations and audio logs. But the result is you will have to press 24 different buttons to access different menus.

It's somewhat a metroidvania, but not really. Your map progress is not limited by an item, it is limited by which skill you pick in the RPG tree. It seldom matters anyway because there are usually 2 to 3 ways to get somewhere which doesn't use a skill you have no points in.

It's somewhat a horror game, but not really. It's not that the enemy design looks bad, it's just bland, and it takes a lot from the fear factor other horror games would give.

It's somewhat a FPS, but not really. You can go in guns blazing, especially if you pick the security tree nodes, but all the ressources in game are limited, so you will eventually run out of bullets even if you craft a ton of them.

It's somewhat a stealth game, but not really. You can use stealth but once in a while you will have to fight creatures. Either because it's a forced fight, or just because Typhons give precious ressources you need. Heck, sometimes stealth is pointless cause you can just run to an exit even if every enemy spotted you. What's the point ?

Everything has been slightly diluted and as such it feels like it succeeds at neither.

And then it hit me : I'm in space, on a spaceship, being somewhat of a lone survivor, fighting alien creatures and talking to two AIs. This game is like Marathon (Halo before Halo) with a bit of welcome to hanwell thrown in the middle and a graphical design reminicent of 2001 a space odyssey.

143982717.review: I call this luxury gaming. Everything works together: the incredible level-design, the art, the functional consistency, the meta-layers of the plot, the callbacks to other immersive sims, the progression-systems, the music and sound-design, the humor. It all results in a celebration of immersive gaming. Only its spiritual successor Neuroshock will surpass it (they are working on that right?). And after that ascension of course.

143955187.review:
This is one of the best immersive sim games, more suitable for players prefer slower pace game.  Overall it requires some patience to observe the surrounding,  understand the enemy, decide the approach and there are always multiple ways to handle enemies and situations effectively.  It has great replay value as different builds' style are very different.  

It puzzles me why a game with such quality didn't sell as well as it should.  Is this really because immersive sim is a niche genre?  It looks like after this game, Arkane is trying to combine other elements such as multiplayer with immersive sim and failed catastrophically.  Probably it would be best to control budget and work on a mid-sized pure immersive sim game.

Achievements in this game requires multiple play through.  This is not a bad thing as some beauty of this game can only be experienced after being forced to use different ways to tackle the challenges.  Just for a reference, my first run of main game took 40 hours, then the next 3 runs took 50 hours to complete all achievements in the main game.   The DLC took me 30 hours for many runs to complete everything.  Just remember that 5 success escape in the same run will reset DLC status.  Make sure you are really ready before doing that.

143743343.review:
This is one of the only games I have played where it is actually practical to disable objective markers to help improve immersion. (except for the outside bits, which is a small portion of the game), for most games where doing this is recommended, I have found it to be more trouble than it's worth. Prey does it better than most by having relatively intuitive environmental design, I was rarely lost, and the other aspects of the game that boost immersion, like well implemented audio logs  added to this. (seriously, technically the best I've seen, I wish their were more of them, they blended perfectly with the gameplay)

I start there because immersion was what impressed me most about the game. coinciding with this is the atmosphere, especially early on, the main location of the game is a well interconnected metroidvania style area that has an effective tension to it, without ever feeling overly horrific. Some games like this never make sense of why any reasonable person would ever want to live/work in the place the disaster happened, like the police station in Resident Evil 2. If not for the monsters running around, this would be a very pleasant place!

Speaking to the horror, this is one of the missteps of the game, mainly fumbled by the enemy design, light spoilers,

The main enemy of the game can transform into various environmental objects, chairs, cups, etc. Early on, this was terrifying, and had me nervously bashing practically everything I could see as I slowly worked my way through this place. Eventually, I took a couple hits from these things and realized that they don't really do enough damage to be a threat, and are pretty easy to stunlock once you hit them with your wrench once, so it was pretty rare for me to get hit more than once by the same monster. This completely killed the tension for me, and any reason I had to be cautious about what I was picking up (so long as I waited long enough for my health to regenerate to a safe level after an encounter, which doesn't take long), I think this would be alright if they were harder to hit once you engaged with them, but they often try and run away and transform into an object to hide right in front of you, making them even easier to take out. 

On the other hand, the other main type of enemy (which has various subtypes), is a little harder to deal with than it should be, it's a large humanoid blob (with various powers depending on the type). Early on, it requires excess caution to safely defeat these things, slowing the game to a crawl, and it's impractical to avoid them since you want to explore and you need their stuff for upgrades. You CAN avoid them, but it's not ideal. This might be a me problem, but these things made me a little to itchy with the quicksave trigger, because I wasn't really interested in recklessly losing to them and having to go back more than a minute. I think I would like these things if they were just larger versions of the other enemy, and transformed into larger objects like vending machines, or maybe fake doors for you to try and go through that could catch you off guard. Once you get a gun, especially a shotgun, these monsters becomes jokes, so there's not really a point in the game where they are both challenging and fun to fight. As is, I would drop these enemies from the game entirely, except for the fire version, which was scary and cool enough to make up for the other aspects. 

There are other enemies in the game, none of which really have great designs (and a few can be damage spongey), but I don't have strong feelings about them either way. 

The characters are mostly fine, they did the job they needed to but I couldn't say any of them were all that memorable. The story was pretty solid I thought.  Voice acting is S tier. 

The gunplay and movement is really fun once you get the hang of it, it would be better with better enemies but it's still very enjoyable. The character upgrades you can get mostly make either exploration or combat easier, I didn't put a lot of upgrades into the superpower stuff, so I don't really know how most of that would have been. 

Overall a definite recommend.

143579321.review:
I recommend this game to people who like these kind of games (adventure, mystery, some horror). Though, I have to say that (in my opinion)  these games are played best without to much prior knowledge about it. Hence I will try to conceal any spoilers below the 'Read more' part, while staying 'vague' before. 

I have to admit, unlike my first impression (and ability to read properly, since it is stated very clearly), this game contains horror-elements. And personally, I'm not really a big fan of that, since unlike the adrenaline-response it may have for others, I usually fall into a pit of existential dread, which I try to avoid.

I only played for a small time (around 15/16 hours) but I did get a good impression of the game. (Maybe this changes if one plays longer, but for now, this is my opinion on the matter).

Still, what drew me into the game in the first place was the ability to explore somewhat freely, as in, while there are things blocking the way, it is possible to somewhat get around of certain problems, when looked at from a creative point. It feels 'metroidvania' to me and I liked that and the game actually makes good on that part. 

* Warning, some spoilers ahead *

Since I don't play many of these games, I'm not going to comment on how buttons are assigned etc. though I was happy with that selecting weapons/inventory pauses the game, which gave you a chance to heal/eat etc.

I also liked the atmosphere, but as stated before, I'm not really a fan of horror and that *is* present, both jumpscares as well as psychological stuff. For example, there's an area where you discover that some scientists were (as a side project) were trying to make a foam dart shooter (which you actually get) and you can read there mail and listen to conversations about how they made it etc. and this reminded me (as a scientist myself) about things I did with my classmates. And then you realise all (or atleast most of them) are dead. And that actually hit me, hence the existential dread part.

One thing I did was change the audio settings after meeting the first person, since that person talked so loudly. Only to reset it later since all the other spoken text/talks were not as loud.

When first playing the game, you start in a room to look around, read some stuff etc. And the game also allows you to pick up stuff and either drop it or  throw it. So I saw a coffee machine and a cup. And as a coffee drinker myself, I thought I just put the cup under the coffee machine. First time dropped it on the counter, second time smashed it at the coffee machine. Well, no coffee for Morgan Yu...

Upgrades and Skills: In the game you can aqcuire upgrades (quite a lot actually). For Morgan, you use Neuromods, which allow skills, like hacking (minigame), lifting heavy stuff, upgrade your suit, upgrade some weapon stats, fixing stuff etc. Later on, you also get some extra (psychic) skills, which are based on the enemies, bot attacking as well as defending. And the best one, change into an object (you can still move and jump etc.) while being a cup/book for example.

Then there are 'weapon upgrade packs', used to upgrade weapons , but upgrading these further, requires some extra skills.

You also have a map (which you sometimes have to download from a pc), and actually a lot of stats and data. For example, you can re-read any email you've seen and when getting a code, it shows you when you need it. (I liked that!) 

Also, later on, you can change materials (from you inventory) into material-blocks, which can then be used to craft other stuff. Crafting requires you to have the building/design plan (from pc's). My (only) issue with this was that both neuromods and weapons/ammo require a specific (same) one, which I ran out of quickly despite looting the place like a desperate kleptomaniac. And since this was a case of survival, I would have had no problem shoving everthing else (like bookcases/bags/carts and anything else) into the machine, if it gave me more material-blocks, because I always felt like having not enough ammo... 

Annoying to switch between the treasure hunt maps and real map, since the email-viewer always resets to the top one.

Dislike: respawning enemies. And not just the same enemies, no, they become harded each time. However, they only respawn when transitioning from one area into another (which is clearly stated), which atleast makes it better. But it made me want to do as much as possible in one area before going to another one. This is probably, beacuse after a while, there's no more loot to find lying around and the enemies do drop stuff, even ammo...

Psy-helmet (which obscures view and sound): allows you to detect (upgrade) and scan enemies to unlock extra (psy) powers (and more info on them).

The game is composed out of several maps, with a central 'hub' (lobby). And while the first 2/3 maps are rather short, requiring you to go back to the hub afterwards, the one after that (psychotronics/something) just goes on and on. And when I finally, had the option to go back to the lobby (using a now fixed elevator), since I gotten some upgrades, which I wanted to explore the rest of the lobby with, I came down only to see the lobby infested with enemies. And they all saw me coming down the elevator. (I have to explain that I was playing on the second easiest option) and these enemies were not just the smaller ones. No, they were one of the hardest ones. So I went back up, since I had some objectives left I could do there first. 

I also liked that you could go outside of the spacestation. 

There are several weapons and I only used a few of them. Some only for solving 'puzzles' and some for combat. 
-Wrench: Used to hit things with, which I did to preserve ammo.
-GLOO cannon: Despite it not saying this, it worked wonders against some of the more difficult enemies (like the telepath) despite not stating this.
-Shotgun: I was granted the Margrave shotgun (as part of my bonus stuff) and this worked well against the earlier enemies. Short distance is a problem for later ones. 
- Silenced/golden gun: Nice to pick health of an enemy at medium distance.
- Shock/taser gun: To me, worthless due to short range, the enemies stated to be weak to electricity, mostly also shoot ranged.
- Foam-dart gun: Does no damage, puzzles only.
- Q-Beam: Effective when having enough ammo, overlays the enemies healthbar and kills the enemy if health is reached. 
- Some bombs: Different bombtypes with different effects. Small amount, not sure when to use them.
- Don't remember others. (Throwing stuff also does damage)

I liked that the GLOO cannon allows you to build 'block' which you can stand on, though you can't make a block on a previous block (probably because this would render a lot of obstacles useless). Still, it would allow you to make a stairway on the side of a wall to climb up that wall etc.

Second dislike: Weapons can be upgraded, but I used N-Mods more for the practical stuff (lifting, hacking) and not weapons. I also didn't use the psy-skills, since turrets will fire on you if you have to much and, because the game tells you that this might be 'bad' for you, so I only used 'morph' since some rooms are inaccessable without it. However, it seems the weapons don't seem to scale with the later, more difficult enemies (on the second easiest dificulty level!), nevermind the 'lock' on N-Mods which temporarily stops you from crafting them, while I could really use them and actually had enough materials to make them.

Now, some enemies are weak to fire, if only there was a flame-thrower... *in ear whispering* Yes, but that psy-skill could be bad for me, game, you told me yourself... Besides, I had set up turrets in the lobby at strategical locations...

I still recommend this game, but I myself would love a game with these mechanics set in a less horror environment (maybe action focused), because I really liked figuring out where I could go using my skills and weapons. Well done game!

Really good game, enjoyed it a lot. I can highly recommend!
The game mechanics are great, the story is great, the characters are also great. Some of the voice actors are not perfect and the character animations are kinda basic but it doesn't really matter because they aren't the focus of the game.

The attention to detail to everything in the game is through the roof. The devs really cared about this game in my opinion. You can find so many little things, the space station really feels like people lived there.

I played it on normal difficulty and it seemed well balanced.

It can still be enjoyable after the first playthrough. I played with mainly human abilities and explored a lot, only left 2-3 side quests unsolved and took about 48 hours. It was a really great experience.
On my second playthrough I chose only Typhon abilities and played it for about 30 hours and left several side quests incompleted.

Both ability trees have extremely useful things but I found that the best is when you combine the best of both.

There are different ways to play the game depending on player's preference. For example you can be stealthy (evade kind of stealth not silent killer type), you can be Rambo with upgraded weapons and fight up close or from a distance, you can use your abilities to trick your enemies or make them kill each other etc.

Would buy it again.

P.S: Also to everyone who plays it: wait for the end credits to roll, don't force quit!!

143052786.review:
What if System Shock 2 had a sequel? Or a spiritual successor? Would be pretty cool, even if it was named somewhat differently. Well there it is!

This is a very much fantastic example of imersive simulator subgenre - there's tons of ways to approach a problem, like you can just shoot or sneak around enemies, but you can also use distractions, or use friendly defensive systems, or just find an alternate route which may require yet another set of tools to reach. This game in particular got a pretty modest selection of traditional weapons and offensive powers, only pistol and shotgun and they're costly to use often at that, but there's a load of fascinating utility devices, like grenades that recycle any surrounding objects into base matter to use with crafting stations or sealant cannons that can freeze-trap enemies AND negate hazards AND offer walkable platforms! On other hand the supernatural powers you can unlock are actually pretty generic in many regards, there's some interesting applications but you don't grant the mobility nor offer the excitement of say Arkane's Dishonored ones - apart from one, that is. See, one of enemy types in this game are what's essentially Half-Life headcrabs if they could shapeshift into coffee cups or other props - and you can receive and use similar power too, playing prophunt with space predators and robots!

The art style is neat too, the space station action takes place on is varied in styles, there's some decadent art deco areas and old utilitarian areas, and all the details and side plot exposition is neat. The storyline is also surprisingly neat with some unexpected plot twists throughout the 20 hours of game.

This goes surprisingly cheap during sales, it's super memorable and replayable, you should totally buy this.

142473541.review:
Prey has stunning environments and rewarding exploration, much of it felt like an actual living space and the game could be incredibly immersive as a result. It's no doubt what the game does best, exploring new places was always a joy. Despite that, backtracking was a massive pain, the map system isn't the best and what's meant to be the game's version of fast travel does not fulfill that purpose. Plenty of loading screens, having it on SSD is crucial.

The weakest part of the game has to be the combat, I found the enemies dull and their attacks annoying, often impossible to dodge. It usually just came down to bringing the right tool for the job, therefore it's hard to get much enjoyment out of it if you prefer to rely on fast reactions and combat skills. It was also never the right difficulty, was too punishing early on and not enough of a challenge towards mid and late game.

The story was pretty interesting, the opening will be forever memorable for me, along with the really difficult choices and moral dilemmas the game sometimes throws at the player. There is, however, a noticeable slump in the mid-game, and the ending felt very abrupt.[spoiler]The ending itself is an interesting twist, but to not get any info on what happened to the real Talos I in the end is a crime. It takes the player's investment in the story and throws it out the window.[/spoiler]

There were some bugs, nothing game-breaking or anything that couldn't be resolved by reloading and such, but they could still be very annoying. Audio mixing was all over the place, and it was common for voice lines to overlap. That covers my main complaints.

Whether you'd enjoy the game depends heavily on how important combat is to you, how much you enjoy exploration and piecing together stories and how much patience you can muster when the game's being a pain in the ass.
4/5

142279398.review:
A lot of what makes Prey such a good game is its surprises. Therefore, I would leave the story elements out of the review, but it's worth noting that the game offers a substantial and intricate narrative.

Prey's gameplay revolves around exploration, puzzle-solving, and combat, blending them together in a very intuitive way. It shares similarities with Bioshock's gameplay, making it a likely choice for fans of the Bioshock series.

Visually, Prey excels in capturing a hauntingly beautiful atmosphere. The graphics are crisp, showcasing impressive lighting effects that contribute to the game's overall immersive experience. However, occasional frame rate drops and texture pop-in issues detract from an otherwise visually stunning game.

The audio design in Prey is exceptional, enhancing the atmospheric experience even further. The sound effects, from the eerie noises of the alien creatures to the hum of the space station's machinery, create a palpable sense of tension and unease. The ambient soundtrack, composed by Mick Gordon, perfectly complements the game's setting and amplifies the emotional impact of key moments.

- Su diseño de mapas es muy bueno, con un estilo metroidvania donde vas desbloqueando caminos y haciendo backtracking cuando consigues nuevas formas de avanzar.
- Buenos gráficos
- Sientes que cada Neuromod (punto de habilidad) te ayuda a avanzar, por lo que es un muy buen juego de rol.
- Buen sistema de mejora de armas, despiece, construcción... que hará que explores cada rincón buscando recursos.
- El juego, sin ser extremadamente difícil, te requiere estar centrado y jugar bien, o los enemigos te machacarán. 
- Muy bueno sistema de exploración espacial, se siente fluido y libre.
- Historia muy interesante.

CONTRA
- Poca variedad de enemigos (Dos tipos de enemigos y dentro de cada tipo unas 4 variedades).
- Pocas armas (4-5 armas si no me equivoco).

9/10

142240711.review:
So, I watched LPs of Prey when it came out, and I knew all the big story elements for awhile, but it looked interesting, and I [b]LOVE[/b] System Shock 2, and to a lesser extent the BioShocks, and I said to myself, "I'd better check this one out," given the pedigree and the reviews. And I [i]hated[/i] playing Prey (the demo). I hated it [i]so much[/i] that I completely wrote it off. The enemies being way strong, your pistol being garbage, your movement being so slow, and all the inventory stuff being dumbed down -- I hated it all, except the story was pretty good. I was never going to play Prey myself.

And then.

Epic made Prey free, a good while ago, and I got it, but with no real intent to ever play it.

Eventually, I got COVID, and I thought, I'm stuck here in quarantine, and I can't go back to work for another week, and I played it straight through, all the way to the end. Because, it turns out, the [i]key[/i] to playing Prey is the combos. It's [b][i]ALL[/i][/b] about the combos, the sneak attack bonus damage, the make-the-enemies-infight plans, the juice-yourself-with-so-many-neuromods-the-enemies-can't-run-fast-enough-to-catch-you strats -- anything but straightforward gunplay. And once I accepted that to interact with the story, I had to interact with the gameplay loop of enhancing damage output by roleplaying with the tools that Prey gives you, I had an absolute blast.

Now, I'm not a huge fan of the procedural randomness in Mooncrash, because wow I forsee that making every future Shock-style game being worse by being used as a crutch to avoid investing in the density of the in-game lore and environment, but alternatively wow the base game has so much density of in-game lore and stark environmental beauty. Nearly every room has lore and environmental story-telling, if you pause to search around, and the sheer mass of Prey's tools mean once you finally understand where things are and how they interact, it's a wonderful playground for messing about with the game itself, and for experiencing the game from multiple angles and routes.

Really, that's the key -- Prey isn't so much a shooter as it is an interactive playground with the story being integrated so tightly into each map's layout that you organically experience different stories every time you play differently, [b]but[/b] you first must understand and then master the tools Prey gives you to do it enjoyably. The first time I played Prey through, I was very skeptical of doing Typhon neuromods, even having researched them all, so I accidentally ended up with a pure human playthrough. Later, I played through again with both neuromod trees, and then a newgame plus run where I ended up about 1/4 of the way through with all neuromods installed, and just ran around completely abusing my sweet, sweet powers and my maxed out weaponry. This time around, I'm doing a pure Typhon run, and the experience is shockingly different, not so much from being Nightmare with all survival difficulty settings on, but from being weak, slow, unable to hack or repair anything at all. I'm reduced to slowly creeping about, avoiding hazards instead of repairing or powering through them, fighting encounters half a dozen times or more until I understand the best way to whittle down a tough enemy with barely any tools (and no neuromods until much of the way through the game), and making errand runs repeatedly to recycle the loot I've found so I can upgrade each weapon until it inevitably breaks. I still have plenty of psi hypos and medkits, and I know how to use operators to my advantage, but wow, it's really challenging in such a fun way, even though it's my [i]fourth[/i] playthrough. It's so special to play a game and be rewarded for my choices, finding new lore each run through, even though I thought I was super thorough! and seeing the cleverness in the design choices of the environment so I [i]can[/i] ignore an area, but if I wrack my brain, I can use a well-placed recycler charge, or a Mimic power, or try to blow things up with a Kinetic Blast, and then I'm into an area that before I'd have just used hacking or repair like all the other times, and the new route and the new access method makes the same story line and same environment and same weapons feel fresh all over.

All that said, the GLOO gun breaks it all so much it's hilarious. And the mantling is pretty sketch, even without GLOO -- a default mantling is the only time I've ever fallen out of the map in Prey -- but you get used to it. And if you find the microgravity movement and orientation really hard like I did at first, try to adjust the FOV wider (unfortunately, in a config file, but at least you can do it) until you can orient yourself comfortably, and then it's not nearly so bad.

In short, I played this game for two hundred hours, and then I bought the Steam version and played eleven more, and then I redeemed a GOG key so I could play with the golden shotgun, and you can, too. Female Morgan is better. The pigeons are the best.

141958981.review:
I'm a diehard fan of Arkane Lyon, and while this definitely scratches the Arkane itch, it doesn't quite have the same charm as the Dishonored games or Deathloop.

First, the cons:

In Prey, you're always vulnerable. There is no point in the game at which you start to feel that your abilities are snowballing into a powerful build, even on the lower difficulties. It's very hard to keep your firearm ammo topped up because the enemies are bullet sponges, making a guns-blazing approach impractical. There is always some level of danger, and most of your ability points will go into avoidance, not combat. Now, take this with a grain of salt as I haven't actually finished the game - but after 15 hours, I still haven't gotten a comfortable build and the grind to find/make effective ammo has gotten tiring.

The game takes place on a space station, so there's a good bit of level recycling and backtracking through areas. Sometimes I'll clear an area of enemies, finish a mission, then encounter more enemies as I pass back through the area I just cleared. This is particularly annoying because enemies disguise themselves as common objects.

Now, the pros:

Prey is pretty believable. The space station has an art deco vibe which is an interesting combination and very much Arkane's distinct style. Similar to Dishonored, there are usually multiple ways to approach a level, whether it be firepower, stealth, or something else entirely.

There are a few missions where you'll need to space walk un-tethered, and it is creepy. The scale of the space station from the outside is really impressive. Combined with debris and corpses floating around in a huge void rife with enemies, the spacewalk levels are my favorite part of the game.

The whole game entails unraveling a series of central mysteries, and finding the pieces of the puzzle does feel pretty cool. This is the biggest selling point in my personal opinion.

Overall if you like mild sci-fi horror, it's a decent game. The premise, environment, and technology are all pretty believable. I think it's at least worth a play through.

141957297.review: Prey is an excellent Immersive Sim. Would recommend it to any fans of the genre.

141955846.review:
Any big fan of the System Shock and Deus Ex games is bound to love Prey. This is an extremely well crafted and polished experience, fine tuned in just about every aspect. The game is a mix of action, puzzle solving and RPG elements like the aforementioned titles driven by a strong story, quests and player choices. Player agency is a major factor in why I loved this game so much, your choices aren't limited to just choosing skill points and weapons upgrade, but rather everything in the game. Every situation and challenge can legitimately be accomplished through a multitude of ways utilizing the game's well crafted systems (combat, hacking, stealth) or a combination of any of the three. Prey allows the player to get creative to accomplish their goals and progress in the game, you are never herded into any specific play style. 
Every system in the game seem extremely well tuned, as if the makers carefully distilled everything that worked great in System Shock or Deus Ex and added it to Prey. Quests, inventory, data and voice logs are easily organized and accesible through the game's well crafted interface. 
Perhaps the greatest character in the game is the space station itself, it feels like a lived in place that underwent a disaster without it feeling forced or like a prop.
The only negatives I have to say about Prey is that the game is on the longer side and tends to drag a bit during the middle of the title but the story was engaging enough to make you push onwards. 
It is a huge shame that Prey got almost no publicity, was marred by using a name of an older and fairly mediocre shooter and was effectively ignored - it should have been at least as well known as Bioshock, a title that is often called a spiritual successor to system shock but that title fits Prey much better. 
If you're a fan of the aforementioned titles or even a survival horror fan in general, you're bound to have a good time.

141673514.review:
What a timeless masterpiece…Like, no one expected anything less from the developers of Dishonored but godd*mn…

What really got to me was [u][b]writing[/b][/u] and more importantly how coherently it delivers itself to the player through the complex worldbuilding. The writing complements the environmental storytelling in such an organic and compelling way that the player’s experience transcends into complete immersion. For some reason, the game gives me the impression of a compassionate mentor. In writing, it is reflected in lessons and perspectives the game tries to tackle, always questioning your level of understanding and subsequently giving you even more food for thought. It very often reaches towards your “inner humanity” and sympathy, while constantly emphasizing the problem of decision-making. Split personality, various points of view, human factor, personal motivations and the sense of duty are just a couple of those lessons and perspectives, and it all perfectly connects into one beautiful whole. Overall, the game communicates with the player on so many levels that playing it absentmindedly is a disservice to your own intelligence. 

The [u][b]atmosphere[/b][/u] feels like…it has always been there. At first, it doesn’t seem to be anything out of the ordinary, but then the realization comes that it’s crafted in such a thorough and permeating way that everything appears to align in perfect harmony and once the first notes of the soundtrack start playing, it fills you with such an overwhelming sense of belonging that you can’t help but keep traversing this fateful space station. 

And then there’s [u][b]map design[/b][/u]. The visual aspect is absolutely stunning, no doubt about that, but the technical part is what makes you really admire its beauty. The overall design, the layout of singular locations and specific passages are so well-done that my inner perfectionist was high all the time. It takes a master of their craft to create something that complex and intuitive at the same time. Not only do you actually get to traverse the whole space station, the locations at no point feel overwhelming or incomplete. It’s so obvious that map designers approached their task critically and thoughtfully that I can’t help but marvel at their dedication and ingenuity.

When it comes to [u][b]gameplay[/b][/u]…I’ll start by saying that you won't feel the whole depth of the gameplay until you play the game on Nightmare. On Normal and Hard mode, you can just shotgun your way through the whole game and not feel a thing. On Nightmare, the head-on approach is most certainly a failure. It will make you strategize, explore the map for resources, calculate risks and look for various solutions. You won't be running straight towards the enemy and spreading lead like a maniac. It will require you to allocate at least two brain cells and think of a plan. Ultimately, Nightmare mode provides the most enjoyable experience, where your actions mirror your resourcefulness. Gameplay here does wonders when you actually start feeling it.
	
On the whole, Prey wants you to experience the very content it has to deliver. It might appear short but it’s only if you carelessly speedrun it. I’d say its duration is perfect when it comes to action games. It actually gives you a fat, juicy, flavorful and digestible chunk of content with little to no nonsense. It is a masterfully crafted piece no matter how you look at it. 

P.S. Mooncrush is a worthy continuation of Prey that for the most part showcases the aforementioned juicy gameplay.

I don't know what you want me to tell you, I throw everything specifically including the kitchen sink at the aliens and turn them into fine paste, what more do you want.

All jokes aside, this game is absolutely excellent with very few weak points, it definitely is one of the best immersive sims ever made with actually meaningful gameplay differences in builds and a lot of choices turn out to matter in really unexpected ways.

The atmosphere of this game is peak suspicious fry meme "I don't like where this is going" in both story and gameplay once you start eyeing every single chair, expecting it to turn into a mimic.

The central twist of the story is both incredibly easy to figure out and still manages to blindside you in the end, when they turn everything around on you.

The only thing I really dislike is that in my opinion the game relies too much on its zero g mechanic in certain parts of the story, since the free form navigation and traversal is not particularly good.

Honestly, the worst thing of this game is how incredibly mad it makes you when you remember that Redfall killed this studio because over 70% of the people that made Prey quit during development of Redfall.

141605391.review:
Gave the game a shot because it's developed by Arkane and not Bethesda. Unfortunately, like everything Bethesda touches, this game just reeks of their influence and you can see that Prey 2017 is only the same as Prey 2006 in name. To start off my dislikes, the game is incredibly slow to get started (about an actual hour just for the introductory stuff) and only really serves to introduce the rather uninteresting mimic enemy who eventually becomes quite tedious to deal with when there's a few. They're quite weak, but don't turn your back on them; especially if there are multiple.

This game also released with Denuvo despite it being a single-player game, which was definitely pushed through by Bethesda because of their lack of understanding on what is necessary for development. I feel sorry for Arkane in how much of their decision making was overshadowed by poor publisher mandates, which likely hurt their development freedom.

The graphics are great for terminals, but the controls surrounding them seem a bit clunky where you can use the mouse to navigate but need to press F to confirm the selection. Fortunately you can't break them, because I would have done it by accident a few times lol. Outside of the terminal graphics, this is a pretty decent looking 2017 game. I wouldn't say the people look particularly good, but they don't have the clay-person feeling either. The animations are relatively fluid, but there's weight lacking on weapons that make them feel good to use.

The story however is kind of ass, even from peeking into the wiki. It didn't really have any strong motivators to do anything, and I didn't feel attachment to any of the characters. I'd say save the cash and just watch someone play it on YouTube, it'll give you about the same experience.

141126309.review:
It's a 6 or 7 out of 10 from me. It's a good game, and one I'd recommend on sale.

The environment design is by far the game's strongest selling point. The space station Talos I really feels like it had been lived in, and the environmental storytelling is probably the best in any game I've played. Moving between low gravity and normal gravity areas is also a neat gimmick, and the low gravity sections are often enough that it feels like a welcome change, but don't overstay their welcome. 

The story as well is well written, and toys about with philosophical notions such as identity and the self, with the game opening in a way that makes you question the reality of the game's world in what is a pretty believable setting (again, helped the environment design). The ending(s) are divisive. I won't explain them, obviously. I thought they were pretty good, but there is a fairly glaring plothole. That's one for the comments, I guess,

For reference, I played the game on the second hardest difficult without hardcore enabled and the totally optional decision to (minor spoiler that you can read in achievement descriptions) 
[spoiler] not use any upgrades that give you enemy abilities.[/spoiler] . The gameplay starts well but peaks early. The game touts that there are many ways to solve a problem, but as you progress and start collecting upgrades, you don't end up needing to think too much about it.

My main gripe however, is with the enemy design. Most enemies are made of this plasma-like flowing substance, making them seem slightly formless. It's great design for an alien creature, but hitting anything other than a mimic didn't seem satisfying. You can knock enemies down with a sneak attack from your wrench or stun them with your stungun, but there never feels like there's much "weight" when you hit an enemy, for lack of a better term. It's like hitting a particularly sturdy bubble that just goes *pop* and spits out loot. Some of the other enemies are just bullet sponges that are a chore to fight. That said, you should experiment with your approach to each enemy. It can be a lot of fun.

All in all, it's a game that's a bit weak at its core, but what kept me playing was the promise of something interesting to look at or read as I wandered through its amazingly crafted world. There were loads of neat moments like recognising email trails across different computers, climbing around a barricade to find a corpse with a name I'd read or finding a diary that explained why the hell there were so many autographed baseball gloves everywhere.

Couple quick tips to close off, although you might want to figure things out yourself:
*[spoiler]The little enemies that spawn from nests will chase anything that's moving at speed. Just chuck something in their direction and they'll explode on it, rather than wasting your ammo.[/spoiler]
*[spoiler] Recycler charges can be used to clear barricades you can't lift. Throwing something that's heavy but you are strong enough to lift can also topple heavier things[/spoiler]
*[spoiler]Don't spend too many upgrade kits on the silenced pistol. It's the only gun in the game you can get a better version of.[/spoiler]
*[spoiler]If you're after the achievement for not killing any humans, the stungun can knock them out. If they're killed by an enemy, it doesn't count.[/spoiler]
*[spoiler]Check the ceilings of every room you get into. You might find something interesting in the rafters, or a way around a locked door.[/spoiler]

141108289.review:
This game has been harder for me to get into than most, but ultimately is a masterpiece. 

To me the closest popular game I can compare this too is Bioshock. Both games feature an Art Deco style and the feeling of abandonment in an isolated place gone bad where you have to use powers and guns to survive, but it stops there because Prey is more evolved than Bioshock.

The story of Prey is shockingly deep and nuanced and the gameplay makes you think because there's a lot to discover and a lot of ways to do it with the game dynamically evolving around your choices. You can be a sneaky hacker, a bold gunslinger, or an astronaut Macgyver. While a lot of games sell themselves on being choice driven not many do it even half as well as Prey does.

In conclusion I think this game is criminally underrated and unpopular. It deserves more love, more attention, and a sequel. It is one of the most intriguing FPS games out there and deserves a place among other great singleplayer fps games such as Half Life 2, Bioshock, Titanfall 2, Outer Wilds, and more. A game above other games.
