141073939.review:
I recently embarked on an exhilarating journey through the captivating world of Prey, and let me tell you, it was an experience like no other. As a fan of science fiction and immersive gameplay, I was instantly drawn to this title, and boy, did it deliver!

Prey takes place in a near-future setting aboard the Talos I, a space station orbiting the moon. You play as Morgan Yu, a protagonist whose memory has been tampered with, forcing you to unravel the mysteries surrounding your own identity while battling an alien threat known as the Typhon. From the very beginning, the game had me hooked with its intriguing premise.

One of the standout features of Prey is its immersive atmosphere. The space station is meticulously designed, showcasing intricate details and a sense of realism that truly brings the environment to life. From the flickering lights and ominous shadows to the eerie echoes of your own footsteps, every corner of the station is filled with tension and suspense. The developers did an excellent job of creating a sense of isolation and constant unease, making me constantly on edge throughout my playthrough.

The gameplay in Prey is a delightful blend of action, exploration, and problem-solving. The game offers a wide range of abilities and tools that allow for diverse playstyles. Whether you prefer a stealthy approach, using your powers to become a ghost-like figure, or a more aggressive playstyle, relying on powerful weapons to blast through enemies, the choice is yours. I particularly enjoyed the freedom to experiment and find creative solutions to the various challenges presented throughout the game.

The Typhon, the alien antagonists of Prey, are both fascinating and terrifying. Their shapeshifting abilities and relentless pursuit kept me constantly on my toes. The encounters with these creatures are intense and require strategic thinking to overcome. Additionally, the game's narrative is expertly woven into the gameplay, revealing secrets and twists at just the right moments to keep me engaged and eager to uncover the truth.

The level design in Prey is top-notch. The space station is a labyrinth of interconnected areas, each with its own unique challenges and secrets waiting to be discovered. Navigating through the intricate web of corridors, vents, and hidden passages was a joy in itself. The non-linear structure of the game encourages exploration and rewards players with hidden treasures, upgrades, and valuable resources. It truly feels like an open playground, allowing you to approach objectives in your own way.

Graphically, Prey is stunning. The attention to detail in the environment, character models, and special effects is impressive. The lighting and sound design further enhance the immersive experience, effectively building tension and creating an atmosphere that kept me fully engrossed in the game world.

I must also commend Prey for its thought-provoking narrative. The game delves into themes such as identity, morality, and the nature of consciousness, adding depth and complexity to the overall experience. The story unfolds in a non-linear fashion, with multiple paths and choices that directly impact the outcome. This element of player agency adds an extra layer of replayability and makes each playthrough feel unique.

In conclusion, Prey is a masterpiece of science fiction gaming. Its immersive atmosphere, engaging gameplay, and thought-provoking narrative come together to create an unforgettable experience. If you're a fan of gripping storytelling, thrilling gameplay, and a touch of the unknown, Prey is an absolute must-play. Brace yourself for an adventure that will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish.

140968083.review:
"Prey" is an interesting game with flaws that become obvious as time passes.

You choose your character's gender. You wake up. You put on your suit. You get in the helicopter on the roof. You meet your brother in the laboratory. You take some tests. Something goes wrong.
I don't fully understand the term "immersive sim", so I describe "Prey" as an action game at its core that can be approached in multiple ways, altering how the in-game world will react to you. Your path might have guns, stealth, or space magic.
The game has a lot of fun systems: GLOO cannons can disable an enemy or bypass it by forming a climbable path; Q-Beams can disintegrate anyone with enough particles; mimics can turn into any object in sight, so get ready for ambushes; the physics allow the player to experiment in unexpected ways… The list goes on and on, trust me.
The game doesn't have a great variety of enemies, mostly spreading between fire/electric/enhanced variants. Fighting mechanics might be engaging for 2/3 of the game, but it gets a little tedious by the end. And in general, you will have to traverse a lot in the second half of the game. However, the most annoying thing is the never-ending necessity of clearing your inventory from junk in order to produce useful resources; it helps that "Prey" has pleasantly fast controls and some perks to skip a trip to a recycler, but it just feels like a waste of time.
Despite some abstractness of in-game models, the game occasionally suffers from framedrops in dense segments. Still, "Prey" shines in its presentation, both in dynamic situations and still moments. You have to see it.
You will need to make some decisions that can impact the story, but it could've been more significant. Still, multiple playthroughs can add to the experience.

This game is cool, intriguing, innovative… and a little too much to spoil the impression. The DLC fixes some of the issues I have with the game, so feel free to check it out as well.

140779146.review:
An amazing FPS in a Sci-Fi, somewhat alternative history setting. In most aspects a game that is really good, even after a few years holds up really well.

Overall I would give it a 9/10 - really good, I enjoyed it a lot. Feels like the game is somewhat underrated (or just wasn't marketed enough?) in my opinion. I recommend it to most people. And here are my thoughts:

Story and lore are well made and presented. There's lots of side content that will influence your journey. You'll probably see things from different perspectives as they're revealed to you.
Even though personally I believe that combat is the weakest point of Prey, it's still pretty decent. Regular melee just feels very clunky. Eventually you will make your own way to fight (or avoid doing so as much as you can) - most ways to play are valid, but i would avoid melee. There's a large variance of weapons and utilities that specialise in doing certain things. The combat abilites seems to mostly do the same thing (but are pretty good at it).
What this game does best is give you a lot of freedom - freedom to choose YOUR playstyle, freedom to make YOUR version of the story, freedom to choose things that aren't just *Dialog option A* and *Dialog option B* which feels pretty refreshing, also gives you multiple reasons to replay the game - if you're into that kind of thing.
Exploration is rewarded and certain skills or creativity let you get into many places (most have more than 1 way in) that you wouldn't otherwise see (hence the perspectives).
Level design seems really good to me. It feels like workstations are used and places are lived in with details that make you think about characters or locations in a certain way.
Enemy design is interesting - with some enemies being pretty similar to things we know and others being very otherworldly.

140685605.review:
I enjoyed Prey, but it is a game that goes on for way too long. At first I was utterly smitten with its systems and world and that enchantment carried me for a solid 10 hours. After that, I started becoming tired of it. The luster was beginning to fade. By the time I hit 20 hours, I was ready to be done with the game. And yet it keeps going for quite a while longer. My first playthrough of Dishonored shaped up to be significantly shorter by a full 1/3rd and it was a clean hands/ghost/shadow playthrough. And the level/world design supported it being that long. That just isn't the case with Prey. And with Dishonored, I was ready to jump right back in to do a bloody playthrough. I was -done- with Prey when I finished it.

The abilities you have access to, while neat, don't feel as cohesive as Dishonored's did. And the levels just aren't as interesting as Dishonored's is either. Don't get me wrong. They're not bad, but they also do not approach the heights that Dishonored did. I will say that the story is generally more interesting than Dishonored's even if the world itself isn't as compelling.

It's definitely a good game, but not the best that Arkane has made.

140558657.review:
A very solid sci-fi horror action game.
Gameplay-wise it strongly resembles Bioshock as you find and get to choose your own upgrades and have more or less a moral system to choose your personal path and how you handle the people around you.

What surprised me was the focus on exploration rather than combat. There are a lot of moments where you would expect to be confronted with a horde of enemies or to be ambushed by something and it just doesn't happen.
I would estimate around 80:20 exploration to combat ratio. It's really not the primary focus of the game.

I only have two complaints.

The first one is the enemy variety; basically every enemy you encounter is a variation of a black writhing mass in either spider, humanoid or machine form.
Yes, that's just how the enemies look, but there could have be more.

The other complaint is that it doesn't matter what ending you choose. You have a variety of options, but everything leads to the same conclusion.

All in all very decent - 7.5/10.

140509204.review:
Prey harnesses the power of silence to strike fear, tension and suspense into every drop of its 20 hour runtime. 

Every game utilises downtime. If you take a traditional RPG, downtime might be spent bartering with local merchants, conversating with NPCs, crafting items and reading tales of lusty Argonian maids. However, downtime is just as important in deeply action orientated games. Take Half-Life 2 for example, once you finish a combat sequence, you’ll typically have to solve a puzzle – a formula which trends further back than DOOM 1 where you’d backtrack to unlock previously closed doors using keycards. For all the explosions, breakneck pace and actions set pieces you can fill in a game, you need effective and satisfying downtime.

This is one area where Prey truly excels. The hum of small, complex machinery whirs in the background, contrasted by the deep and heavy pulls of a ship – the Talos I – spinning slowly and aimlessly through space. Perusing Audio Director Matthew Piersall’s CV, I notice Metroid Prime 3: Corruption and it all begins to make sense now.

The lack of any earthly sounds creates a cold and unfamiliar soundscape. Nothing sounds familiar, and having your memory wiped at the beginning of the game, it isn’t meant to be either. Everything feels new and it can be difficult to read what the game throws at you. Even Prey’s legendary intro is based upon taking a familiar, upbeat scenario of a first day of work and flips it into something broken and distorted. 

Prey’s main enemy is the mimic: an alien which can take the shape of objects within the environment, before springing into life to attack the character. On the one hand, this creates beautifully tense gameplay where nothing is as it seems, and the player must be attuned to every small twitch in the room. Was the vase over there, [i] always there? [/i] One excellent moment see’s you discover an abandoned lab and trace the footsteps of its previous occupants, who have put sticky notes on every piece of equipment that which are definitively not mimics. On the other hand, it’s also absolute bull****. Difficulty feels artificial as concealed mimics lead to cheap deaths throughout, especially on the harder difficulties. It’s an area that, while a defining theme of Prey, feels like a small but significance sacrifice of gameplay for narrative tension.

It's a hell of a lot of fun the other way around though. As you progress through Prey, you’ll acquire ‘Neuromods’ which let you use the mimic ability. This instantly creates a vast, diverging pathway of options when exploring the Talos I. For example, one section featured a locked door with no keycard in sight. My hacking skill certainly wasn’t high enough to break the lock either, and so I backtracked and found a science textbook laying on a table. From there, I threw the book above the room I was trying to access, leapt above and briefly morphed into the book, slipping through a very slight crack in the ventilation and into the room, before returning to my human self. This moment was absolutely thrilling and represents what makes Immersive Sims the incredible genre they are.

I did stumble across a few technical difficulties however, likely due to the game’s immense amount of interlocking mechanics throttling my CPU. Stutters were frustratingly common until I figured out a goldilocks combination of in-game and Nvidia control panel settings. From there, it was smooth sailing but did factor to a month-long period break from the game.

All in all, Prey represents Arkane Studio’s magnum opus and stands as a superb call back to the likes of System Shock 2 and Bioshock. The dramatic tension grips you from the moment you begin and never fails to let go, yet a succinct 20 hour runtime prevents significant player fatigue. Buy Prey, or at least tweet the audio director telling him he done a great job.

140473685.review:
Prey is an absolute masterpiece. The story and lore are incredibly interesting and offer a lot to think about, so much so that I can't get it out of my mind. From the gameplay side, the amount of freedom the game gives you to make choices is greater than any other game I've played by far, and it feels so good to for once play a game that respects your creativity this much. To me, those are the strongest aspects the game has to offer.

The game expects a careful and cunning approach from the player, particularly in the part of the game when you're still underpowered. I very much enjoy this, but for some it may feel tedious and overly punishing. Still, personally I count this as a total plus because I look for games that can challenge me like that. You can adjust the difficulty at any time anyway, if needed. But as you progress and toward the end of the game, you can become an absolute monster and rip through the enemies that dominated you in the early game, which is just so satisfying. The combat abilities available to you become quite varied too, and it's very fun to play around with different strategies.

All that said, I will acknowledge two of the criticisms that felt most salient to me here, first of which is the enemy design. There isn't a ton of enemy variety for the most part, and the majority of enemies you come across are variants of two basic designs (one of which is iconic and amazing, and the other of which is closer to just being serviceable). There are a handful more enemy types, but they are much less common. This doesn't bother me personally and I like all the enemy types, but some people have found it repetitive, which is understandable. I think if you're invested in the other aspects of the game like I was, this won't impact your experience negatively.

The second criticism has to do with the materials and crafting system of the game. Throughout the game, you can find junk items littered around which exist solely to be recycled and repurposed as raw materials for crafting things like ammunition. Some have said that the process of collecting trash and recycling it is too tedious because you need to collect a lot of it to accrue any substantial amount of material, and this plays into an inventory space issue. This also doesn't bother me too much personally because I really enjoy item collecting, but it's a very fair complaint for those who do not, or who dislike inventory management.

Overall though, Prey is a fantastic game with few flaws, and it has been criminally underappreciated. It deserves to be seen by more people and to be played through unspoiled. If you love science fiction, cosmic horror, and/or immersive sims, do yourself a favor and play it.

140458105.review: I've owned this game since the year it came out and only just played it now. Huge mistake. One of my favorite AAA games of the last 5 - 10 years. Great atmosphere, rock solid game play, graphics still hold up well(Max settings, 4k) engaging story, lots and lots of lore to go through if you are interested, great exploration, I could go on and on. If Prey is your first immersive sim like it was mine, ask yourself: Does having freedom and a plethora of ways to solve problems interest you? For example, lets say you come across a locked door. You could find the pass code for it, or you could hack it if your hacking skill is high enough, or there might be a maintenance tunnel you could find to get in(and sometimes the maintenance tunnel is blocked and there are multiple ways to deal with that), or you might be able to shoot the unlock button on the inside with a toy gun, or if you have a certain power, you could turn into a coffee cup and get through a small opening. That's Prey. By the way, this also applies to combat. On the outside prey is a run-of-the-mill FPS, but it's so much more then that. You can kill your enemies with conventional weapons, or you could throw gas canisters at them(you can throw them more accurately or farther based on a certain skill) or maybe you found some portable turrets and you set them up to kill your enemies. Maybe you came across some broken turrets? If you invested in repair, you can repair them and then use them to kill enemies. If you maxed repair, you can fortify them to double their HP which makes them much better at taking out the more tougher enemies. Came across some enemies robots? you could sneak up and hack into them and have them fight for you. This game is really engaging because usually when I come across something like a locked door in a game I think "Okay I'm supposed to find the key or something later and comeback" but in Prey I immediately start examining my options. I can't recommend Prey enough.

Kept putting Prey off until recently (as I'm sure many of you reading have too) and I'm genuinely sorry I did. Prey is now one of my favourite games of all time (since the PS1), I have never played a game where you find yourself so immersed in the story with the phenomenal voice cast and world building.

I normally play games on max difficulty but ended up playing easy in my first playthrough after getting my arse kicked (!) so you'll never find yourself bored as the increasing difficulties truly challenge you to think outside the box and be creative (something I don't often feel in games).

As cheesy as it sounds Prey is the kind of game that gives you a whole new perspective on life and I'm never getting Alex Yu's voice (portrayed by the incredible Benedict Wong) out of my head now. The music and sound design sends shivers down my spine and really captures the atmosphere the world creates. I feel as though I've lived in the stunning and beautiful place that is Talos I and I'll be coming back for more as soon as I can (as well as the equally engaging and even more replayable Mooncrash DLC). 

If you haven't already you really should give it a go and at least see the intro sequence for yourself if you can. I can only describe the experience as closer to playable immersive art than a classic video game and huge props to the Devs for such a work. Truly time to shake things up if you haven't already!

This was a game alright. Holy, a lot to unpack. I'll avoid going too deep in this one because it's a rabbit hole. I love the setting of the game, it's basically a bioshock meets Dishonored kind of thing but more the former. I love how this game plays, all the approaches you can have to a situation. Locked Door? You wanna slip through this small crack? Force it Open with your strength? Traverse through the roofing and into a maintence hatch? Hack the electronics? Hey, that keypad there? Yeah, the code is actually on the computer in this employees email. Need to find them? Look up the location with their wristband tracker.  I was constantly finding more and more hidden things, new ways to solve every situation I was in. There is so much lore built into the game through nuance. The place feels lived and every NPC has a story. I got really invested in the DnD game a few of the players were in. Upon learning more and more of their emails the DM revealed treasure maps that by acquiring all of them gave me a blueprint for a pretty strong chip for my suit. You are rewarded for your exploration. Combat wasn't always required, which is good because it's hard. Took so much of my valuable resources to fight normal enemies, and that only multiplied as I went deeper into the game. The maps are intricate, layered. Detailed. Beautiful looking. And it only evolves the more you play and get further into the game. There isn't a fast travel in the traditional sense. The map itself isn't gigantic, but it can feel like it is at times with how much you can explore. You can exit the space station and use your suit to travel between docking points of the various areas. The story was awesome, it starts off so tame and slowly spirals into a grander puzzle that doesn't make any sense until the ending. The biggest complaint I had was really poor performance, fps was dropping all over the place and then the micro stutters, but with that out of the way, there is a more than good game here.
This is an easy 8/10 
It would be a 9/10 if the performance was smooth. but it's a bethesda game T.T
This game is a great buy when it's on sale and even a solid buy at it's current full price

139831199.review:
TLDR: Excellently-built survival horror that I think most players will either love or hate.

Unrelated to the 2006 game of the same name, Prey puts the player in the role of Morgan Yu, one of the two executives of the TranStar corporation in charge of a space station. As one might expect, something goes horribly wrong.

The set-up of this game will be familiar to anyone who has played space survival horror. Indeed, the DNA of games like System Shock is all over this one. As alien forms infest the station and more and more is revealed to a mind-wiped Morgan, the player must gather resources and evade or kill their foes while trying to decipher what's happening.

Player controls are pretty standard, though I found the jumping controls a little less responsive than many similar games. Part of the game will see the player in zero-g gravity and having to control themselves with thrusters, where momentum continues movement after letting up the keys. That was a neat change-up and added its own challenges. There are several skill trees with multiple skills, with standbys such as weapons proficiency, hacking, repair, stealth, increased health, and a variety of  boosts that will feel familiar to anyone who has played a game like this. Weapons are a mix of standard and boring, and interesting, like the GLOO gun, which fires blobs of rapidly-hardening polymer. It can be used to block doorways, immobilize enemies, secure sparking electrical connections, or to create makeshift staircases on walls to reach inaccessible areas. I love multi-concept weapons like this.

Skills also include powers derived from the alien Typhon organisms. There are chipsets for the player's suit and helmet, which give additional benefits, and more slots can be unlocked through gameplay. There seem to be multiple viable skill builds for whatever playstyle the player wants, and that's a plus. Skills are added via neural implants (neuromods) injected right into the eye and the brief animation the first time this happens made me wince.

In fact, the entire narrative framework in this game is quite good. The opening and first few story beats, before the player really embarks on their "main" journey were very tense and, to me, the best parts of the tale.

I will also say the environments in Prey are gorgeous and rendered well. Talos Station feels like a space station should, with different areas devoted to crew quarters, life support, engineering, storage, research, etc. The levels are varied in design, if not necessarily in appearance, and all feel very organic and flow together well. As the Typhon slowly assume control of the station, filaments of their psychic energy end up strewn around the staion like glowing party streamers. I also thought the sound design was excellent. The Typhon sounds are distinctive and distance from the enemy can be easily gauged by sound volume alone. Other characters radio the player, audio logs can be gathered around the station, and in general, the voice acting is very well done.

Players will quickly encounter the Typhon enemies and they are no slouches. Superficially, the enemies are varied and weird, starting with the crab-like mimics, who copy objects in the environment and hide in plain sight before leaping to the attack ... to the ghost-like phantoms, corrupted robots, giant telepathic blobs, and the nightmare, a swirling ball of evil specifically summoned to attack Morgan.

Appearances aside, however, most of the enemies are pretty blah. Until the player upgrades weapons and skills, even the lowest level mobs are all bullet sponges, and all hit really hard (even on easier difficulty modes, the highest level ones will drop you in a few attacks). None of them act that bright; they see the player and attack, even when you're unloading rounds into them. The one type that flees when under attack usually runs around a corner, lets its shield regenerate, and then returns to life as normal. There are enemies that are cheap, including invisible ones that can literally kill you by just psychically throwing you into the ceiling--doing so in one occasion from across an electrified floor you can't cross. Minor spoiler: at one point late in the game, the player will have to deal with a lot of rapidly (and endless) spawning enemies. The spawn points can be blocked and the enemies defeated but it didn't make sense in context (as in, if the story was logical, it should have happened much earlier) and it was an annoying mechanic that just served to slow down the story at a point where it was accelerating to the finish. A lot of fights can be snuck past, either via stealth or alternate pathing, but certainly not all, and some difficult ones were just unavoidable. It all just felt ... low-effort. I didn't find the combat impossible but it was annoying and always present.

Aside from the main story, there are other quests and requests from surviving crew members and while some offered tangible rewards, I found many kind of useless at such a late point. To advance the story, one needs to make a full circuit of Talos station, during which many of these quests will rack up, and unless the player backtracks a lot, these side requests will not be filled until the latter stages of the game--again, when the story is picking up speed toward conclusion. I get it, it's not an RPG and not a quest game, but I really prefer to have my optional content spread more evenly over the game and easy movement around the station (to not spend a long time retracing your route) doesn't come until late in the game.

In terms of stability, it was pretty good, though I crashed to desktop on almost every exit, rather than shutting down cleanly. I did have a few instances with the game simply going into a fugue state when loading a new zone, and refusing to respond. Aside from that, I also had a few odd bugs, such as objects staying suspended in air when the object beneath them was moved. It's an acceptable level of buginess, but there were a few.

Steam achievements will take a while, since it requires multiple runs through the game. As with most games like this, players who love it won't see that as daunting ... but overall, this isn't a game to buff up your completion percentage (if that matters to you).

My personal enjoyment in Prey was middling; I logged a total of thirty hours but in the end, just kind of shrugged. Some games get better or develop new aspects with time but this isn't one of them, as I enjoyed the first half more than the second. Having said that, I agree that overall, Prey is an excellently-constructed game, with a lot going for it. I think it is going to hit the sweet spot for many players. Even if it wasn't for me, I recommend players give it a try, especially anyone who likes survival horror games. 

Pros:
- Multiple avenues to success, both in approach and in character builds
- Excellent story, graphics, and sound

Cons:
- Combat was more annoying than difficult
- Side quest progression delayed to late game


Final Score: 6.5/10

139511383.review:
Prey's story and characters are interesting enough, and the gameplay is good for the most part. More than that though, it's the atmosphere which I find to be Prey's strongest aspect. However, I sadly had to lean a bit more towards giving it a negative review.

In terms of enemy design, the Typhon all look and sound the same to me. They all just blend together into the same black wobbly blobs with tendrils. Some enemies are basically even carbon copies of another, just with a different ability duct-taped to them. The Phantom's 4 versions are prime examples of this. As a side note, character designs (the humans) frankly also look quite unappealing. To be blunt, this all comes across as a bit boring and unimaginative to me.

In terms of balance, most Typhon are so overtuned it's not even funny. I get that Prey isn't your typical 'guns blazing' type of FPS, but that doesn't excuse the enemies from being [i]this[/i] obnoxious to fight. From teleporting/dashing all over the place, to being really tanky, to attacks that chunk your Health in an instant, to abilities that can nearly stun-lock you, and more. The iconic 'Mimic' ability is one of only a few abilities that I think is interesting, which admittedly does give Prey a uniquely creepy/fun aspect to it.

It's also mandatory to scour the map for trash to feed the crafting cycle, seeing as items and ammo can be rather scarce otherwise. Now I personally don't mind that too much since I'm a big looter, but I can imagine that this can be quite annoying for others. Finally, constantly respawning enemies are also a big frustration. A once-cleared area can just repopulate with enemies again upon hitting certain story points, undoing a lot of your efforts and feelings of accomplishment there.

As a side note: some bugs also happened during my playthrough, mostly consisting of weird corpse spawning, and the behavior of both fire and off-screen enemies, but luckily nothing too gamebreaking.

If you're a fan of immersive sim games, Arkane Studios, or just like a good Sci-Fi game, I'd recommend Prey to you, it won't let you down.

No, this is not related to the Aboriginal American Prey. Yes, that was an amazing game. No, that does not make this game any less fun.

However, this game [i]is[/i] fucking EVIL.

You can pick up and move environmental objects such as chairs and cabinets. You also have a Grenade which deconstructs environmental objects and turns them into crafting materials. IT IS TOO EASY, AND TOO SATISFYING, TO PILE UP EVERYTHING IN A MAP SECTION AND TRY TO DELETE IT WITH A SINGLE GRENADE.

Say goodbye to your free time.

A genuinely fun game. You kind of [i]can[/i] do things in whatever order you like, but of course there are some things you need to do to progress in certain ways, so I suspect that most people complete certain objectives i the same order.

Crafting is pretty good. The crafting materials are divided in such a way that collecting and carrying them is very simple and easy. I do like games with specific components that work together in overwhelmingly varied recipe variants, but this system works well for this game.

My only complaint is the Audio balancing. Some speech playback is much louder than others, so it can be tricky to find a good balance where nothing is too loud, but where you can still hear everything clearly. I recommend subtitles if you like to experience every drop of story/lore/etc in a game.

I recommend the hardest difficulty. You don't get anything for it, but it encourages you to use more of the game's potential. Turrets, Grenades, and environmental dangers can be a lot of fun to use against enemies in a clever way, but if I were on an easier difficulty I would probably just mindlessly fire death at my crosshair room after room, rarely needing to use even a medkit.

139051478.review:
Hard to believe it took me this long to finally review this great game.  It's a lot of fun.  Made by the same people that made Dishonored.  The visuals are impressive, especially if you like outer space, or sci-fi settings.  The story was well thought-out.  Like, it's very difficult to predict the ending, even if you do pay attention to all the little things throughout the game.  Not to mention there's more than one way to complete the game and more than one outcome.

There are several weapons and usable offensive items.  All weapons can be upgrade multiple times.  Your character uses "neuromods" in order to learn various new abilities, either present from the start, or unlocked later on.  Depending on what difficulty settings are used, there are different forms of "trauma" the player can experience, such as broken bones, concussions, etc., all of which negatively affect your character until addressed.

There's an inventory system similar to the Deus Ex style.  You have slots for items, weapons, ammo, consumables and junk that can be recycled for materials, which are then used to fabricate useful stuff, or even plot-specific items.

All of this made for a very fun game.  An achievement hunt is not stupidly difficult, like in a lot of games, but does still indeed challenge the player.

If you liked Dishonored, you'll like this.  For those who haven't (yet) played Dishonored, if you'd be interested in a first-person sci-fi action adventure, you'll definitely enjoy this.

138964525.review:
I know everyone is bombing Arkane for Redfall, but this game is one of the best games I have ever played. Prey is a gem of the immersive sim genre and I am really sad that I haven't played it until now. 

The story is simple but engaging. You're Morgan Yu, scientist in a space station called Talos I. After a terrible accident, all hell breaks loose in the station and you're left to a) figure out what happened and b) escape the station. The characters are a bit flat, but the quests you are actually engaging with them are top-tier. As in all immersive sims, I found a contradiction between the main story that focuses on me and the side missions that focuses on the world. Talos I is an incredible place with lots of opportunities to discover.

The gameplay is like other immersive sims, most notably Deus Ex. You have the skill trees, the upgrades and the different weapons that can and will make you approach each situation differently and challenge you to find the most suitable solution to the problems. The mimics are brilliant and they will keep you on your toes but other enemies are just engage or avoid, without further thinking.

Prey is the game, I would like to make. A variety of tools, clever situations, and a world/space station that feels immersive and is there to explore and exploit. The micro-stories that are woven in the side quests, the little hints that are given as clues to solutions, make this game a truly remarkable one. 

I don't know if Arkane deserves hate for Redfall, but it certainly deserves praise for Prey.

This game is AWESOME! Well made, I enjoy the story, the gameplay, the combat... then why the negative review?

I am almost 20 hours into the game (lots of offline game time) and have encountered a game ending glitch. In the mission Reboot I have to get a key off of a corpse. Easy enough, the corpse is on fire. Shoot it with the GLOO gun and put out the flames. Doing so however clips the corpse through the floor, making it completely inaccessible. I only learned that I needed the body about 30-45 minutes afterwards while looking up a guide. The auto save function saves about every 3 minutes... My previous manual save was 3 hours prior...

I looked up workarounds, even cheats. Nothing. The only thing I came across were other people who had the same game ending glitch stuck where I was. Turns out there are dozens of game ending glitches like this all over the game. The Devs blocked out all forms of cheating. No cheat codes, no console commands. Even the CryEngine remote terminal doesn't work! People have reached out to the Devs on multiple occasions and their only advice is "load a previous save or restart the game". 

That is simply unacceptable and I hate to review this negatively, but, here we are. My 20 hour adventure forever incomplete... I needed the storage space anyway...

138648556.review:
Me resulta difícil imaginar algo que me haga sentir más minúsculo que mirar al cielo estando en algún lugar alejado de las luces artificiales y del ruido de los motores. Hasta cierto punto me relaja ver que no soy nada. La relatividad más pura es que nuestra existencia no supone ni supondrá nada que haga cambiar el proceso de esto en lo que demonios vivimos, tiempo, espacio o lo que sea. La relatividad de no ser nada a veces tranquiliza y te hacer verlo todo desde la perspectiva más aséptica. Sin embargo, los humanos como especie nos hemos afanado en creer que lo que hacemos tiene significación, tanto lo individual como lo colectivo, hasta el punto de olvidarnos de la inmensidad que nos rodea que creemos intuir pero que nos abruma de tal forma que preferimos ignorarla, tomar su belleza exterior como las galaxias o las nebulosas, y quedarnos en esas simples luces que brillan, o brillaron, ahí arriba.

Basándonos en las apreciaciones que nosotros hacemos de nosotros mismos, llegamos a considerarnos una especie "viva" inteligente, argumentando para ello la capacidad de modificación del entorno, de fabricación de herramientas y de búsqueda de respuestas. Nuestro egocentrismo individual y grupal es tan abrumador que nos consideramos por encima de otras especies del planeta no mecanizadoras y las miramos con superioridad, y en el mejor de los casos, con condescendencia. Sin embargo estamos completamente perdidos a la hora de entender lo que estamos viviendo, limitándonos a modificar nuestra realidad con obstinación y, normalmente, sin prestar demasiada importancia a las consecuencias de nuestras acciones. Hacer y, si cabe, luego intentar parchear. Es la historia del ser humano, autoconsiderado inteligente, aún no certificado externamente por alguna otra especie "inteligente", ah vale, es verdad, que nosotros somos los que damos el carnet de inteligente.

Fruto de la inteligencia humana está el haber otorgado a las corporaciones privadas la capacidad de explo(t/r)ar el espacio: uso, disfrute y beneficio. Y ahí tenemos a "filántropos" de sí mismos lanzando coches eléctricos al espacio, y aquí abajo aplaudiendo. De eso va "Prey" precisamente, de decisiones que se toman basadas en alegatos al "bien común", al "progreso de la ciencia" y que no son más que temeridades que se hacen sin pensar en las verdaderas consecuencias, solo pensando en el rédito económico y el reconocimiento público. Pasear por la Talos y escuchar los audios de los tripulantes es tan adictivo como inquietante, sobre todo al principio, consiguiendo rodearte de una atmósfera opresiva y cargada de peligros. Casi cincuenta horas después puedo decir que recorrerme la base espacial de arriba a abajo varias veces ha sido de las experiencias más terribles que he tenido en videojuegos, sobre todo por la escasez de munición y lo complejo que es, al principio, entender cómo acabar con cada alienígena que sale a tu paso. Hace media hora ví el final, o los finales, porque los probé todos. El primero fue el que más me satisfizo, no porque empatice con los hermanos Yu. Para nada. Más bien porque creía que era lo correcto. Otra vez. ¿Qué es lo correcto? ¿Existe realmente como algo absoluto? Otra vez los humanos con nuestra moralidad, nuestros conceptos, nuestros principios, los cuales llevan con nosotros miles de años para precisamente saltárnoslos a diario. Digamos que, en términos relativos, hice lo que me generó más confort. Supongo que es lo que hacemos continuamente y, por eso, me cuesta entender que seamos inteligentes, tomando la inteligencia como algo un poco menos relativo. No somos inteligentes porque tomamos decisiones (incluso a nivel científico) basadas en suposiciones, teorías, ideas, recuerdos, fantasías...

Podríamos seguir así infinitamente, hasta que nos hayamos separado tanto de Andrómeda M31 que ya no haya apenas estrellas en el cielo visibles, dentro de miles de millones de millones de años. El ser humano no habrá sido para el Universo ni lo que dura una inspiración en la vida de una persona de 100 años. Quizá existamos simplemente para maravillarnos y admirar lo que parece esta inmensidad que nos rodea, para cuidar del planeta donde surgimos y de las criaturas que lo habitan. Quizá nuestro desempeño debería ser solo ese y no aspirar a ir más allá, continuamente. Pero no somos capaces de ver que mientras no seamos capaces de manejar con soltura los problemas planetarios domésticos no estaremos preparados para dar el salto a ningún otro lado. La Talos es el ejemplo de que nuestra existencia no deja de ser algo ridículo y anecdótico, incluso en la historia natural de nuestro pequeño planeta no somos nada. Sentarnos y observar el cielo, eso sería más útil para entender lo que somos y lo que, afortunadamente, nunca jamás seremos, conseguiremos ni entenderemos. Es duro asumirlo pero en el medio de la noche despertarse, mirar hacia la ventana y darse cuenta de que todo esto es un minúsculo microinstante de algo que es imposible que lleguemos a entender, es de las cosas más maravillosas y gratificantes que uno puede vivir. No somos nada, afortunadamente, y la familia Yu todavía menos.

138463870.review:
No plot spoilers

Good:
- Shock-like, with a satisfying gameplay loop and plenty to do.
- A good chunk of it is non-linear, giving you a lot of options to achieve your goals, with quite a few things to do in your own order.
- Plenty to explore early on.
- A really cool opening.
- Challenging, at least until you learn the ins and outs of the game and upgrade your character.
- Really cool use of geometry and physical mechanics.
- Great voice acting and at least a few characters you grow to like or hate. Benedict Wong kicks ass.
- Visually clean (after tweaks) and usually stylized in a pleasing way.
- Long, giving you plenty of bang for your buck.
- Full of memorable moments.
- Performance seemed good, but my computer is ridiculous, so YMMV.
- What little music there seemed to be was decent.
- Recycler charges are super satisfying.
- The enemies are really interesting, though the variety often feels lacking.

- SPACE!

Bad:
- * The game looks like a muddy mess until you tweak it. Disable motion blur and add Reshade for sharpening to correct this. Once you do, the game is exceptionally clean, with no aliasing. It's not the most graphically impressive game out there, but it looks good. It just requires some work to get there.
- The most baffling thing... they decided to put the default crosshair on the lower portion of the screen, rather than centered. You know, like every first person game ever made? This can also be corrected, but gun models will still point at the lower screen. Once you learn to ignore it, you're golden, but seriously, how do you mess this up???
- The game suffers from a mid-late lull, as a lot of games with non-linear objectives do. If you care about side quests, you are going to backtrack a lot, and you will get to a point in the game where you spend hours doing this.
- The difficulty can seem unfair until you get used to the game and learn what you should and should not be fighting at your current level of progression.
- The endings feel rushed. I won't spoil anything, but they aren't very satisfying. Separately from that, the after credits scene may be divisive. It didn't make me feel much, but some people may find it cool.
- As with most games that offer this level of customization depth, you can trivialize most of the game with the right unlocks.
- While some of the environments are unique, a lot of them get samey. There is a lot less visual appeal and unique design than something like a BioShock. It's a space station with more subtle art deco design, with a few cool interior sets. The exterior is really cool though.
- There are a few sections where you spend a bit too much time in zero G. The 6DOF movement is cool, but it gets cumbersome after a while.
- Zero oxygen environments put you in a helmet that can be a bit obstructive at times.
- The feeling of the opening of the game is never quite matched later on. To compare it to BioShock again, imagine if the Andrew Ryan office scene was the start of the game, then there was nothing quite as impactful for the remainder.
- Weapon variety is limited. Only two standard firearms, a couple of utility weapons, a wrench, and a beam weapon I found less than useful.
- Grenade weapons vary from next to useless to vital, depending on how you're playing. Overall, I find them lacking.
- Recycler charges should yield more materials for large objects.

138366882.review:
I tried this game and bounced an hour in twice. I recently thought that I should try it again to see what people were always talking about, and man am I glad that I did. Maybe the worst thing about Prey is that they hit you with a banger of an opening followed by a steep drop. The pace slows significantly, your character is very weak and limited, and it doesn't show you many of the things that make it great right away. It's absolutely worth getting through that dip to get to the meat of the experience. 

I've been a big fan of Dishonored, and I think Prey might rival both of those games for me. The story, world, and atmosphere are all fantastic. I expected it to have surprises, and it still managed to surpass that. It's tense, unnerving, and mysterious in all the ways I could ask for. There were puzzles I could only see one way to solve until I looked online and saw two other ways that gave me the light bulb moment. 

After the downward trend of Deathloop into Redfall, I really hope that Arkane can channel the magic that went into Dishonored and Prey again. There's way too much brilliance in that studio for them to ebb away into mediocrity.

138349150.review:
Prey is a proper Immersive Sim through and through. Think of a mashup of games like Half Life, Deus Ex, Bioshock, and System Shock, and you get this banger of a game with well thought out level design, great RPG mechanics, fun abilities, unique weapons and items, a semi-obscure and intriguing Sci-Fi plot on an alien space station, and an amazing synthwave/horror themed soundtrack not only from the mad lad himself, Mick Gordon. It's definitely worth buying, and the DLC is worth it too!

I've never been too keen on Arkane Studios other game series (Dishonored), but I have to say Prey is something special and probably the best game they've done thus far imo, one of the best games to come out in the 2010s decade. Prey is a proper immersive sim through and through, having a big area-zone for you to take on any way you see fit with a multitude of weapons and items to get through areas, multiple ways to complete quests, save all NPCs, kill all NPCs, multiple endings, and finishing the game early.

You approach a locked, coded door that may have you stumped at first, but then you realise Prey has more than one answer for your problems, giving you a handful of solutions for your obstacles. How about using the glue gun to climb up the wall and jump over it? or climb into the vents Deus Ex style,or hack all the computers to find the code for the door. Or even better, use one of the multiple alien powers to mimic a coffee cup and slide through the gap in the window to get through the locked room. Prey truly feels like a 90s game that escaped and silently showed up in 2017 right under the radar. It's already becoming a cult classic game, not leaving much of an impression sales wise or with mainstream appeal; sadly, that's the nature of games like this and Deus Ex. It's a shame that the sales were pretty bad for Bethesda standards; the possibility of a sequel may be nonexistent, but damn, was this an amazing entry to the immersive sim genre.

138134731.review:
Possibly one of my favourite games ever. I'm glad I played this game blind. Such amazing level design, interesting storytelling, with a twist at the end that the game had been foreshadowing right from the beginning. Possibly my favourite thing about this game that I haven't seen any other game achieve is that every single thing in how you navigate and get into parts of the station and deal with enemies really makes you feel like it was your own idea. Whether it's by simply having the correct hacking level, or finding the keycard, or looking for an alternative route, or making an interesting platforming contraption with your GLOO gun to get beyond it. 

The other thing is that there are only a couple of different endings, but it can end about 19 different ways. Every single little thing you do in this game is reflected on later on, for something you didn't think a game designer would have even thought about. Luckily I got the best ending, but I feel like it was my choice for the games events to turn out the way it did. You don't "pick" the good ending. It is merely the result of all your actions along the way. I really wish Arkane could make a sequel. The only time I bought a game and dumped every night of the week playing it was when I discovered S.T.A.L.K.E.R. I just had to find out what was next.

Whatever you expect this game to be from the photos and trailer is wrong. Do not play it like a shooter, or you'll get your ass handed to you.

138076442.review: Excellent game, definitely one of my favorites overall. Engaging story, interesting characters, good gameplay. If you like immersive sims and sci-fi/horror, this is absolutely for you.

138075078.review:
Prey is an immersive sci-fi FPS with similarities to Bioshock and Control. It's story-heavy with a vast network of characters (mostly deceased) who's agendas and interconnections are revealed as you gather intel and put the pieces together. Progression is mostly linear with a few karma-based choices yielding slightly divergent endings. 

Gameplay mainly takes place inside a space station, but also takes you out from its relative comfort and into the very uncomfortably disorienting experience of navigating between airlocks. Enemies remain threatening until pretty late in the game and are creepy enough to want to generally avoid. This isn't really a horror game, but it definitely has its moments. 

The game uses a somewhat unconventional crafting system where just about every object can be "disassembled" into its elementary components, which are then used to fabricate weapons and upgrades. There are a lot of "junk" items that can thankfully be converted into something immediately useful as well. 

Much of the weapon kit is familiar with heavy resemblance to that of Half-Life 2. The exceptions are a surprisingly reliable stun gun and the GLOO cannon, which functions as both tool and weapon. 

[i]Neuromods[/i] (See: Bioshock's [i]plasmids[/i]) add a great deal to the combat experience giving the character superhuman stat and movement bonuses and unlocking powerful elemental and paranormal abilities.

Great game with little to complain about. Hope to see a sequel in the future.

138074950.review:
I adore this game. It's like if you took Half-Life, Bioshock, & System Shock and a bit of Fallout and blended them all together. The gameplay loop is addictive. There are plenty of little side quests along the way to keep you interested in exploring. The looting and crafting is very unique and interesting in this game. You can recycle loot and items and turn them into 4 base crafting materials, which can then be used to fabricate different items you may need; such as ammo, weapons, upgrade kits, etc. This makes it very rewarding to hunt around for loot. 

The atmosphere and setting are incredible. Replay value is high since there are multiple ways to approach any given obstacle or quest. Different endings based on your actions and decisions also ensure repeat playthroughs. Although I found getting the "good" ending to be much more satisfying than the "bad" ending. Still, it's fun to have the option to play the game as a total monster, killing indiscriminately. 

The human weapons are not very varied, but your Typhon abilities later on makes up for the slight lack of gun variety. I found using a mix of guns and abilities to be a good balance. You do get a cool original weapon/tool that can be used to help in combat, or help you get around the level. However towards the end of the game, if you leveled up your abilities just right, you tend to be a bit too OP. But this is mainly a repeat playthrough issue, as you'll have figured out which upgrades and abilities are best suited for your play style. I recommend playing on Hard or Nightmare for a second or third playthrough to help mitigate this. 

The story is interesting enough to keep you going, with exposition and information delivered via audio logs, hacking into people's computer terminals, finding notes, and running into other survivors, etc. The game also has quite the ending. Not going to spoil anything here, but it threw me for a loop. It certainly makes for interesting repeat playthroughs. 

Some of the enemies will mimic objects, such as coffee mugs, or chairs, and can pop out and attack you and give you quite a scare. This can be suspenseful and frightening at first, but later in the game this is mitigated when you get an item that can actively scan for these hidden creatures, thus reducing the jump scare factor. The observant players will learn how to spot these enemies before they attack. I wouldn't call Prey a "horror" game, but it certainly has a suspenseful and tense atmosphere at times. I absolutely love the setting of the game: a retro-futuristic 1970's styled space station orbiting the Moon in the year 2035 in an alternate timeline. As a space nerd, I absolutely loved being on this station. Some of the views and areas are incredible. 

Overall, I highly recommend Prey if you like atmospheric sci-fi shooters with some extra abilities thrown in, and a dash of suspense. If you enjoyed Bioshock, Half-LIfe, or System Shock, you will enjoy Prey.

138025340.review:
[h1] [i] And now it's time to beat the mind game [/i] [/h1]

Prey is Arkane Studio's magnum opus (How did we get from this to Redfall?).
To put it simply, this game is a cosmic horror story with meticulously designed levels and challenging but enjoyable gameplay.
 This game won't hold you back; it gives you the tools and the playground to be creative. Prey's world design is one of the best out there; there are many many ways to approach a quest, fight an enemy, or simply traverse through areas of the map. The only limit is one's imagination. 

What I like the most about this game is that it encourages thinking outside the box. You should see my face when I discovered that you could open the security station doors with foam darts. 
[b] Prey most definitely deserves the immersive sim title [/b]


I rarely look at a game again after finishing it for the first time, yet this one is different. One run won't do this masterpiece justice.
 It's so sad this game won't receive the attention it deserves.

138017483.review: incredible story. Never played or cared for thriller or horror games, but this one was beautiful

138015677.review:
Prey is a first-person shooter game developed by Arkane Studios and published by Bethesda Softworks. The game takes place in an alternate timeline where history has taken a different turn, leading to the creation of a space station called Talos I, which is infested with hostile aliens known as Typhon. You play as Morgan Yu, a scientist stranded on Talos I who must survive and uncover the mysteries of the station.

The gameplay of Prey is a mix of exploration, puzzle-solving, and combat. The game encourages players to use their creativity and problem-solving skills to overcome obstacles, as there are multiple ways to approach a given situation. The game's atmosphere is immersive, with a detailed and believable world, engaging characters, and a haunting soundtrack.

The combat in Prey is intense and challenging, with a variety of weapons and abilities to choose from. Players can upgrade their character with neuromods, which grant them new skills and powers, such as the ability to mimic objects, move objects with their mind, and even become invisible. The game's difficulty is well-balanced, making it challenging without feeling unfair.

One of the standout features of Prey is its story, which is full of twists and turns. The game's plot explores themes of identity, morality, and the consequences of scientific advancement. The characters are well-developed, with believable motivations and personalities.

The Mooncrash DLC adds a roguelike twist to the game, with randomized levels and permadeath. Players must survive five simulated environments, each with its own unique challenges and hazards. The DLC offers a fresh take on the game's mechanics, encouraging players to experiment with different strategies and playstyles.

Overall, Prey is a fantastic game that offers a unique and immersive experience. Its blend of exploration, puzzle-solving, and combat is executed flawlessly, and its story is engaging and thought-provoking. The Mooncrash DLC adds even more replay value to an already excellent game. If you're a fan of immersive sim games or just looking for something new and different, Prey is definitely worth checking out.

137692295.review:
Surprisingly good immersive sim and spiritual descendent to System Shock. Not very complex, but still an entertaining and engaging game where exploring and returning to parts of the space station with new abilities and more and more door codes or passwords piling up in your inventory to access new rooms feels rewarding. It's also a welcome and okay-ish filler to plug the cavity that's left by the Deus Ex series for me that I should've played way earlier than I did, even though it lingered in my library for almost six years.

A little bit more polish to the presentation of the story would've been nice as it feels a bit rushed at the end and some more levels of complexity like dialogue options or weapon customization (in addition to upgrading the weapons' stats, which you actually can do) wouldn't have hurt either, if you ask me. Psychic abilities, skill tree and weapons/tools are fun. There's an office nerf gun with foam darts to activate buttons you can't reach otherwise and the gloo canon let's you incapacitate enemies, temporarily fix hazards or build platforms to climb high places with. Playing around and experimenting is rewarded, too. 

Despite some lacking depth here and there, it still works perfectly fine and is nicely balanced - maybe a bit too easy in the normal difficulty, especially if the optional survival elements are not enabled. My tip would be to activate oxygen consumption, weapon degredation and traumas if you like some more depth and challenge. 

I'd like a sequel, even more than a continuation of Dishonored or games like the recent one by Arkane Austin. But, that'll probably not happen. Shame.

137689385.review:
Taking nearly 30 hours to beat my first playthrough, I absolutely loved Prey. I think Talos 1 was one of my favorite worlds that I have been in in some time. Space is one of my favorite settings, so being able to transition between inside the ship and outside was one of the best parts of the game. The different areas of the ship all had their cool touches and it didn't feel like I was doing the same thing over and over again. 

All the Typhon and mimic types had me on the edge of my seat going "what the hell is THAT" every time I came across a new one. Every room I walked into I was frantically looking for out of place items and many times the cup or chair I wasn't paying attention to jumped out at me. It takes a lot for a new game to topple the Fallouts, Tomb Raiders, Far Crys, or Metros from my list of favorite games, but Prey did it. Despite taking around 30 hours, I didn't want the game to end because I was having so much fun playing it. Just the sheer amount of different ways to approach each area was amazing. You could sneak past the typhons, you could glue gun a bridge to the catwalks above and walk past, or you could go guns blazing and take them all on. Despite not having that many characters, the ones it did have were great and I kept guessing on what the game would throw at me next. Nothing in the game felt tedious and even the crafting was something I wasn't expecting to be enthralled by. Looking back I honestly can't think of something I didn't enjoy about the game. Maybe the fact that I ended the game with only one human killed(if you played the game, you know who it is), robbing me of the achievement.

Overall Prey is one of my favorite games I've played in the last 5 years and would absolutely love to see more from Arkane in this same vein

137636325.review:
A LONG 1st person collector-survivor type game with a HUGE map. Marked as horror, but if anything, it is probably directed at the player, as your character becomes much scarier as the game progresses (perhaps it was intended as such). 
Use a gargantuan yet fun variety of combat strategies to take down different foes. All strategies can apply to all enemies with enough time, but obviously, some are better than others (like shooting a fire enemy instead of slapping him). 
Every detail in the game is well-thought out, from combat and exploration to the layout and usage of the HUD and inventory menu. Graphics and sounds are both immersive, and the BGM lends a great hand with this.
You can definitely tell that there was actual effort put into the game and game-play. 
 
As stated, your character becomes disgustingly strong as the game progresses, slapping the definition of 'power-creep' across their face as you beat down aliens with only a wrench. This can be taken as a pro or con, depending on your personal play-styles. 
WOW is this game long (if you're doing the side quests). A game guide is highly recommended, as there is a ton of content that is missable if you're only speeding through the main story. This could be tiring for some. 
Traveling in this game is also somewhat annoying, as the map is big and your character runs out of stamina if running for too long. You can spam the boost-jump to circumvent this somewhat. 

Still, highly recommend this game, despite how many individuals view Bethesda. Very easy to just loose yourself in this game for hours on end.

137540445.review:
Prey almost single-handedly restored my faith in gaming.

As I've gotten older, I've started counting the truly great games that are getting released. How many months, years have passed since I had an amazing experience with a game? Prey broke a drought for me.

Fundamentally, it's a well put together imsim. The combat is good, not great. The crafting is good, not great. But there are a few things that make it stand out:
- You are exploring relatively open spaces. There are a lot of tiny nooks and cracks, places you don't need to go but you can in order to get extra resources or to find lore pieces. Having this well done has become extremely rare in gaming.
- The plot is solid, and something that's very rare is that the ending is truly good and recontextualizes the whole game. For the whole game I was dreading getting to the ending, thinking it might ruin the whole plot. I didn't expect to be pleasantly surprised.
- There are aspects of the story and world that are a little dynamic. This is pretty subtle and the game doesn't milk this anywhere as much as it could. It's also hard to describe without spoiling anything.

137522186.review:
The beginning, second and 4th act are definitely the most memorable parts of the game, although i wish the game made you think a bit more, because the stars of the first act, the mimics, make a noise when they're hiding. i believe greater mimics don't do that so that's nice but early in the game you get the ability to see whether objects are or aren't mimics, and i HIGHLY recommend you don't for maybe the first 10 hours, but i wouldn't blame you if you did.

I am constantly surprised by the immersive sim genre as i constantly forget that puzzles require smart solutions, and to pay attention to your surroundings, but due to the beginning being a bit more horror based, your play style actually becomes based on paying attention, causing me to come up with solutions that the developers most likely thought of, but it feels like they didn't. I can confidently say this is is the best haunted house you can experience (out of the games i've played (no i haven't played alien isolation, i will change that soon). 

Talos 1 is A very memorable setting, other than it's layout, you'll forget how to reach an area quickly, although luckily the actual rooms are memorable. The Arcane art style works with this game extremely well, and the first time you actually go to space and look at the station, It looks amazing. You can't think of Talos 1 without thinking of the Typhon, and the state of the station. It's clearly in a bad state, with the Typhon infesting each corner. You get a feeling that you're not being told something. And not just one thing. It feels like there are two layers you're missing out on. 

The worst and best part of the game is definitely the third act. It's bad because there are a few forgettable events and everything is just preparing for the fourth act. The reason it's The best part is because you're exploring and completing side quests which mostly have satisfying endings, and also will enhance the ending, even if you don't do them.

Now let's talk about Mooncrash, AKA the best DLC of 2018 with no exception. It's a Roguelite where you have to figure out what happened to a moonbase which is slightly related to Talos 1.  I would recommend playing Prey, then play Mooncrash as you can get used to the mechanics in prey, so you can use your skills more effectively in mooncrash.

There are 5 characters, who each start with a base kit and have access different parts of the base game's skill tree which you have to unlock. for example, the Volunteer (the first one you gain access to) is kinda the sorcerer of the bunch, he has a lot of typhon abilities in trade for having little health. It admittedly has an easy final objective if you don't limit the amount of delay time loops you use, or don't use any at all. If you get prey (which, by reading this review, you've signed a contract saying you will), you MUST get Mooncrash. It would be a game of the year contender in itself if it were released separately.

Prey is an incredible experience that everyone should play. It undersold, but most of those who did get it, love it. I strongly recommend getting and playing this at your earliest convenience.

So I revisited the game after initially playing it on XBOX One in 2017...

and I gotta say it holds up fantastically! Arkane has produced a masterpiece with PREY! 

THE GOOD:
The Story and setting is interesting enough that it'll keep the player engaged throughout the lengthy campaign. In particular the ending is very interesting without wanting to spoil it here.
The game looks good even 6 years later and it runs flawlessly. 

THE BAD:
The Soundmix however is attrocious...I have no clue who mixed it and what exactly went wrong...but QA should've never let that stay in the release of the game. IT'S BROKEN and directional audio clues on enemy location is busted too.

THE GREAT:
Gameplay in the sandbox of this game is second to none. The sheer options you have to engage enemy enounters with all the different weapons, abilities and interactable environment is what really keeps the player going here! Another very well made part of the game is the progression system and how crafting works in general! 
To put it short: this games replayability is huge and will still provide player wiuth lots of interesting mechanics!

One day I decided to invest some more time into it and really liked it. It's like a BioShocky Deus Ex. The only thing is I wished there was more to it. The world could have been fleshed out more. One of the biggest problems with the "you're the last person alive, survival type game," like Resident Evil or BioShock is it doesn't quite feel real, organic, or believable. There should still be people running around screaming, hiding, and fighting back. It just feels lonely. This isn't so much a problem with Prey, per se, but with the genre itself. Historically, I believe, the sole survivor trope is mostly due to development limitations, such as time or size of the medium. I guess you can't have everything.

[h2]Summary[/h2]
A somewhat beautiful game, but all together boring

[h2]Pro[/h2]
- Beautifully made
- Story is somewhat interesting
- Controls feel good

[h2]Cons[/h2]
- Repetitive
- Boring

[h2]Details[/h2]
It's not a terrible game. In fact, it's pretty decent. Controls and combat feel smooth.
The problem simply is that it's boring.

137299017.review:
This is a great game. If you enjoy the FPS with RPG elements type game, Prey is your best bet. Feels everything that was great from the genre-defining System Shock, with added amazing storylines, emergent backstory that rolls out from side quests, notepads, and hidden secrets. Sound and music are solid, and I have no complaints about the graphics or gunplay. The advancement skill tree seems like there are many different and truly viable ways to play through the game, which I just love. Tons of puzzles/locked doors can be overcome in multiple ways.

Cons to consider, but not stop you from enjoying this game: a few pretty big bugs that take research on the internet to solve (but all were solvable). One bug had a key story objective item despawn, and took some deep finagling with save files to fix. If I hadn't been able to fix it, this would have been a negative review, because I was that invested. Also a little underwhelming is the enemy design, it just doesn't feel particularly well thought out. Humanoid, bug, and floaty thing is pretty much it. 

Last, the difficulty scaling is a bit off. Feels extremely hard at first, and then after building out your character,  becomes frightfully easy.

All that said, buy this game.

Alright I'm almost finished with my first playthrough, I played the game way back around the time it was released because everyone was saying it was like 20 of my favorite games rolled into one. I ended up dropping the game and right now, years later, I'm picking it up again on a new save.

I am slowly remembering why I dropped it in the first place.

There is a point in this game where once you get past the first 5-6 hours, the honeymoon period ends and the game starts to have pacing and balance issues. Enemies are either total pushovers or bullet sponges, your build doesn't feel meaningful or interesting, the gunplay completely falls apart (I've been using the shotgun and pistol for the last 8 hours, shoot me).

The game is getting more and more tedious and don't get me started on the performance problems. Holy fuck Bethesda can you publish one game that doesn't have a pile of issues even years after launch?!!??!? 6800xt GPU, 5900x CPU, 32 gigs of 3200mhz DDR4 ram running on a Sata SSD and this game will drop 40-60 frames at times. Holy shit.

I'm still recommending it for now because the game genuinely has a shitload of cool ideas and fun gameplay moments and if you like western 3D RPGs like Deus Ex or System Shock this game is really fun and gives you that zen of exploring and upgrading and finding stuff but it often suffers from a lack of focus. All kinds of cool stuff, but half of it is never realized fully or would be better in a lot of other games.

recomendado si te gusta la ciencia ficción y la tecnolgía, El juego cuenta con una narrativa envolvente que se desarrolla a través de pistas encontradas en el entorno, lo que fomenta la exploración y el descubrimiento del mundo del juego. Los jugadores tienen una gran libertad para abordar los desafíos que se les presentan, ya sea a través de combate directo, sigilo o resolución de acertijos. Además, el juego ofrece una amplia variedad de armas y habilidades sobrenaturales que el jugador puede adquirir y mejorar.

Los gráficos y la ambientación del juego son excelentes, con una estética retrofuturista que recuerda a los clásicos de ciencia ficción de los años 60 y 70. La banda sonora también es impresionante, con una mezcla de música electrónica y ambiental que ayuda a crear una atmósfera tensa y opresiva.

136902117.review:
Damn...

First thing you should know about this game is that its not a casual one. You can't put 1-2 hours in it and play it again after 2-3 days. That was my mistake. I own this game for a couple of years now. Tried to play it twice, but i stopped at about 5 hours in. It got complicated. Messy. Demanding. I was trying to focus at the story but i was getting new stuff and info at a rate that it became exhausting  so i dropped it. Twice. 

This time though, i persisted. And boy oh boy was i surprised. 

After the first 15 hours, as i was upgrading my skills and weaponry, the immersion started to kick in. The plot got thicker. And as it did, i started to invest even more brain matter into it. And then i realized that i was playing an underrated gem, worthy of being up there with Bioshock, Dead space and Dishonored.

136848705.review:
One of the best games I have ever played. There's no way we got a game this good in god damn 2017, and yet we did. Don't go into this game expecting some generic space boomer shooter, because it's far from it. Much like the original Deus Ex - it's not a top-tier shooter, top-tier stealth game, or top-tier RPG, but it uses all of those mechanics (and much more) in a very good way. It's more like a first-person, sci-fi, survival adventure with highly emergent gameplay. That being said, you can totally play this game like a basic shooter if you want to - just as long as you build your character that way. There are so many creative ways you can get through the game, with lots of cool builds, powers, weapons (most of them are more like tools), and there's a lot of depth to the levels with many options and paths you can take.
Unfortunately there are a lot of long loading screens in-between levels and I feel like it could have been more seamless in some places.

Still, the game has hardly any flaws (except for a few really gay story details) and it's worth every single minute spent outside of loading screens.
[/b] 9.5/10

136832602.review:
It's... complicated. But I'll start with:

***WARNING***
This game has severe audio issues that have never been fixed. If you experience weird volume levels, like dialogue, gunfire, or impacts abnormaly quiet or loud, know now that there is no fix. If you find the issue too annoying, refund quickly. It is not a settings issues. You will experience the entire game like this.
***WARNING***

So this game reminded me a bit of Deus Ex. You have quite a bit of freedom, there's side quests and storylines you can follow (usually with no great finale, but nice rewards for them), and you can do things in whichever order you want. Therefore, it's one of those games that allows you to become very powerful before proceeding with the main quest line. You also start out very underpowered, so there is very satisfying progression to be had.

The above is pretty much it. It was enough to keep me going. You're free to do your thing, and the enemies won't become incomprehensibly stronger as you power up. I finished it in 54 hours-ish.

On the flipside, the game pretty much has zero polish. Animations are meh for such a title, audio is 0/10 need subtitles, and there's just quite a bit of overall jank. If you enjoy Deus Ex-esque games, and don't get the audio bug (or can look past it), you will probably enjoy this. Lots of reading and lore, and usually sensible stuff, so it's not just jam-packed with chapters upon chapters of useless reading material. Would not give more than 20 or 25€  if I knew then what I know now.
