136485311.review:
A masterpiece of a game. People might compare it to System Shock 2, but I haven't played that, so the best I can say is – it's a mix of Bioshock and Dishonored, but more open-ended than either. Took me around 45 hours to complete on my first run, though I did get most of the achievements (42 of 48, non-DLC) in doing so.

I ran into a few minor bugs, but none of them game-breaking. Characters tend to talk over each other, the first Operator you encounter has once voice-line without the proper sound effects. Operators in Deep Storage tend to float up to the high ceiling and stay there indefinitely. Etc. The worst one was when I phased through the ceiling, though that was fixed by loading a quicksave.

There is an attempt to make realistic directional sound. If an enemy is in an other room, you will not hear its noises coming from the walls, but from the nearest entrance. Unfortunately, it doesn't decrease in loudness as it should, so a Phantom will always sound like it's about to enter your room.

I found the helicopter intro quite clever, with the credits being billboards on buildings. After that intro, I found the end credits to be lackluster. They could've done so much more: have the dust of the final boss turn into words as the shuttle flies off into the distance, or have the words projected onto the station as the camera orbits around it, or have the camera fly through the station's interior with the words being shown on screens and in reflections. Just a simple name-scroll was disappointing after all that the game was. The post-credits scene, however, is a stroke of genius. That made me want to replay the game a few more times, and not just to grind out the remaining achievements.

After I was completely done with the base game, Mooncrash was what fifteen years ago we would have called an expansion pack, rather than a DLC. On its own, it adds a new roguelite campaign with a new map. and some new weapons, abilities and enemies unique to it. I wouldn't price it at 20 € due to its small size, but it's an easy pick during a sale.

[b]Story spoilers below[/b]
[spoiler] The game really seems to have a pessimistic view of humanity's chances against the Typhon, even though Talos I was doing quite well against the alien threat. Aside from the player, the security chief was, seemingly, an other super-human figure that emerged in the race for survival. In my view – that is a very promising result. That bot's idea that a single Mimic would destroy the world seems especially laughable. If one station has two, then an entire planet will have countless. Things will only get better from there due to the forced evolution of humanity – we've gotten quite good at the whole 'species war' thing over the course of a few million years. Of course, the reason for that pessimism is made clear in the end, though I found that in itself to be quite perplexing.[/spoiler]

136418823.review:
Prey 2017 is an underrated gem of a game that deserves far more attention than it got upon release. While it may not have been perfect, there's no denying that it offers some of the most immersive and atmospheric gameplay you'll find in any first-person shooter.

The game's setting, a space station overrun by an alien menace, is a masterclass in environmental storytelling. Every inch of the station feels lived-in and believable, and the game's attention to detail is truly impressive. From the flickering lights to the ominous whispers in the dark, the game's atmosphere is second to none.

While the game's AI can be a bit flawed at times, and the challenge can start to wane after a while, the sheer joy of exploration and discovery keeps the game engaging throughout. There are always new secrets to uncover, new areas to explore, and new weapons and abilities to discover.

But what really sets Prey 2017 apart is its sense of freedom. You're free to explore the space station at your own pace, tackling challenges in any order you choose and approaching each encounter in your own unique way. This freedom, combined with the game's immersive atmosphere, makes for a truly unforgettable experience.

In short, if you're looking for a first-person shooter that offers something truly different, then Prey 2017 is the game for you. It may not be perfect, but its strengths far outweigh its weaknesses, and it's a game that deserves to be experienced by anyone who loves a good story and immersive gameplay.

136231035.review:
I tried to like this game. I really did. But there is far too much I didn't enjoy. 
The main difficulty you'll face is not knowing where to go, how to get most items, what items are best used, and similar "guide damn it" moments. Once you realise how overpowered shotgun is, how to get the stun gun after entering the second room, and that you can abuse operator stations for large amounts of crafting resources, a lot of the difficulty drops off a cliff. 

However, there are still a large number of ridiculous design choices. Why do enemies respawn when you have a finite amount of any given resources in a level? Why bother having Bioshock-styled powers when they're on a cooldown resulting in about several dozen Psihypos in my inventory (even before the quest that gives infinite Psi energy)? Why bother punishing the player for taking "Mutant" powers by making turrets hostile when pretty much every turrent after the Lobby is either broken or folded up? Just so many questions and that's before even getting to the enemies.

The enemies are about as interesting as they diverse and that's not a compliment. Mimics are your run-of-the-mill ROUS' and the game can't even hold itself back as it gives you the ability to reveal them about 30 minutes after you get the Scope. Phantoms are basically humanoids that may have one of two elements but are still easy to defeat with a single Typhon power. Weavers don't do much beyond give you motion sickness through screen shake. Cystoid are easily dealt with through throwing a garbage can at them. Telepath show up 2 times that I can recall and both in the same level. Technopath can be stun gunned to death. Poltergeist are likely to kill you out of sheer luck. And the Nightmare...

The Nightmare is where the entire game just falls apart and makes all the gameplay issues obvious. A massive bullet sponge that just shows how unsatisfying the combat is since you're largely limited to dumping numbers into a body and hoping that maybe your tissue paper turrets do any damage. No, the best option is literally to stick yourself in a locked security booth, a vent tunnel, or literally just wait in a previous level for 2.5 minutes for it to despawn because the concept of a door is too much for it to handle. 

As for the story, there's not much to share. It pretends to be complex when it's just convoluted, trying to made some statement on The Human Condition™️ before ending with "Empathy Am Good". Between that is a bunch of moments where you're being led by the nose to do menial tasks. The sidequests don't do much more than the main story of "go to a place and get a thing". "Go to my room and get a medal". "Go to my room and get a recording". "Go find some turrets and place them here, wagie!" The reward for this is little more than a firm pat on the butt and a "thanks".

As for the visuals, they're honestly pretty basic. High quality, for sure, but basic nonetheless. Even thought it seems like the developers did their best to make it 'lived in', they kept making the same room of "a fenced off area under a platform with a recliner and table" about three times. 

Is the game worth it? Maybe on a steep discount and you intend to play it more than once, I guess. Otherwise, expect about 12-15 hours for an unguided, casual playthrough.

Prey, the game that's unforgettably forgettable.

[h1]Unforgettable or Forgettable?[/h1]

Prey is a strange game in that I remember gameplay aspects that I liked, I remember the intro and I remember the gist of the plot but I have no idea how A got to Z. Everything plot wise between A and Z is gone. Hard as I might try, I simply cannot remember a single thing.

This strikes me as very odd as Prey is a great title that's well made with innovative ideas throughout and feels as if the world in which you occupy is an organic one, therefore it's strange that I'm drawing a complete blank. 

In general Prey is a great game all round:

Good graphics? > check
Good sound design? > check
Is it fun? > check
Etc? > check
Etc? > check
Etc? > check

I genuinely don't have anything to complain about. I really enjoyed my time with this title.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Prey plays exactly like [b]System Shock[/b] and [b]Bioshock[/b] etc with a few unique elements thrown in for good measure.

[h1]Prey 2006 Sequel?[/h1]

I do get a feeling that the name "Prey" was tacked on for some sort of money grabbing business reason as this Prey has nothing to do with the original Prey game and definitely nothing to do with the Prey 2: E3 2011 official trailer either. This Prey is a game that occupies it's own space and holds it's own... made off the back of the then cancelled Prey 2 (as far as I'm aware).

This has nothing to do with anything, I just wanted to add it.

135975107.review:
Prey is the best game to use the System Shock formula. It has a unique resource/crafting system, good gunplay, interesting enemies, amazing exploration, plenty of secrets, and a good sense of progression with more areas being unlocked as you play the story and gain new abilities. The worldbuilding and environmental storytelling are good, and the story is well written with player actions eventually dictating which of the several endings you receive.

My only complaints are the fairly limited arsenal (which makes sense according to the story, you're on a science station orbiting the moon), and limited amount of enemy types.

Complaints aside, I usually come back to this game every year because each playthrough can easily give you dozens of hours of exploration and sidequests.

So I ignored this game back when it came out; the buzz around it was mostly about Bethesda ruining a sequel/reboot to a cool IP (though one I'd not heard of beforehand), and then reviews were pretty meh. But I've been binging YT game reviews and Prey keeps coming up as a hidden gem, so I decided to try it.

Man am I annoyed at how badly Bethesda screwed Arkane by refusing to drop the Prey name or market this game correctly. I had no idea it was one of my favorite genre of games (immersive sim). It's essentially Mildly-Spooky Deus Ex Lite, In Space.

The first 20 minutes is probably the most memorable of any game I've played in recent memory. I'm really intrigued by the story and can honestly say it's the only time I've willingly read the emails on computers just to see if there's more clues as to what's going on. 

I have only been playing a few hours and have already been delighted so many times just from exploring and finding new things or alternate paths. The gloo gun is also such an interesting tool.

I'm not saying this game is a masterpiece, I have barely scratched the surface so far, but as someone who wrote it off as just another spooky space shooter, I want to make it clear that this is not the case at all. 

I picked up the deluxe edition (heard great things about the DLC) for the current full price of $40 and I feel like I got a good deal. 

If you're a fan of play-the-way-you-want gameplay you should absolutely give Prey a try.

Prey is a game that truly immerses players in an incredibly detailed and intricate world that's full of mystery and danger. From the gameplay to the storyline, everything about this game is top-notch.

One of the standout features of Prey is the game's open-world gameplay, which allows players to explore the space station, Talos 1, at their own pace. The game's variety of weapons and abilities also add a level of strategy to the gameplay, with players able to use stealth or brute force to take on enemies.

But what really sets Prey apart is the game's story, which is full of twists and turns that keep players guessing from start to finish. The game's protagonist, Morgan Yu, is a complex and interesting character, and the game's multiple endings offer plenty of replay value.

The game's graphics and sound design are also top-notch, with the space station feeling like a believable and immersive environment. And the voice acting is superb, with the cast delivering performances that bring the game's characters to life.

In short, Prey is a game that's full of surprises and one that will keep players engaged from start to finish. Whether you're a fan of first-person shooters or simply love a good story-driven game, Prey is a must-play title that will leave you wanting more.

135594137.review:
I think I have said this about every single game I have played by this dev team but it rings true for all of them, Games aren't made with the same level of love and care as they used to. This game is a culmination of so many mechanics and details they have developed and made into a unique experience that recognizes EVERYTHING you do. Even the small things, for instance the game recognized my attempt to not kill any of the mind controlled humans. This wasn't a tracked number while I was playing I didn't even know it was being tracked until I beat the game and was rewarded for doing so! This game rewards you for playing your own way, whether that means you kill everything mercilessly, save everyone and be the hero, or a little of both. I did what I believed Morgan would do given the info I could find about him in the game, which was already kinda what I wanted to do anyway.
Now to mention the story/setting, There is so much detail and so much variance based entirely on what your actions are. This goes beyond just who you kill or don't kill too, it's decisions it's planning. Going out of the way to do as much as possible for people or yourself, I didn't even find everything in my first run and I was quite thorough (my run was 32 hours, I took my time.).
When you are playing this, think deeply about your decisions and what they could mean for you and the future scenarios to come. There is a lot more consequences and rewards for every action you make.
One thing to take into account when playing this, DO NOT think it is a basic shooter that is centered around killing everything and shooting like you have infinite ammo, not to say you couldn't do it but it is gonna be a lot harder than you think. If you are familiar or have played the Dishonored series I recommend you play it like that game. Take your time exploring all your options and tackling challenges with as many options available to you as possible, find smarter ways to defeat enemies that require less resources, set traps or avoid conflict all together. It is ultimately up to you to quote the game and the games before it made by this team "Play your way".
In my play-through I chose to play on hard with the survival settings on, it was very rewarding and not overly difficult. 
If you are familiar with their other games I recommend playing as I have if not the next difficulty higher.
I can imagine that the lower difficulties would have made my play-through less entertaining, I quite like a challenge and feel like I need to keep challenging myself or things may grow stale.
If you are not familiar with their other games and just want to get the story I recommend a lower difficulty maybe still use the survival settings though, they don't make the game super hard they just make it more interesting and logistics based. You will want to be more frugal with your resources and may want to avoid combat a bit more often since it adds status effects that need specific things to fix them (example, when taking fire damage you may receive burns if the damage is significant enough and that will cut a chunk of your health out until you fix it with a burn remedy)
In conclusion to one of the longest reviews I have ever made.
This game is another fine example of what games should be, here's hoping we will eventually see this kind of quality, love, and effort put into the games yet to be made by anyone in our future.

oh and PS: Don't trust the chef.

135521885.review:
Prey is an overlooked gem with a beautiful message about mental health and identity: The only you that matters is who you are now. Whoa...

Prey asks a lot of interesting questions about memory, identity, self-image, mental and physical wellness, interpersonal relationships, workplace culture, scientific advancement, human folly, violence, and the morality of survival at all costs. These primarily come through in the dialogue, which is largely in the form of audio logs found throughout the game world, a 60s-chic space station where hostile alien lifeforms have already killed your coworkers. The space station is a piece of art in itself, and serves as a (quite convincing) mega corporation's cutting-edge research facility, and a clever representation of the human brain. This place is your mind, and your mind is a battleground and a mystery; warm and welcoming; cold and mechanistic; dark and eerie; layered and deep.

This first-person-action-thriller-RPG is in every sense a competent and heartfelt homage to several massively influential titles: System Shock 2, Thief, Half-Life, Deus Ex, and Dishonoured. It also draws clear inspiration from the Alien film franchise. If you enjoyed any or all of these titles then you will probably love this exceptionally well-paced, well-written, beautifully-rendered mind game.

Prey's biggest fault is its name. With enough patience and skill you will go from being the hunted to the hunter, but this game is so much more than that. It really should've been called "Mind Game" or something akin to this, but I can appreciate that there perhaps was a good reason to deceive the player, as after all, deception (self-deception) is a core theme. This is not to say that Prey has any unpleasant surprises. Everything is deliberate and subtle and smartly woven into a coherent experience that is engrossing and deeply emotional. It could've been a bit more confident in itself, though.

All said, this game deserves your time, and you deserve the immensely validating chance for self-reflection that it offers.

135514198.review:
Prey is the best game you never played. 
Arkane's masterpiece has one of the best game worlds and environmental design I have ever seen.
Every inch of the station is carefully and masterfully designed just as if it was a real place. 
Talos-1 makes sense as a whole. Every person, every room is thoroughly thought, and every email you read, every diary you listen to connect as a whole. It is so detailed that you can list what happened to each person during the disaster, probably. 
Finished it 3 times on Xbox; finishing it once more on PC; Prey still managed to enjoy me with new content, which is why I love Prey in a nutshell. I found new ways of solving an existing obstacle, missions I haven't seen before stashes I never found, and secrets that I wasn't able to find my way before.
Prey is often compared with the Bioshock series but the statement is simply wrong: Bioshock games are both narratively and level design-wise merely linear (Bioshock series has many semi-open levels -Fort Fraulic, Minerva's Den-but there is always one way to deal with the problems in Prey game is all about sheer amount of solutions to any given problem).
Prey should be compared to System Shock and basically is a spiritual successor. 
The atmosphere of Talos-1 is spot on; the exterior feels big, loose, and tense (just as it should be), the sound design is horrifying and high-quality (I agree it can become exhausting later ), OST made by Mick Gordon is one of a kind.
 I also like the art style, architecture revolves mainly around Art Deco, Industrialism, and constructivism (game explains why). Different levels of the station have different styles, as you go down to Power Plant it is more industrial and brutal almost Soviet-like but as you go higher up the station places feel more luxurious and decorated, the art-deco style being dominant; it is kinda like Bioshock 1 (although I must agree Bioshock 1 was superior in showing it; and it leaned even more towards art-deco and neon lightning) mixed with Half Life. 
The power plant level reminded me of the one from Bioshock 1 and, Arboretum felt to me just like Arcadia (not an expert these are merely my observations on architecture). And many other places seemed to me like they were out of Half Life.
Prey is the most underrated game I've ever played, a perfect blend of Half Life, Bioshock, and System Shock in my mind. This was the Half Life 3, I was dreaming of as a kid. 
A masterfully thought Semi-open world, with many ways to solve any problem, with Metroidvania elements and a breathtaking atmosphere. I simply can't help but loving it...
A must-try experience for fans of the genre.

135498157.review:
Well, Prey is kind of like a delicious cake that looks amazing on the outside, but once you take a bite, you realize it's made of cardboard. Don't get me wrong, there are some great things about this game. The graphics are beautiful, the atmosphere is tense, and the music is hauntingly beautiful. But, it falls apart in other areas like a soggy cake.

For starters, the game's story is so convoluted and confusing that it gave me a headache. I don't mind a little complexity, but Prey is like trying to solve a Rubik's cube blindfolded. It's frustrating, and I just ended up feeling lost and disconnected from the game's world.

Then there's the combat, which is clunky and unsatisfying. I mean, sure, you get some cool alien powers, but using them feels like trying to juggle wet noodles. The enemies are also repetitive and uninteresting, and the game's difficulty is all over the place.

Overall, Prey is good- but still a disappointment. It's like a cake that looks amazing, but tastes like disappointment. I'd recommend giving this one a pass unless you're a die-hard fan of the genre or have a lot of time to kill. Sorry, Arkane Studios, but this cake needs more sugar.

135068916.review:
[h1] Prey - A thrilling sci-fi adventure [/h1]

Prey is a sci-fi first-person shooter game that takes place aboard the Talos I space station, orbiting the moon in the year 2035. The game offers a unique blend of action, exploration, and horror elements, making it an exciting and immersive experience.

The game's story revolves around Morgan Yu, a scientist who wakes up aboard the Talos I with no memory of the events that led to their current situation. As Morgan, you must explore the station, gather resources, and fight against the alien Typhon threat to uncover the truth about your past and save humanity from extinction.

Prey's gameplay is a mix of combat, stealth, and exploration. The game offers a wide range of weapons and abilities that can be used to take down enemies or avoid them altogether. You can also use the game's crafting system to create new items and weapons, which adds an extra layer of depth to the gameplay.

[spoiler]One of the most impressive aspects of Prey is its opening sequence, which is reminiscent of the opening scene of Mission Impossible. In that scene, the bad guy is in a fake hospital, and the audience is not sure what is real and what is not. Similarly, in Prey, the player wakes up in a simulation that appears to be real but is later revealed to be a simulation.[/spoiler] This opening sequence sets the tone for the game, leaving the player with a sense of unease and uncertainty.

The graphics and sound design in Prey are also top-notch, adding to the overall immersion and atmosphere of the game. The game's soundtrack, composed by Mick Gordon, is especially impressive, with its haunting and atmospheric tunes perfectly complementing the game's sci-fi setting.

Overall, Prey is an excellent game that offers a unique and thrilling sci-fi adventure. Its gameplay, story, and atmosphere all come together to create an immersive and unforgettable experience. If you're a fan of sci-fi, first-person shooters, or just good storytelling, then Prey is definitely worth checking out.

134934637.review:
TL;DR - Prey is fantastic and deserves to be played

Prey is one of the best games released in the past decade. The amount of freedom the game gives you for navigating the (really nice looking) station is exemplary - you can hack, find hidden vents, lift heavy objects, foam crossbow to manipulate screens, telekinesis etc. Its a breath of fresh air in a time where video games treat the player like a drooling tard that needs his hand held through every step of the process. 

Graphically the game is pretty good - its lightly stylized so it'll hold up longer than realism-focused graphics. Native ultrawide support. Very annoying decision is to have your weapon POV right up in your face. There a fix for that though.

Plot is very interesting and benefits from the player taking the time to read emails/audio logs to get the full picture. Multiple endings. You are also given a wide array of freedom in helping/killing NPCs

Very minor woke elements.

Only legitimate criticism is a noticeable amount of bugs in the later part of the game. A few quests can bug out and require reloading from an earlier save to complete. Some areas have missing textures.

Overall easy 8.5/10 - one of the best games made in recent memory
DLC is OK but overstays its welcome a bit, thought it does provide extra context for the plot so its worth it for that at least

Prey is an incredibly fun imm sim. You can see how much the devs thought about player solutions to problems players may face. As such, each one can be potentially solved with either tools or keen wits. A "No Needles" playthrough will make you appreciate how much there is on offer in the game. There are a couple of rooms that look to be gated off by powers, but they don't block main story progress.

Its DLC, Mooncrash, is an excellent roguelike simulation, where you have to guide 5 characters to 5 unique exit points. Each has their own strengths and weaknesses, and the mode is very challenging to newcomers and veterans alike, as the simulation changes up specific aspects of the area, such as hazards, each time.

If you like Deus Ex and other imm sims, you'll love Prey. You'll also enjoy it you love a good sci-fi horror story as well.

134629268.review:
(Have played this on Steam briefly but have beaten it on PC Gamepass)

Damn.... What is there to say about Prey? God, what a great journey that game was. 

-Amazing soundtrack with the man himself Mick Gordon. The song "Everything is Going to Be OK" from the Prey OST is one of my all time favourites of game songs. Not much to say about the soundtrack other than Yes Yes Yes.

-The story is excellent. Everyone is comparing it to System Shock but I've never played that, so to me it felt like Bioshock mixed with Dead Space. You are aboard Talos I, a space station that orbits the moon with Earth's Best and Brightest aboard to push humanity further than it thought possible. Of course, Everything goes wrong and you are left fighting for your life. 

-Great gameplay. A great slew of open-ended puzzles that almost ALWAYS have more than one way to solve them. Exciting combat with different ways to defeat your enemies, or just sneak past them if you want. Replayability due to the extensive Neuromod skill trees. Fun powers to mess around with and master as you discover more and more enemies. And who didn't love the Recycler charges? God what isn't there to love?

-Overall design of the game is just A+. The UI is awesome and makes using the terminals in the game pretty fun, the game is immersive and mysterious and makes you want to learn more about Talos I and what happened aboard it, enemies have cool variations, there is tons of side missions, and a pretty compelling, if sometimes a little bland, antagonist as well. 

Solid 9/10 I'd say. Great game that I will certainly be revisiting.

134617030.review: Prey is an incredibly engaging game that deserves more recognition than it currently receives. The story is intriguing and constantly keeps you on the edge of your seat. The gameplay is top-notch, with a variety of weapons and abilities that allow you to approach situations in different ways. The game world is rich and immersive, with secrets to uncover and multiple paths to explore. The graphics are great, with attention to detail that creates a believable and haunting atmosphere. Overall, Prey is a must-play for fans of action-adventure games and science-fiction, and it's a shame that it's not more popular.

134572738.review:
I really want to like PREY. It's really a spiritual successor to the Bioshock 1 and 2, and other immersive sims that preceded it, like Deus Ex. However, I think expectations are easily my biggest issue with PREY.


The game looks great, it has a great voice cast, and it has fantastic opening premise, with a very strong setting/worldbuilding identity. It's more akin to a first-person resource management/puzzle game than a Shooter/RPG like its clear inspirations. Perhaps you'll enjoy it more than me, but there's still some problems I can't look past, mostly stemming from the overall unfinished feeling the game has.

The UI is terrible, possibly even worse than Skyrim. It was clearly designed for a Gamepad rather than Mouse and Keyboard. On top of that, the Quest pings and objective markers and very intrusive, as they're often accompanied by sounds and effects.

Movement is very sluggish but also feels weirdly weightless, like you're a bowling ball sliding around.

The combat is ok, but rendered entirely moot by the strength of enemies, who can 1 shot you before you have the chance to identify them, let alone react. You can't just run and gun like its DOOM, you do have to be slow and methodical, using the right tool to dispose of enemies efficiently - hence the puzzle game comparison.

As much as PREY tries to emphasise multiple solutions for the same problem, the only way to succeed is to scrounge every nook and cranny for supplies (which is much more tedious than Bioshock), and then die in one shot to an elite enemy that was dumped in the starting area.

I know difficulty is a controversial topic in games, but PREY is very inconsistent. On one hand, it holds your hand so tightly it hurts your fingers, only to then not even tell you important information like how to charge a power attack with the Wrench.

If PREY had a few more months, I think it could be something amazing. While I see the appeal, I personally found it a frustrating experience. It was telling me 'play your way, there's many solutions to each problem', only to then tell you 'no, not like that'.

P.S. I had to shorten some of this review's content, due to it surpassing Steam's allowed amount of symbols, therefore some game's aspects will be discussed briefly. I wish i didn't have to do this, but it can't be helped.

At first, i tried this game on 16th June of 2019, earned one specific achievement purely by messing around, which in result left me cheered up and with a realization that devs have a good sense of humor. Nevertheless, back then - i dropped the project, since at the moment i was looking for a different type of entertainment. But then, on 13th February of 2023, this game's time has finally came, and it was worth it.

---{Gameplay}---

☑️ Land of opportunities
☐ Has a couple of tricks up in its sleeve
☐ Simple, yet operational
☐ Will do, if in a small doses
☐ Do something else while playing

- This is a first immersive sim i ever played in my life, so i don't know if it's the weakest, the strongest, or the average one among the genre. But no matter where it's going to end up - this is an amazingly impactful game overall. This is exactly a case when the game is a centimeter-wide and a kilometer-deep. All mechanics are fun, meaningful, consistent till the very end. Some of their branches are not polished to a finished state, but they will not prevent you from enjoying the game.

--{Story}---
☐ Do you feel like a hero yet?
☑️ You will wish to experience it like the very first time
☐ You will have something to discuss about
☐ It's just good enough to keep you going

☐ Laughable, broken, pitiful
☐ There is none

- Narration reacts to your actions - you can play the game as if it is totally linear, or you can slow down, take your time, an treat it like in an RPG. You kill every character in the game, ignore everyone's quest, serve only yourself and cowardly escape from problems - It's fine! The game still has a place for your kind. In fact it has so many endings - one of them actually covers this behavior specifically.

---{Graphics}---
☐ Style is immortal
☐ This is the real reality
☐ Commendable
☑️ Decent
☐ Meh
☐ Disgusting
☐ Call an ambulance, your eyes are bleeding

- While this game shares Arkane's own art style, developed during creation of first Dishonored, it feels drastically watered down, as if Studio never had enough time to ponder it out fully: ingame drawn pictures, half of props and human anatomy does look polished, but usable equipment, enviroment and the other half of props - does not. Overall it still manages to create an appropriate representation even by 2023 standards, but it lost its chance to stand out.

---{Sound Effects}---
☐ ASMR
☐ It could even carry your feelings without OST

- Aside from recycling noises of (obviously) the recycling grenade, typhons' whispers and Gloo Gun's firing sounds, in my opinion, everything else sounds just okeyish. I think it's imperative for Prey's OST to accompany its SFX, and vice versa, because otherwise, by turning music off you'll contribute to the most unwelcome boredom's magnification.

---{Music}---
☐ This sentinel being just became my favorite composer

☐ You will find yourself relistening to a lot of tracks
☑️ You are going to find some tracks to be memorable

☐ It struggles to fit in

- From my perspective, the game has 2 very good tracks, while the rest of the album reminds narrowly-specialized, difficult-to-listen-separately ambient. Which is actually your most-common situation in games, or probably just a little bit better, since i remember a lot of decent games where i couldn't remember anything related to music.

- That's a simple one, to be honest. This game's just better than that, therefore it won't force you to fall for that, not even a single time, and no matter how good you're in combat and inventory management.

134476862.review:
[h1] So, Prey [/h1]
It's my personal dream game even before I knew that I have such dream game in [b] mind [/b] or in need. As a casual fan of sci-fi genre and science in general + lover of transhumanism theme in media I can highly recommend Prey. I won't tell the known story about "unfair lack of attention on the release", at that point it's just a fate for such cult games I guess. The design and art of Prey is remarkable, weapons, atmosphere, the idea and look behind different divisions and Talos-1 in general, it is very gorgeous. I personally believe that after gravity gun in half life, gloo gun in Prey is the next major step in creative weapon design (also lol, gravity gun and crowbar in half life and gloo gun and wrench in prey, you see?). Controls in open space are very natural and just right, giving the feeling as if I would really be in space. The view of Earth, Moon and cosmic void when you first go out into open space and feeling of it thanks to size of Talos, impressive distances between different objects and places outside the station, are really breathtaking and making you believe that you here are stranded; when I tried to fly away towards the Moon I was very horrified by loneliness and isolation that was pressing harder with every meter separating me from Talos, where, yeah, [b] typhons [/b] and stuff, but not this unimaginably sized emptiness. Story is intriguing and especially its final. Questions that will be raised here and decisions you make will test [b] yu [/b] as a person, as a [i] human being[/i]. Also side stories, lore and overall atmosphere of every crew member, their work before the incident, their relationships, everyday life here is very [b] human[/b]. You can really see how even the brightest [i] minds [/i] liked to play DnD or have a musical concert and other grounded stuff. Ofc there are some little bugs, that I even met in different walkthroughs at the same place, but as I said they are minor and don't break the game or your immersion. If you are not familiar with immersive sims (otherwise you know about Prey without this review lol) give it a try and especially try Prey if you just like good and unconventional sci-fi, it won't disappoint you and mby it will become your favorite game as [b] it [/b] has become for me

134323313.review: This game is not talked about enough, an absolutely fantastic game, and truly shows exactly what an immersive sim should be. The freedom in how you play this game is just so refreshing, from the immense amount of abilities to choose from, to the choice to explore the space station how you want to. If you're not convinced to play this game by what you've read about this game, the intro will convince you to really get into it, I honestly just love the intro for this game, it does such a perfect job of making the story and world so appealing, and I don't want to talk about the intro too much because I feel everyone should go blind into the intro of this game. The story for this game is great, it just does a good job of making you feel for these characters, once I started this game I had in my head made a decision for how I wanted to go with the story, but by the end of it, the world building and characters had convinced me to go down a different route. Personally for me one of the best things this game does is your ability to kill[i] anyone [/i], I love the freedom of choosing how the story goes, if you don't like a character or their motives, you can just kill them, and these choices affect the story. The ending of this game really is not what I expected at all, but once you see it it makes sense, and it calls back everything from your play through and how you chose to play the game. This may be all over the play but overall, Prey (2017) is a must play game, absolutely fantastic and super fun.

134269878.review:
Short and Sweet: If you like System Shock or Bioshock, this game is for you. It's a direct take on merging those two into one.

If you're looking for something at all, even slightly, like Dishonored, then you'll only like the graphics, which have that awesome Arkane style. Little else is like Dishonored.

If you're on the fence, you should just ignore all of the negative stuff people said at launch. This is a very competent, good game. It's not perfect, though.

The controls are sloppier than Dishonored 2. I guess that's from changing engines to Cry instead of Void. There are small small bugs I've never encountered in other games, like only being able to use [Enter] or [F] to select certain menu options (despite saying you can click). And there are common bugs, like texture clipping. But those are nit picks.

If you really want it and can absolutely commit, you should play System Shock 2 instead. That is the defining game of this genre and is still absolutely unbeaten, in my opinion.

133964351.review:
Prey is a hidden masterpiece of a game that takes the ideas put forth in the system shock games and improves upon them in many ways. The psi powers are solid, and they all have their uses (though some tend to be better than others). You can use them for the entire game, if you choose, which is great. Speaking of choices, there's a lot. You can choose how you want to enter a room, if you want to save someone, and what kind of skills you want to have. Freedom to enter a room guns blazing or sneak around the enemy. Your choices also directly affect the narrative. The gunplay is smooth, with unique options like the recycle charge (grenade but it gives you items when you use it), stun gun (best gun in the game after the shotgun), and the q-beam. The characters are fleshed out. There are all kinds of people on the space station and they all have real relationships with each other; the audio logs are well done and the world building is great too. The aliens are decently challenging, but you can always up the difficulty if you feel its lacking. The only complaint I have is that the audio isn't mixed super well, and that sometimes the npcs can be a bit glitchy. 

10/10

tl;dr its better than bioshock, dont buy system shock remake and play this instead (then play system shock 2).

133794153.review:
Prey 2018 takes place in an alternate timeline where JFK survives the assassination attempt and the US and USSR join forces to build a space station called Talos I. The station's purpose is to research an alien race called the Typhon and develop technologies to defend against them. You play as Morgan Yu, a scientist who wakes up with no memory of what's going on, and must unravel the mystery of what happened aboard Talos I.

Now, let me tell you folks, this game's story is a real nail-biter. The plot twists and turns like a snake on roller skates, and it keeps you guessing until the very end. The characters are well-developed, and the voice acting is top-notch. The pacing is just right, and there's never a dull moment. The story is the highlight of this game, and it's worth playing just for that.

Now, let's talk about the gameplay. Prey 2018 is a first-person shooter, but it's also an RPG and a survival horror game. You have to scavenge for resources and manage your inventory carefully, or you'll find yourself in a world of hurt. The enemies in this game, the Typhon, are no joke. They come in a variety of forms, from the small and squishy Mimics to the massive and terrifying Nightmare. Each Typhon has its own weaknesses and strengths, so you'll have to adapt your playstyle to take them down.

The game's level design is also top-notch. Talos I is a massive, interconnected space station with multiple routes and hidden areas. You can go just about anywhere you want, and there are plenty of secrets to discover. The puzzles in this game are challenging but fair, and they make you feel like a genius when you solve them.

Now, I do have a minor gripe with this game like the loading times that are a bit on the long side. However, these issues are minor and don't detract from the overall experience.
In conclusion, Prey 2018 is a must-play for fans of sci-fi, horror, and RPGs. The story is gripping, the gameplay is challenging, and the level design is excellent. If you haven't played it yet, do yourself a favor and check it out.

133630896.review:
If I were to rate [i]Prey[/i] (2017) I'd give it a 7.5 out of 10. 

The visual aesthetics remind me a lot of [i]Dead Space[/i] while the game play reminds of, Arkane Studio's prior game, [i]Dishonored[/i]. The stealth system in combination with the GLOO Cannon gives the player multiple ways to tackle objectives and Neuromod abilities allow for fun fluid fast-paced and chaotic combat. Mick Gordon, the composer behind [i]DOOM[/i] (2016), worked on the soundtrack.

I felt like the story plateaued about three quarters of the way through. Observing the interactions and personalities of the crew through TranScribes, notes, and emails did add to the late game but I felt like the minimal amount of in-person interactions with humans meant a lot of wasted potential.

---

The game took me about 23 hours to fully complete. I could see myself replaying the game for new game + or to get achievements related to not using Neuromods. I did not end up playing the DLC. 

The game ran fine on the Steam Deck with Linux but I did experience the occasional physics glitch where an object would remain floating and once an airlock door would not open despite the sound effect indicating that it had. I had to reload my save for the later. 

On a sidenote this game has nothing to do with the 2006 version of [i]Prey[/i]. Developer Raphael Colantonio in the AIAS Game Maker’s Notebook podcast the decision to name the game Prey was pushed onto them by Bethesda.

133617425.review:
As a reminder, this is effectively as close as we're ever going to get to another Immersive Sim for god knows how long. It's great, through and through, and takes the adaptability and variety of games like the original Deus Ex and System Shock 2 while porting them to a modern genre with modern tools and tech. I could write all the words I'd want to write with this review, but I must stress that would do nothing to actually properly describe how much of a masterpiece that PREY (2016) is.

This thing is a very delicately and meticulously crafted love letter to games, one that you can play over, and over, and over again, through dozens of runs, dozens of separate tries, and still encounter something new in each and every playthrough. PREY is a game that they made specifically to push your boundaries just as much as you push its own. Press the advantage, run, hide, fight, scavenge, recycle, upgrade, survive. I could keep rambling, but it's one of those titles that I think is best served with a "You'll have to play this for yourself to truly come to terms with how wonderful it is."

Arkane managed to make a game so over-the-top and excellent in quality that even six years later I still look at it longingly, and I hope like no tomorrow the story it set up at some point will be continued with a sequel that does the first one justice.

Good morning, Morgan. Today is Monday, March 15.

Let's begin.

133548240.review:
As a spiritual successor to System Shock, Prey took the formula of immersive sim and evolved it into something quite unique and special. 

It's a real shame that the game undersold commercially since people were expecting something close to an FPS game like Doom, this was mostly due to Bethesda forcing the name "Prey" onto anything that would stick and not realizing how many people were fans of the original IP who were also bummed out by the cancellation of Prey 2. 

Arkane knows how to make DLCs worth your time, which they proved with the Dishonored series, but with Prey they literally knocked it out of park. Mooncrash is an amazing rogue-lite experience that received literally no marketing, it released one year after the original game was out, even now you can only find SkillUp's video just straight up praising Mooncrash.

I think at one point, people are going to realize what they missed out on, this game is going to be the cult classic for many years to come, no other immersive sim comes even close to it. 

Everyone should play the mind game.

133377194.review: I'm a big fan of Arkane, I'm a big fan of Immersive Sims and I love System Shock but for some reasons the boxes didn't check for me on this game. First off I will say I did go into the game in the wrong way, when I found out Arkane made it I let myself expect Dishonored in Space, I didn't look at any trailers or pictures, I saw it was on sale so I bought it. So when I first got into the game, besides being blown away by the visuals I started to realize that this was gonna be more like System Shock and less like Dishonored, so once I got past that little mental hurdle I started to enjoy the game, all the interactions you can do are really impressive and it leads to a lot of "A ha!" moments when you finally figure out what to do, but to me that's all the game feels like it has to offer, it drags on and on and on and gets old once you've already discovered the intricacies of Talos 1 and even when you get past all the boring bits the ending just sorta drops on you, you are given a bunch of options to end the game at once that will impact the ending and it almost makes it feel like your choices throughout the game didn't really matter besides some dialogue, my favorite immersive sim, Deus Ex: Human Revolution does this kinda as well, but the over all enjoyment of that game makes up for it and also Human Revolution's endings are all more emotional in my eyes. Prey's twist was kinda lame too in my opinion, but what really gets me is it's just not memorable outside of the sticky note section or the Gloo Gun, when I think back to playing it, what mostly comes to mind is boring, dragging on sections and repetitiveness. It has all the great things that an Immersive Sim should have I suppose, that's why I recommend it, I recommend it to those who want to play more Immersive Sims but not to the ordinary gamer.

133376843.review:
Prey takes the Bioshock formula with a bit adjustments. The story progresses slowly and keeps a lot room for interpretation. It really depends on your own choices and the ended. Prey really shines with the exploration and side quests. 

A downside for me was the gameplay. Enemies were too strong so there was no other option than avoiding them if possible. If you like survival, you'll will enjoy it, because the enviroment several option to progress (most of the time).

Another downtime are bugs. Invisible crew members, etc. which makes it impossible to progress some side quests.

Over all I really enjoyed Prey and can recommend it, if you like survival and/or exploring.
